PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.
Debate resumed from 21 August, on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the Foreign States Immunities Bill. It is based on the 1984 report of the Law Reform Commission on foreign state immunity. That report was produced by the Commission in response to a reference given to it in November 1982 by the present honourable member for Menzies and Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N. A. Brown), who was then the Acting Attorney-General. The Government and the present Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) are to be commended on adopting the recommendations made in the report and bringing the Bill to the House. I join with the Attorney-General in congratulating the Law Reform Commission on an excellent report.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Bill is to state for the purposes of civil proceedings-but not, I emphasise criminal proceedings-in an Act of Parliament the law relating to the jurisdiction of Australian courts over foreign states, their agencies and instrumentalities, and in doing so to define the extent of immunity from jurisdiction of our courts of those states, agencies and instrumentalities, the scope of enforcement measures available against them and to deal with related procedural issues such as the service of process, waiver of immunity and discovery of documents, together with certain incidental matters.

The reasons for the Bill are to be found in the present state of the law. Rules of civil immunity of states have evolved in the courts through judge-made law. The genesis of the present immunity doctrine is obscure. The classic formulation of the doctrine is to be found in the decision of Chief Justice Marshall of the United States Supreme Court, speaking on behalf of the court in the case of the Schooner Exchange v. McFaddon in 1812. That decision, as the Law Reform Commission points out, is based on the reasoning of general principles in regard to territorial sovereignty, the equality and independence of states and notions of implied consent and is confirmed by anology from the personal immunities for heads of state, ambassadors and visiting forces by reference to treaty and other practice. The Schooner Exchange case did not decide whether the trading activities of a foreign state were protected. These activities came before the courts of the United States and England at a later stage. In England the Court of Appeal in 1880 in the Parliament Belge case held that the ship in question was the public property of a state and was destined to its public use, and that the mere fact of the ship being used subordinately and partially for trading purposes did not take away the general immunity. Later in 1920 in England and in 1926 in the United States the English Court of Appeal in the Porto Alexandre case and the United States Supreme Court in the Berizzi Brothers Co. v. Steamship Pesaro decided that even state-owned merchant ships were exempt from local jurisdiction.

Perhaps the most categorical statement of the absolute immunity rule is to be found in the decision of the House of Lords, England, in the Cristina case, another ship case, in 1938. Lord Aitkin, a famous and eminent English jurist, stated two explicit and broad propositions which he thought to be well established and beyond dispute. First the courts of a country will not implead a foreign sovereign-in contemporary language a foreign state-by forcing the foreign sovereign against his will to be a party to legal proceedings whether the proceedings involved process against his person or seek to recover from him specific property or damages. The second proposition went to the enforcement of judgments against a foreign sovereign. It was regardless of whether or not a foreign sovereign was party to proceedings the courts would not seize or detain property which is his of which he is in possession or control. Lord Aitkin held that this immunity extended to property used for commercial purposes.

It is fundamental to the fabric of a civilised society that laws be as just as we are capable of making them. It is always difficult, if not impossible, to arrive at any abstract tests that may be applied to laws, whether made by the courts or by parliament, to determine whether they are just. Jurists and philosophers have endeavoured in Western civilisation since at least the days of Socrates to devise tests against which the justness of laws could be measured. On balance, no test has ever been devised which has been found to be applicable to all the many circumstances that can arise and the many laws that may be considered. However, it is frequently not difficult to get widespread agreement on the question of whether or not a particular law is capable of producing injustice and the effect of Lord Aitkin's rule necessarily raises a very obvious question of justice. Why, in respect of commercial dealings, should foreign states have immunity? Is it just that citizens of another country, who enter into commercial transactions with foreign states, their agencies or instrumentalities, should be denied redress if those states break their contracts?

Quite clearly the rule stated by Lord Aitkin is unjust, however well founded that rule was. Nevertheless, for some 40 years it was applied to diverse situations in the courts of England and Australia. In England those situations included immunity to an action for libel against the official Soviet newspaper for a publication and news sheet called `The Soviet Monitor', and immunity to an action for breach of contract governed by English law and deemed to be made and performed there for the supply of German tanks. I was interested to note that the decision was given in 1951 so one can only assume that the tanks were somewhat shop soiled. The Germans have always been well known for making hardy and useful tanks.

In Australia the immunity rule led to the dismissal of a claim for breach of contract made within Australia for employment with a colonial government. That case involved the Netherlands Indies Government, which perhaps did not have very long to run in any event, and more curiously the dismissal of a claim against the United States Government, which arose out of the termination of a contract to provide a clothes cleaning service for members of United States forces on leave in Sydney. However, as the Law Reform Commission points out, an uncomfortable awareness developed in the English courts that the absolute immunity rule was not necessarily required by international law and practice, nor was it consistent with the position in many European countries. In 1977, the Privy Council held that foreign state-owned merchant vessels were not immune from a suit in an Admiralty action in rem; that is to say, an action brought against the vessel-the ordinary form of an action in rem. In the Privy Council's decision, it said:

In this country-and no doubt in most countries in the Western world-the state can be sued in its own courts on commercial contracts into which it has entered and there is no apparent reason why foreign states should not be equally liable to be sued there in respect of such transactions.

Here we see the development of a doctrine of restrictive immunity. In the same year, the English Court of Appeal in Trendtex Trading Corporation v. Central Bank of Nigeria applied the restrictive immunity rule to an action in personam; that is to say, an action directly against the person. That action arose from a commercial transaction and was brought against a state bank. This decision has since been approved by the House of Lords in a case called I Congress del Parido. The arbitrary distinction between actions in rem and in personam which had been suggested by a decision of the Privy Council was not given support. Lord Wilberforce, one of the most distinguished jurists of the last 50 years, summarised the restrictive theory of foreign state immunity in the leading speech. He said:

The relevant exception or limitation, which has been engrafted upon the principle of immunity of states, . . . arises from the willingness of states to enter into commercial or other private law, transactions with individuals . . . When therefore claim is brought against a state . . . and state immunity is claimed, it is necessary to consider what is the relevant act which forms the basis of the claim . . . is it a `private act' or is it a `sovereign or public act' a private act meaning in this context an act of a private law character such as a private citizen might have entered into.

As Lord Denning pointed out in the Trendtex case, in some countries the governmental departments conduct all their business through their own offices-even ordinary commercial dealings without setting up separate corporations or legal entities. In other countries, separate corporations are set up under the complete control of a department but enter into commercial transactions, buying and selling goods, just as ordinary trading concerns do. The difference in internal arrangements ought not to affect the availability of immunity in international law.

Moreover, the more the affairs of a country are the subject of government regulation, of which the prime example is the communist totalitarian states, where government control of commercial transactions is all pervasive, the more it will be found that perfectly ordinary commercial transactions will be entered into by bodies clothed with the outward indicia of the state, but which are, by any objective judgment, bodies entering into commercial transactions.

Faced with a choice between developing case law to meet the many problems that can arise or adopting statute law to lay down wide-ranging rules, the leading countries in the Anglo-American system of jurisprudence have opted for the statutory solution. In 1976 the United States of America enacted the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act. In 1978 the United Kingdom Parliament enacted the United Kingdom State Immunity Act to clarify the law of state immunity and to extend the scope of local jurisdiction and enforcement. Incidentally, and in light of the deregulation of the Australian financial sector-this is a matter of importance-a significant factor leading to the United Kingdom legislation, so the Law Reform Commission tells us, was pressure from London bankers and lawyers who were concerned at the possible loss of sovereign risk lending business to the United States. I might interpolate that since we have seen that some of that sovereign risk lending has been less than profitable to the lenders. In retrospect, that was something that they might have desired to stay out of, but certainly it is a field that one wishes to have the option of being in.

The state immunity law has since been adopted with little change by Singapore, Pakistan and South Africa, while Canada has adopted an Act which reflects the approach of both the United Kingdom and the United States Acts. The choice faced by Australia is to leave matters to the common law and to await an international agreement on the subject, or to legislate. To leave matters to the common law-that is, to develop them through judicial decisions-is fraught with uncertainty. There have been few cases in Australia on foreign state immunity. Much remains to be done in refining the doctrine of restrictive immunity, and as the other leading common law countries have enacted statutory rules to deal with all or many of the problems of foreign state immunity in civil proceedings, we will be denied the help of being able to learn from developments in the common law of state immunity in those jurisdictions. In effect, they will be applying a set of statutory rules.

Not only would leaving the law to be developed in the courts cause very great uncertainty as to what in particular cases the law may be, but also there are areas of state immunity which do not lend themselves easily, or in some cases at all, to developments through judge-made rules. These include the permissible scope of execution against foreign state assets. It is perfectly futile to have a judgment if it is not possible to satisfy that judgment, and indeed the costs of getting it, by execution against the assets of the defendant. The ambit of exceptions to state immunity relates to such matters as local property and trust funds, service of process, legal questions that can arise in such disparate areas as membership of corporations and partnerships, rights to trade marks, patents, copyright, registered design and trade or business names and actions to support those rights and liabilities on bills of exchange.

Australian domestic legislation is therefore necessary to remove the many areas of uncertainty in the law relating to foreign state immunity. Although there have been few Australian cases in this area to date, with increasing involvement by foreign states in investment, banking and other activities in Australia, that may not be the situation in the future, particularly if, as I hope, and believe most of us here hope, Australia becomes the banking centre for our region. The legislation before the House will not affect any immunity or privilege conferred by the Diplomatic Privileges and Immunities Act 1967, the Consular Privileges and Immunities Act 1972 and any other Commonwealth legislation which confers immunity on a foreign state.

The approach taken by the Bill, which follows the United Kingdom State Immunity Act 1978, is to confer as a general rule absolute immunity on foreign states, subject to a number of exceptions, which are stated in the Bill. These exceptions include commercial transactions. There will be no immunity where the proceedings concern commercial, trading, business, professional or industrial or like transactions, including contracts for the supply of goods or services or for loans or guarantees. Also included are contracts of employment. As a general rule, and subject to specific exceptions, the foreign state will not be immune in proceedings concerning a contract of employment that was made in Australia or is to be performed in Australia.

Another exception concerns torts. A foreign state will not be immune in proceedings concerning death or personal injury or loss or damage to property caused by an act or omission in Australia. This extends to motor vehicle accidents where the foreign state is liable vicariously for the actions of negligent drivers and to other torts, but not to the so-called economic torts such as defamation. Other areas in which the immunity of foreign states, their agencies and their instrumentalities is excluded or limited include actions involving immovable property; actions involving industrial or intellectual property; membership in locally formed partnerships, unincorporated bodies or corporations; liabilities arising out of bills of exchange and actions in rem against a ship if at the time the cause of action arose the ship was in use for commercial purposes.

The Bill will enable service of certain foreign states to be carried out by the Department of Foreign Affairs using diplomatic channels and extends the time limit for the entering of an appearance by foreign states. The property of foreign states will in certain circumstances not be immune from judgments obtained against it. The immunity from execution conferred on foreign state property will not apply to the commercial property of the foreign state. As I said earlier, the importance of the availability of execution against the property of a foreign state is paramount, as otherwise one goes through the toil and incurs the costs of obtaining judgment but is left without any effective remedy. Other matters with which the Bill deals concern questions arising in arbitration, discovery of documents, submission to the jurisdiction of Australian courts and immunities in related proceedings-that is, proceedings related to what may be described as the main action.

The Bill is a substantial step forward over the uncertain situation which presently exists in the area of law relating to foreign state immunity. In welcoming the Bill and commending the Government and the Attorney-General for bringing it forward, I would add only one last observation. It is possible that an international convention will be devised dealing with the question of foreign state immunity in civil proceedings. I would adopt the suggestion made in the report of the Law Reform Commission in paragraph 62 where the following is said:

In enacting legislation, the Commonwealth should express its willingness to reconsider the legislation in the event that a generally acceptable convention emerges from the work of the International Commission.
I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak in this debate because, whilst this matter is one which I think lay persons would see as a fairly erudite and rather boring subject, to those of us who know the impact that it can have in the lives of ordinary individuals it is no such thing. The Foreign States Immunities Bill reforms and codifies the proper behaviour of the Commonwealth of Australia towards foreign states which have representation in this country and also codifies the behaviour that Australia expects of foreign states by limiting their diplomatic immunity, especially in the area of trade and commercial transactions. Legislation of this type, I might say, is long overdue. This does not mean that in general foreign states have been remiss in their behaviour in Australia although there have been some cases which have required action if justice were to be given and in those cases justice was not available.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation recognises the fact that foreign states since the early nineteenth century have been entitled to some immunity from the courts of other countries. While immunity has been covered by common law in Australia, the limits which might be expected to be reasonable have been difficult to define. There is no doubt that progressive common law judgments have restricted diplomatic immunity to some extent. In those countries which do not have a common law background immunity of foreign states has been clearly defined. In some states with a common law background, that is, the United Kingdom, Canada, New Zealand, Singapore and South Africa, common law developments have been arrested by the advent of limiting legislation. There are good arguments for both extending some diplomatic immunity and limiting its scope which are based on restrictive immunity. There is not of course a single point of distinction between cases which should have immunity extended to them and those in which it should be limited. However, common law developments, before they were arrested by legislation in other common law countries, have been unclear and uncertain in a number of ways and this has presented a number of difficulties.

The uncertainties were highlighted in the Law Reform Commission report referred to in the second reading speech of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). That report listed them as follows: The necessity for closer jurisdictional links with state transactions than in other cases; the ambit of exception relating to local property, trust funds, et cetera; the permissible scope of execution against foreign state assets; and the proper methods of service of process and related procedural questions. These issues of course are extremely important if justice is to be done in dealing with foreign states. There are a number of reasons why these uncertainties must be clarified apart from the closing off of common law developments. These arise from the unsatisfactory nature of apparently settled common law questions such as waiver of immunity and the rigidity of the distinction between immune and non-immune transactions which is inappropriate and inadequate to deal with the complex issues now facing Australian courts.

There are other reasons why codification of the laws relating to foreign state immunity is required. These relate to the rights of the Australian public to day to day dealings with foreign states through commercial and domestic relations and the political rights of Australians to follow certain foreign policy options without their legality being challenged in the courts. The Law Reform Commission recommended in its report that codification of legislation was required in Australia. This Bill is in fact that recommended by the Commission with only minor drafting amendments which do not alter in any way the substance of the recommendations. The Commission, I might say, has done an excellent job in relation to this issue and should be congratulated. It has dealt with a sensitive subject and provided clear legislative guidelines for the Parliament to follow.

The Commission recommended, and this Bill provides for, a broad definition of `foreign state' which includes the Executive arm of the state plus departments and organs which act as agents or instrumentalities of the state in question. It makes no distinction between component political units of federal states but includes political subdivisions such as provinces, States and self-governing territories. This is an excellent recommendation which, if adopted internationally, would be another nail in the coffin of the ambiguity and uncertainty which has arisen in the relations between the states of independent nations and their former colonial masters.

The Bill provides that a foreign state may submit in advance to the jurisdiction of the Australian courts. Submissions can extend to prior agreement subject to specified limitations, exclusions or conditions. Immunity is deemed to be waived where a foreign state initiates proceedings or intervenes for purposes other than asserting immunity.

The Bill also provides for some very important exceptions to jurisdictional immunity, especially in the commercial and industrial arenas. It provides that commercial transactions be defined to include commercial trading, business, professional or industrial activities, in particular contracts for the supply of goods and services and agreements for loans for the provision of finance and guarantees for indemnities in respect of financial obligations. This is an important provision given the extent of state-owned commercial entities which now operate. In the days before the trend towards internationally greater government commercial activity such a Bill would have been less necessary, but since 1917 and 1949, to mark two notable shifts in the direction of government enterprise and activity on the world scale, quite obviously a Bill of this sort has become even more important.

For the benefit of the House I recall the great difficulty that the South Australian Government had when a ship, which belonged to the Chinese Government, rammed the pier at Wallaroo in about 1974. The Chinese Government, having caused some millions of dollars worth of damage to a facility in this country, immediately sought to exercise immunity on the basis that the ship was owned and operated by the appropriate department in China and, as it was a governmnent department, it could claim immunity and, therefore, not be liable for the damage. Fortunately, after proceedings through the courts to the higher courts, the common law was upheld as defeating that claim, but in order to do that-if I may make a comment about the judgment-there was a need for the court to extend the common law to protect the undoubted justice of ensuring that the Chinese should pay for the damage that had been caused by their wrong doing.

The Bill allows for Australian jurisdiction in the industrial area where contracts of employment are between a foreign state and a citizen or permanent resident of Australia. While this will not stop some unsavoury industrial relations practices to which some embassies have resorted in the past-notoriously, of course, the Philippines Embassy-it will, in most cases, protect Australians who work for foreign states, expecially in commercial areas. The rights of the Australian public will be guaranteed by the Bill with respect to ownership and protection of inventions, trade marks and copyright, and where they are locally established or controlled. They will be guaranteed by explicit non-immunity in proceedings concerning death or personal injury or loss of or damage to tangible property caused by an act or omission in Australia. That is a long overdue clarification of the law. Likewise, they will be protected in cases of bankruptcy, administration of trusts of deceased estates, et cetera. These are only some of the provisions of the Bill, although they are among the most important. The Law Reform Commission has made recommendations which, when adopted by the passage of the Bill into law, will put Australia in the forefront of the codification of diplomatic immunity, its extent and its limits. It is long overdue and will afford Australians as individuals and Australia as a nation the protection which they should expect and have operating in this country. I congratulate the Government on bringing the Bill forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to follow the honourable member for Makin (Mr Duncan). There will not be many occasions on which I will agree with him on matters before this House, but I am pleased to say that I join him in supporting the Foreign States Immunities Bill which the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has brought in. The reasons for the Bill are valid. We on this side of the House, as was discussed by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), in what I might say was a most detailed and excellent expose of the law on this subject, are pleased to support the Bill. Obviously the topic is one that does not captivate the attention of all honourable members; nevertheless it is an extremely important matter. In 1982 a report of the Joint Committee of the Law Council of Australia and the Maritime Law Association of Australia and New Zealand on Admiralty Jurisdiction in Australia recommended to the Federal Government that it consider enacting legislation comparable with the State Immunity Act 1978 of the United Kingdom. In October 1984 the Australian Law Reform Commission report No. 24 entitled `Foreign State Immunity' was tabled in this Parliament. As the honourable member for Makin said, it is an excellent report.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation we are discussing today is in broadly similar terms to that of the United Kingdom, Canada and the United States of America, which adopts a policy of `restrictive' immunity rather than the `absolute' immunity, which was the policy adopted by the common law until the 1970s. In very summary terms, because I do not think it is necessary to go into the detail that has been given by previous speakers, a foreign state will not be immune from the jurisdiction of local courts in disputes arising out of commercial transactions-this is the key to this legislation-ownership or use of local real property, local torts causing death, personal injury or damage to tangible property and a number of other matters to which the honourable member for North Sydney referred.

The advantages of the legislation are covered by the Attorney-General in his second reading speech. However, paramount amongst them is the certainty and predictability such Federal legislation will bring to an area of the common law which suffers from uncertainty. Additionally, there is no recent Australian case dealing with these issues and, thus, no direct authority for the restrictive immunity rule. Furthermore, as the Law Reform Commission correctly points out in my view, there would be doubt in an area such as this as to whether the common law unaided would keep pace with the community acceptance of local jurisdiction over such matters as personal injury arising as a result of a foreign state activity. So the `absolute' immunity doctrine is clearly not appropriate.

I would like to draw attention to clause 18 of the Bill which deals with actions in rem. Things maritime are, of course, of interest to me as a Tasmanian and having, as I do, the Australian Maritime College in my electorate. I might add that this college is the only one of its type in Australia. As a sometimes visiting lecturer at the College, I know that the complexity of the maritime legal jurisdiction gives both students and legal practitioners many concerns. We are moving slowly in this country to bring our maritime law into the twenty-first century. At the forefront of this move is the Australian and New Zealand Maritime Law Association; which, as I have already said, in 1982 joined with the Law Council of Australia to begin work on the Bill which we are finally discussing today.

As a nation ever more dependent on a successful export trade, we ought not to forget the strategic importance of our shipping laws in facilitating such trade. The Association does great work and it ought to be congratulated on its efforts. Clause 18 of the Bill seeks to remove a foreign state's immunity in actions in rem-that is, as was explained by the honourable member for North Sydney, an action against the object-so long as the vessel is engaged in commercial purposes. An important step is contained in clause 18 (2), which concerns `sister ship' arrest. At present, Australian admiralty jurisdiction, which is dependent on the Colonial Courts of Admiralty Act 1890 of the United Kingdom, does not allow for such arrest. This change has the practical result of being able to pursue a `sister ship' in an action in rem if the primary ship has departed. Both ships must be in use or intended for use for commercial purposes. In effect, it means that if a ship of government X calls to collect perhaps a live sheep shipment and departs prior to payment of all obligations, the next ship from government X to call to collect a following sheep shipment will not be immune. So an act in rem can commence to make good the prior ship's default. I think the example that was given by the honourable member for Makin about the Chinese incident is also particularly important bearing in mind the difficulties that we face or have faced in trying to pursue common law remedies against ships owned by foreign governments or their agencies. I believe that this measure is particularly important to Australian trade. Indeed, the whole Bill is extremely important. I have great pleasure in supporting the Attorney-General. I congratulate him on introducing this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of foreign states immunity and diplomatic immunity is of great importance to Australia. The first experience of this matter that I had was when I was a law student working at the High Court of Australia with people from Canberra. They told all sorts of horrendous stories about diplomats and diplomatic staff running people down as they drove around this fair city. Such injured people could allegedly make no claim. They were denied their common law damages awards. Fortunately that situation has been resolved. The whole issue and all the side issues contained in the Foreign States Immunities Bill 1985 have been canvassed in a very worthwhile report brought down by the Law Reform Commission. I congratulate the former Chairman, the Hon. Justice Kirby, and the members of the Commission, on bringing down an excellent report which other speakers have dealt with at some length.

SPEECH.PARA: Our nation plays host to a million tourists a year. We are told that there are vast numbers of illegal migrants in our country. Many Australians, as we all know-in particular, members of parliament know-marry overseas, marry tourists who are visiting the country or non- Australians. There are many situations in which foreign law prevails. People get in touch with their embassies and claim that they are outside the jurisdiction of Australia and are not subject to the laws of Australian courts. Some people seek to claim immunity from the criminal process, and from being arrested. The Law Reform Commission's report pointed out that the common law remains unclear. That was one of the points made in Mr Justice Kirby's report. It detailed a number of areas in which the common law should be clarified. In particular, it pointed out the necessity for closer jurisdictional links with state transactions than in other cases. It also stated that the ambit of exceptions relating to local property, trust funds, et cetera, should be clarified, that the permissible scope of execution against foreign state assets should be clarified and that the proper methods of service of process and related procedural questions should be sorted out. In places such as Sydney, which has a very large diplomatic corps, and Canberra, which has an even bigger diplomatic and consular representation, this is important in the case of trades people, and servicemen and all sorts of people who deal with embassies. Historically, at common law, embassies and consular buildings have been exempt from town planning regulations, rates, taxation and public health and safety laws that apply to everyone else in our nation.

The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) introduced the legislation that we are debating today. The essence of the legislation is that until the 1970s it was generally thought that at common law foreign states and their agencies were entitled to absolute immunity from jurisdiction. Under this legislation exceptions will be clearly laid down. Essentially, the legislation will decline to accord immunity in respect of commercial transactions. Many nations-and political divisions within nations-provinces and states conduct commercial transactions. It has been essential for Australia to codify the situation. Commercial transactions will no longer be immune. The second reading speech of the Attorney stated:

This includes all contracts for the supply of goods or services or for loans or guarantees . . . It is an essential step if Australia is to develop as an international banking centre conducting sovereign risk lending.
The Attorney also highlighted the following point:
Torts resulting in death, physical injury or damage to tangible property will not be immune if committed in Australia by the foreign state or by its servants acting in the course of their employment.

Tort is a legal word for a wrong, hurt or injury of some kind. The Attorney gave an example of a person injured in a road accident involving diplomatic personnel acting in the course of their employment. The person so injured and aggrieved will be able to sue the state for damages. The diplomatic person, of course, will be protected but the foreign state may be sued. The Attorney pointed out also that where only an economic loss is suffered by a tort such as defamation, misrepresentation, deceit or negligent misstatement, unless it is a commercial misstatement, there will be no liability. This harks back to the point made by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) that in one of the early British decisions the Soviet Embassy in Britain was held immune from defamation proceedings when it published apparently defamatory material which was a reprint of a Soviet newspaper article. The Soviet Embassy regurgitated this material. Proceedings were taken in Britain, yet there was deemed to be no legal claim for defamation.

The other areas the legislation covers involve employment contracts concerning Australians entered into by foreign governments. But, of course, foreign nationals who are not permanent residents or Australian nationals will not be so protected. Disputes concerning immovable property-for example, land-will not be immune. If an embassy buys a building or enters into a lease or timesharing arrangement in a capital city in Australia, there is no immunity if the embassy refuses to pay. There are rights for the vendor to take proceedings against the embassy. The other matters for which immunity will to some extent be removed include disputes involving industrial and intellectual property, membership by the foreign state in locally formed partnerships, companies or bodies corporate and the conduct of arbitrations. The legislation provides for voluntary submission to the jurisdiction.

The legislation has been extensively dealt with by the other speakers. There are provisions whereby the Attorney-General can arrange for the service of writs through the Department of Foreign Affairs using diplomatic services. The legislation essentially follows legislation in the United Kingdom and other countries. Without delaying the House further, I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my colleagues the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) and the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), together with the members of the Government, in welcoming the Foreign States Immunities Bill. I thank the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher), who preceded me, for his contribution. I hasten to add, however, that the immunity for diplomats to whom he referred continues to extend for any criminal liability they may incur. This legislation will allow the people who are hurt in a case such as the example the honourable member for Lowe gave-by a diplomat driving a motor vehicle-to commence civil actions against the state as the diplomat's employer. However, the previous exemptions relating to a diplomat's immunity under criminal legislation will continue. The legislation will not affect any immunity or privilege conferred by the Diplomatic Privileges and Immunities Act 1964, the Consular Privileges and Immunities Act 1972 and any other Commonwealth legislation which confers immunity on a foreign state.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to put to rest many of the uncertainties relating to the jurisdiction of Australian courts over foreign states. As honourable members have been informed, since the early nineteenth century Australia has recognised that foreign states are in a special position when brought as defendants before the courts. A fundamental plank of our common law system is that these states are entitled to some immunity from jurisdiction of the courts. Nonetheless, over the passage of time a distinction has arisen between a state's act of sovereignty as opposed to its private law or business transactions. It is, in my view, correct to draw that distinction and to allow a foreign state to be brought before the courts as a defendant when it is engaging in private law or business transactions. A great many doubts and criticisms over the absolute immunities provided to foreign states have arisen, particularly over the last 15 or 20 years, in light of the trend in international law and the position of civil law in other countries that have long distinguished between governmental and private transactions of those states. Therefore, this legislation will do much to clarify the position of foreign states' immunities in Australia.

The legislation results from a report and recommendations of the Australian Law Reform Commission on foreign states immunities and the draft Bill which was included in that report. I join with the honourable member for North Sydney in congratulating the Commission on its very detailed and productive study. The Commission's report no doubt will be studied closely by both scholars and legislators in other countries, with a view perhaps to codifying at least to some extent their own jurisdiction in this area. As honourable members will know, many common law jurisdictions, such as the United Kingdom and Canada, have already legislated to restrict immunity of foreign states. At present common law governs the question of foreign state immunity in Australia and I believe legislation is vitally necessary to clarify areas of uncertainty in the law. It must be said that the present law in Australia is uncertain and that there are few, if any, recent Australian cases which can be referred to as authority. It is likely that prior to this legislation Australian courts would have had to follow the English precedents, as I understand earlier Australian cases did. Needless to say, changes in international law and foreign relations mean that Australia cannot afford such a vulnerability.

It is true to say that much of the approach in this Bill follows the United Kingdom State Immunity Act 1978. It confers as a general rule absolute immunity on foreign states, subject to a number of exceptions. The exceptions enumerated in the Bill include commercial transactions. There will be no immunity where the proceedings involve commercial, trading, business or professional transactions, including contracts for the supply of goods or services or for loans or guarantees. As honourable members will know, this will simply bring Australian law into line with the law in other financial centres, such as New York, London and Singapore. As the honourable member for North Sydney mentioned, if ever we are to become the international banking capital of at least the Pacific basin, measures such as this will have to be tackled by the Federal Government so that we can compete with those other centres of Singapore and Hong Kong.

Another exception enumerated in the Bill will be contracts of employment. Unless the employee is a foreign national and not a permanent resident or national of Australia, employment contracts entered into by foreign states will not be immune from proceedings in Australia. Looking at the law of torts, a foreign state will not be immune where it wrongfully causes death or personal injury or damages property within Australia. However, immunity will be retained by the foreign state in respect of the so-called economic torts, such as defamation, deceit and misrepresentation unless the tort occurs in the course of a commercial transaction. Other matters from which immunity will be removed include disputes concerning immovable property, such as land actions involving industrial and intellectual property, membership by the foreign state in a locally formed partnership company or body corporate, and the conduct of arbitrations.

The legislation makes provision for a foreign state to submit voluntarily to the jurisdiction of Australian courts. This may be done by written agreement or by submission to the court. I may say, perhaps with the cynicism acquired from some years practice in the law, that it is difficult to understand a defendant voluntarily submitting to be brought before the courts. However, we trust that the need to preserve good relations with many of our trading partners will be such that they will in many cases voluntarily submit to the jurisdiction of the Australian courts. If over the years a practice has arisen where that is not adhered to by a number of international bodies, it may well be that this legislation will have to be looked at further.

The legislation will enable service of certain foreign states to be carried out by the Department of Foreign Affairs using diplomatic channels, and also extends the time limit for the entering of an appearance by a foreign state. They are matters which are to be welcomed and are a natural progression of allowing the issuing of proceedings to be freed. After all, there is not a great deal of point in allowing proceedings to be issued against foreign states if the service of documents and the entering of appearance are restricted. Furthermore, property of foreign states will be immune from execution to satisfy judgments obtained against them, subject to specified exemptions. Commercial property, property used by a foreign state substantially for commercial purposes is not immune from execution, nor is immovable property once a successful judgment has been brought against such property.

In conclusion, I advise the House that the legislation will clarify the law relating to the immunity of a head of state acting in a private capacity. The legislation confers the same immunities on a head of state and spouse as on a head of a diplomatic mission similarly acting. I welcome the legislation. I echo the comments of my colleagues that it is well overdue and will do much to bring Australian law into line with the common law countries, such as the United Kingdom and Canada. It will do much to assist corporations as well as individuals to obtain justice where previously justice was unobtainable

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Interstate Road Transport Bill concurrently with the Interstate Road Transport Charge Bill. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Interstate Road Transport Bill 1985 and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Bill 1985, which are the result of the National Road Freight Industry Inquiry. I commend the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) for his initiative in establishing the inquiry and maintaining the momentum to this point. The coalition supports the overall aim of the legislation but it is concerned about the questions of adequate consultation, reliance and regulation and unresolved details of implementation. I will refer to these in greater detail later in my comments and at the Committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: The road transport industry is of great importance to the Australian economy. The vastness of Australia has provided a particular challenge for the reliable and efficient movement of freight and people. The road freight industry is the principal mover of all freight except for bulk commodities such as wheat and coal. Interstate coach and bus services have developed remarkably in recent years and now offer a most comprehensive, cost-efficient and flexible service for a rapidly increasing number of Australians.

However, the interstate road freight industry has a turbulent history of instability, a high number of owner-operator bankruptcies, low morale, price cutting, speeding, maintenance and safety standard problems and pressure on drivers. This is apparent to anyone who lives in a regional centre or a suburb with a concentration of truckies or to someone who travels along major interstate highways such as the Hume. Most Hume Highway travellers have special stories of being pursued downhill at 140 kilometres an hour by a 38-tonne truck or having to pass a long line of slow-moving, closely-packed heavy transports up a hill.

Road safety statistics verify some of the additional and special problems created by heavy vehicles moving too fast or too slowly or problems with safety and maintenance standards. The industry has been acutely aware of its problems, including the lack of uniformity between the States in registration arrrangements, speed limits, axle loadings, safety checks and so on. Therefore the proposal of the Minister for Transport to conduct a national inquiry had the wholehearted support of the industry, as well as that of the State and Territory Ministers responsible for transport and roads, at the July 1983 meeting of the Australian Transport Advisory Council, ATAC.

On 12 September 1983 the Minister announced that he had appointed a committee to conduct the inquiry comprising three members-Mr Thomas May, the Chairman, Professor Gordon Mills and Mr Jim Scully. This committee presented its report in 1984 and on 11 October 1984, Stephen Lusher, the then shadow Minister for Transport and honourable member for Hume, indicated in Parliament the general support of the Opposition parties for the recommendations. The inquiry produced about 98 recommendations designed for implementation on a national basis to cover both Federal and State spheres, but principally the State sphere. The recommendations provided a basis for action in a wide range of areas affecting the trucking industry such as cost recovery, licensing, safety, vehicle mass and load limits, finance and insurance for the trucking industry, and research and consultation with the industry and government.

Today's legislation encompasses an immediate objective of implementing two Federal and five State government initiatives which are complementary and which cannot be fully effective without complete adoption by all governments. Federally, they are the introduction of legislation providing for the registration of vehicles and the licensing of operators engaged in interstate trade and commerce and the establishment of the Australian Road Freight Transport Advisory Committee within the Transport Industry Advisory Council. For the States, they are, firstly, the introduction of graduated truck driver licences which will require that the drivers operating the large interstate vehicles have had appropriate experience. Secondly, improvements in railway cost recovery are to match any improvements in cost recovery in the road freight industry. That would also apply to Australian National. I understand that it applies to inter-system or interstate rail freight. Thirdly, they include the introduction of the May committee's reforms relating to finance and insurance and to providing owner-operators with access to existing consumer protection arrangements. Fourthly, fees charged by some States on vehicles already registered in another State are to be removed. Finally, they include the removal of the speed limit differential between trucks and other vehicles outside built-up areas.

There is also provision for the implementation of other recommendations including those concerning safety standards and, possibly, mandatory monitoring devices. I understand that these and the operators' licence scheme will be introduced at a later stage. These cause the most concern to the Opposition. I have been advised that the earliest that the first stage-or fast track package, as the Minister likes to call it-can be implemented is 1 July 1986, because the States will not pass their necessary legislation on speed limits and so on until the 1986 autumn sessions of parliament. The Inter-state Commission will also report at the end of April 1986 on cost recovery for interstate road and rail services.

The road freight industry has suffered from State regulation over the years but the freedom of interstate trade provisions in the Constitution have allowed interstate operators to pay considerably less than their intrastate colleagues, particularly for registration. For example, the standard registration cost for a typical State-registered truck in New South Wales is $2,543 or $27 for interstate registration. In Victoria, it costs $1,500 for State registration and there is no charge for interstate registration. South Australia charges $1,543 or $10 for interstate registration and Western Australia charges $1,606 for State registration and $9.50 for interstate. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The May report recommended $1,400 as a suitable Federal interstate registration charge for the maximum weight vehicle, to which should be added approximately $300 for third party insurance-hence the $1,700 figure. This is lower that the average of the State charges to which I have just referred. There are approximately 15,000 interstate registration trucks at present. This legislation offers their owners, or for that matter the owners of any trucks engaged in interstate trade, three choices of registration. The first is to use State registration. The second is to pay the Federal annual fees of $1,400 for the heaviest 38-tonne vehicle. The fee is graduated accordingly for vehicles below that weight and thirdly, consequent upon the installation of a monitoring device, a charge per kilometre may be paid.

SPEECH.PARA: The annual fee could alter when the Inter-State Commission reports on cost recovery. The issuing and collection of Federal fees will be administered by the States. It has been said that only one additional officer would be needed in the Department of Transport to cover the Federal responsibility for not only the Federal registration arrangements but all the aspects of the legislation. I ask the Minister whether this is so. The fees collected from Federal registration will be paid into a trust fund. All those moneys will be allocated to the States for the actual repair of roads frequently used by interstate transports. The safeguard that all the money will be so used is that to do otherwise could result in a constitutional challenge.

I understand that the Minister will determine the actual allocation to be made each year. It is estimated that if approximately two-thirds of the owners of the presently interstate registered vehicles opt for the Federal annual fee about $14m could be collected. However, in time this percentage could fall if there is seen to be no advantage in Federal registration. I hope that this actually happens so that we have increasingly State-only registration. The States will also charge a $20 processing fee for Federal registrations. I ask the Minister: Is this correct? Will there be an additional fee for anyone accepting the option of having a truck registered as a Federal interstate vehicle?

The road transport industry organisations must be congratulated for their continuing support for the removal of the anomaly between interstate and State registrations of vehicles. They are well aware of the cost pressure in the industry where rates have fallen in recent years while fuel, spare parts and replacement vehicle costs have risen dramatically. An additional $1,400 is extra pain for them, but individual operators I have spoken to, as well as the organisations, accept that this is part of a package which they believe will overall improve the standard of the industry. They have mentioned to me the possibility of payment of the registration fee by instalments, and I put this point to the Minister also. I hope that the questions that I am putting sincerely to the Minister will be responded to, either in the Minister's closing remarks or during the Committee stage, because they are questions that concern not only me but also everyone in the industry, and at least some of the States, and we all want an answer.

The differences between the extremes of $2,500 and nil cannot be sustained, particularly when one considers the oft quoted statistic that one journey by a 38 tonne six-axle rig does as much road damage as 10,000 cars and when one also takes into account that the ordinary private motorist is paying $150 to $200 for annual registration fees. There is also industry concern that the States and the Federal Government in concert will periodically raise the cost of registration charges beyond a reasonable level once the interstate loophole is blocked. The report of the Inter-state Commission is of considerable importance here as a check to such a practice. If the Commission believes that $1,400, together with the several thousands of dollars collected from fuel excise, is adequate cost recovery for damage to roads done by those vehicles, the Federal annual fee should act as a barrier to such a practice. However, I do raise with the Minister the comment on page 243 of the May report that once a fee which is a suitable cost recovery fee is established, State fees should or will be lowered to that level. This is of considerable concern to the industry. Will this happen? Will all of the fees come to a uniform charge-and that could mean the lowering of those higher State fees-or will the State fees continue to be at a higher level?

I also raise for the Minister's response that on the same page of the May report is the statement that government authority vehicles engaged in commercial activity, such as Telecom and Australia Post, should be subject to the same charges and conditions. Will this happen? Where we have authorities, correctly in many cases, engaging more and more in commercial activity in competition with the private sector, I consider it only right and proper that they should be subject to the same charges, including the same vehicle registration operator licence safety standard requirements, et cetera.

In fact, the road transport industry support for this package of legislation is one of faith in two ways. The first way is that Federal involvement is to assist the States and the industry to obtain better standards and uniformity of standards and it is not for the Commonwealth to interfere in the State area of responsibility or to push the States and the industry. The second way is for the Minister not to proclaim any of the legislation until all of the five State requirements are met in full and are actually in operation. I emphasise that requirement-that all of the five State requirements are met in full and are actually in operation.

For the Minister to do otherwise would be a breach of faith and could cause chaos in the industry. For example, for the new fees to be in place while the States are only considering intersystem rail freight increases but not having those rail freight increases actually in place, would be completely unfair and unacceptable to an industry which is already committed, if the registration fee is proclaimed, to a higher charge or a higher operating cost without any ability to recover those charges in freight rates. The goodwill of the industry and the credibility of the Minister relies on the requirement that one will not happen without the other. I am concerned that in his second reading speech the Minister states:
I expect the vehicle registrations scheme to be proclaimed once substantial progress has been made on implementing the other parts of the fast-track package.

I draw the attention of the Minister, the House and the industry to the words `substantial progress'-not complete progress or not everything in place and in operation before any proclamation takes place.

I have been told that there is a memorandum of understanding between the Commonwealth and the States on this package. I ask the Minister to release publicly that memorandum so that everyone has confidence that all the parties will play their part and will play their part in the correct way at the correct time. Motorists and responsible truck operators also want the assurance of the State governments that if trucks with adequate braking standards are permitted to travel legally at 100 kilometres per hour or whatever the general State limit is they are subject to police enforcement of that limit and not subject to the present apparent lack of any enforcement. Unless there is far greater police enforcement of the road speed limits in relation to interstate trucks than at present all we will have done is substitute an 80 kilometre starting point, which one can exceed, with a 100 kilometre limit which one can exceed by a similar amount. I believe that responsible truck operators-and that is obviously the vast majority-are just as anxious as the ordinary motorists to have that assurance because they can then feel that they can safely and securely abide by that new speed limit requirement in this most competitive industry.

I understand that general support has been given to the legislation at Australian Transport Advisory Council meetings and that State officials and industry representatives were recently and briefly shown the draft legislation. Several proposed amendments have been accepted and I commend the Minister for that. However, the States were led to believe that they would be consulted again on the final legislation before it was introduced to Parliament. Several State Ministers were surprised to hear from me of its introduction last Wednesday and even more surprised to hear of its intended passage through the House today. My posting to them of the Bills and speeches et cetera was their first opportunity to view the final legislation, and some received this material only on Monday.

This raises the general concern that the Opposition has about the legislation and is the reason why I will move an amendment for the legislation to be withdrawn, redrafted and reintroduced at the beginning of the autumn session so that greater consultation can take place and many of the uncertainties of this legislation can be overcome. We believe that more exposure of the legislation is necessary because of the uncertainty as to how many of the aspects will be implemented, possible gaps and contradictions in the legislation, the too great a dependence on regulations and the uncertainty of the definitions. As the main purpose of the legislation is to provide an umbrella for the States to achieve greater uniformity, as no State government to my knowledge will be legislating before the autumn session next year-in fact, they have given me the impression that they are in no great hurry or urgency actually to introduce legislation-and as the Inter-state Commission will be reporting at the end of April and therefore the earliest possible date of implementation is 1 July 1986, we believe our action is responsible and constructive.

I want to mention a few of the uncertainties which the Opposition, the industry and the States want clarified. I will discuss them in more detail in Committee. The States are anxious to have a more definite formula for the distribution of the trust fund money. Country people want an assurance that local and arterial roads used by interstate operators will receive a fair share of that trust fund. They also want to know that all of the fund proceeds, including interest, go to roads, and that none of it goes to Federal or State administration. The Opposition and the industry want to know how much the States will charge for the Federal registration and for the mandatory safety checks as they are introduced at State level. Will there be an additional charge for federally registered vehicles? In other words, will anyone who takes that option really be paying more?

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—Well, we already have the figure of $20 for the registration fee. I certainly want that clarified. How much will the States charge for operator licences, both originally and annually? Once again, will there be a loading on federally registered operators? I have heard figures ranging from $30 to $50 for the issuing of those licences. Is there really a need for annual operator licences? Why not have three-year licences as recommended, as this would reduce the paper work at the State level? Will the smaller States be assisted in establishing inspection facilities? If not, will Federal and State registration be easier and cheaper in some States where these facilities are not in place? That certainly is one of the problems at the moment, as the level of safety requirements varies from State to State. What guarantee is there that the States will remove all their restrictions on out-of-State or federally registered vehicles so that there is a complete Australia-wide acceptability of any Federal or any State registration? For example, I am told that New South Wales has a special limited bus registration for certain tourist situations.

SPEECH.PARA: There is particular concern that the whole subject of safety is contained in one general paragraph. Clause 34 of the Interstate Road Transport Bill reads:
For the purpose of this Part, the Minister may, by order in writing, declare standards, to be known as federal road safety standards, with respect to road safety matters.

I do not believe that that is good enough. It relies completely on statutory rules and, although subject to parliamentary disallowance, this does not cover the objections from the Opposition or the industry on the grounds of vagueness. Will the Minister just invoke the necessary rules to complement those agreed to by the States, or will the Commonwealth become a pace-setter? How inclusive will these safety standards be? Will they be so embracing that the petty non-safety matters presently complained about by operators in New South Wales will be generally applied? Will Federal standards conflict with State standards? If so, which will prevail?

A further safeguard for the industry against hasty and ill-considered regulations would be a requirement, presently in place in some State legislation, that the industry be given 30 days notice before any regulations are introduced. I sincerely put that proposition to the Minister for consideration. There is also confusion over registration charges and the separate registration of the prime mover and the trailer. To be fair and uniform a 38 tonne rig should be charged $1,400 whether it is a total rig or a separately registered prime mover and trailer. The present schedule of fees does not appear to me to indicate that this will be the case. There is also the question of graduated charges below that. There is also the problem of differences between the States on how prime movers and trailers are registered. I have been told that in Victoria one can register both the prime mover and the trailer on the one number plate and then transfer the trailer part of the plate to another trailer-that poses some interesting questions on safety standards-but that in other States the two have to be registered separately.

There is also the point about reimbursement for part intrastate work with an interstate licence. Does that mean that a State registration is also necessary or is that a loophole that allows lower cost registration? Monitoring devices also cause concern in relation to both civil liberties in police and road authority action and the provision for them to be mandatory. I understand that such devices are mandatory in a number of countries and could be so in the future in several Australian States. Will the Commonwealth require their installation for a federally registered vehicle even if all the States do not and the operator has opted for the annual rather than the per kilometre fee? I understand that at least one State will not require the mandatory fitting of such devices.

The Minister has also indicated that all of the administration and enforcement of the registration and operator licences and safety standards will be carried out by State officials and that the only exception will be the option for a case to be heard in a Federal court. I want his assurance that this will be so and that a new Federal bureaucracy duplicating the States will not be established. I also put to the Minister the option of deleting altogether from the legislation some of those provisions to be implemented later so that the Bill is restricted to the first stage, for which there is more detailed information and agreement.

There are also definition problems. As I understand it, one of them includes a possible problem with the 100 kilometre exemption, the exemption for vehicles moving across State borders for distances of less than 100 kilometres, in that such vehicles are exempted from the need for an operator's licence. If they are so exempted, does that mean that they have to have State registration as well? Is their Federal registration useless outside that 100 kilometre limit? I could go on. I also acknowledge the value of the Australian Road Freight Transport Advisory Committee which the Minister is establishing within the Transport Industry Advisory Committee, and the need for it to be operating as soon as possible. To my knowledge, that is not dependent upon the passage of this legislation. A valuable starting point for that Committee would be the clarification and redrafting of this legislation for presentation in the autumn session. I, therefore, move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst supporting the overall aim of the Bill, the House is of the opinion that the Bill be withdrawn and, following more adequate consultation of its details with the industry and the States, be redrafted to remove its current excessive reliance on regulation, for presentation in redrafted form at the commencement of the 1986 Autumn sittings'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in support of the Interstate Road Transport Bill and Interstate Road Transport Charge Bill. I oppose the amendment moved by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). Few industries are as misunderstood in Australia as the trucking industry. I can speak from some personal experience on this subject. My father was in the industry for many years and my brother and two brothers-in-law are in the industry now. In Australia, the road transport industry is fairly easy to get into; yet, once in, operators find it virtually impossible to leave of their own accord. The problems and instability are reflected by the rate of bankruptcy-amongst the highest of any industry in Australia. The life of the truckie, in reality, is far removed from the somewhat romantic picture portrayed in some trucking songs. The hours are long; the work is arduous and often dangerous; the pressure on health is serious; and the pressure on home life must be almost as severe as the pressure on a politician's family life.

SPEECH.PARA: We may ask why anyone enters the industry. Many do so for a variety of reasons. I feel that often when people start out, especially as owner operators, they do not fully appreciate what they are letting themselves or, indeed, their families, in for. But whatever motivates them, these circumstances have their human face. The small businessman who, having invested everything in his trucking operation, may find that he loses not only his business but also his house and often his family. Those who stay in the industry face the prospect of a continuing battle of living hand to mouth, often working long hours and pushing themselves and their trucks to the limit. Whilst claims are often made that some even go beyond limits to endanger safety, the vast majority in the industry attempt to do a good, honest job in a most professional manner.

The importance of the road transport industry to Australia cannot be overemphasised. Some 70 per cent of all freight is moved at some stage by this industry, but despite the industry's role and importance it has lacked clear national direction. Previous governments have all but ignored pleas for help from the industry. It was not until the Hawke Labor Government came to power that there was a Federal government prepared to take a comprehensive look at the industry. Not least of these measures was the commissioning of the National Road Freight Industry Inquiry. The legislation being debated is a first step in implementing the recommendations of that report, commonly referred to as the May report. It is landmark legislation. It also represents another element in achieving the Federal Government's national transport objectives which include the development of safe and efficient transport systems for the movement of goods and people both within Australia and in international trade, providing the opportunity for all Australians to have reasonable access to transport services for employment, business, recreational and other needs, and implementing these aims in the most socially effective way.

The legislation should also be seen in the context of the principles which guide this Government's involvement in transport. Simply stated, these principles include investing in transport infrastructure where there is a clear economic and social justification and requiring users to meet the full costs of government-provided infrastructure and services to improve economic efficiency. The only exception should be where there are clearly identified social requirements. There has been extensive consultation with State and Territory governments and the industry. Most have strongly supported the Government's moves. I was therefore somewhat surprised to read in the Australian Financial Review of Friday, 13 September this year, that the Executive Director of the Australian Road Transport Federation, Mr Tony Hargreaves, had criticised the legislation, saying that it could be disastrous for small transport operators. He argued that there will be difficulties with administration and immediate cost increases, but throughout the industry there has been a favourable reaction to this legislation. I might add that there has always been within the industry a high expectation that this Government would act quickly to introduce worthwhile reforms, and discussions will continue to be held with industry representatives on the legislation and the method of its operation. This indicates this Government's recognition of the need for consultation in the reform process. As we are undertaking taxation reform in consultation, so it will be with transport reform. We are a government that not only is prepared to talk to all sections of the industry but also welcomes consultation with them.

The general thrust of the inquiry's report was endorsed in December 1984 by the Australian Transport Advisory Council, which comprises Federal, State and Territory Ministers responsible for transport and marine matters and an initial fast-track package of reforms based on the inquiry's recommendations was subsequently endorsed by ATAC in June 1985. The report and the subsequent fast-track package have received broad industry and general community support as these groups have recognised that the recommendations must be implemented as a package. The fast-track package endorsed by ATAC involved the following initiatives: For the Federal Government, the introduction of legislation providing for the registration of vehicles and the licensing of operators engaged in interstate trade and commerce and the establishment of the Australian Road Freight Transport Advisory Committee-ARFTAC-within the Transport Industry Advisory Council. For the State governments, there will be the introduction of graduated truck driving licences which will require that the drivers operating the large interstate vehicles have had appropriate experience; improvements in railway cost recovery to match any improvement in cost recovery in the road freight industry-this would also apply to the Australian National Railways Commission; the introduction of the May reforms relating to finance and insurance to provide owner-operators with access to existing consumer protection arrangements; the removal of fees charged by some States on vehicles already registered in another State; and removal of the speed limit differential between truck and other vehicles outside built-up areas. The fast-track package represents a balanced set of reforms for the industry designed to increase professionalism, improve overall safety and set in place a workable cost recovery program.

This legislation is of great importance to the industry and will lead not only to greater efficiencies but also to an improved image for the industry. Too often we hear truck drivers referred to as highway cowboys, causing carnage and death as they race to make a delivery or a quick buck. Then there is the truckies' unreal reputation as free-wheeling, loose-living hell's angels on 40-tonne steeds. Of course, as in all industries, there are rogue truck drivers and there are a few who bring discredit to the industry. Although there are a few who may bring discredit to the industry, there are many, the vast majority, who do a great job for Australia and do it with great safety. Many of the rogues in the business are not the drivers but the owners, owners who in the past have not carried out adequate maintenance on their vehicles and who have put unrealistic demands on the drivers. This legislation will go some way to overcoming these practices and thus to making our roads safer.

When we talk about road safety sometimes I think there is too much emphasis on the drivers and not enough on, say, the operators or the companies. We hear about accidents but, as the May report rightly says, the level of involvement of trucks in road accidents is not excessive when account is taken of the great distance travelled by trucks. Perhaps we could do more in road safety. One area which I am particularly interested in and which we should look at some time is the possibility of having a lighted triangle on the front of road trains. This would be of great benefit in places such as the Northern Territory where these road trains operate.

Perhaps governments should also accept some of the blame for the condition of our roads. At least this Government is doing something to improve the condition of our roads. If the previous Government had done more for road improvement and put more money into roads, many truckies and road users would be alive today. But it is not all the truckies' fault. Caravans, in my view, are a greater menace on the road than big rigs. Caravans trundle along the road and up hills causing huge traffic jams and frustrations. If ever anything should be barred from the roads or require a special licence, in my view it is caravans. I hope that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport Safety will examine caravans. Car drivers are also at fault in the way that they behave on the road. Far be it from me to suggest that all truck drivers are blameless. I have driven too frequently on the Picton-Appin road when a ship has been at the coal loader in Port Kembla to make this claim that they are all blameless.

I particularly welcome the introduction by State governments of graduated truck driver licences and finance and insurance reforms for private owner-drivers. Regarding licences, it has for some time worried me that there is no graduated scheme. I have felt, with today's potentially lethal trucks in the hands of the inexperienced, that more categories and more experience on the road should be required before a driver can move up to the big rigs. The days when one could go out and get a licence on a little Bedford without a load and then buy a Kenworth and go out on the road with it fully loaded are over, and this will be welcomed by the industry.

Truckies are often accused of treating the road laws with contempt. Many of the laws they break, some claim, are out of line with modern society and absurd in the light of today's high powered trucks. But considering the number of trucks on the road, an indication of which is that as many as 4,000 heavy vehicles pass over the weighbridges at Marulan in the southern highlands of New South Wales in a single night, in the main they do obey the law. It is almost unbelievable that in Australia today an operator can commence a journey complying with regulations governing vehicle weight, speed limits and conditions for registration and before completing his journey into another State find himself in breach of that State's laws governing weight, speeds and the like. This will change. In winding up, I inform the House that it was my pleasure to be at the truck drivers cabaret in Shellharbour last Saturday night, and at the truck show last Sunday.
