I would like to turn to another issue which I think is most important as part of this legislative program. I am sure it is a matter which appeals to the economic dries on the other side. A question was raised about the setting of freight rates as a means of improving the returns to owner-operators. We were asked why the Government does not set freight rates. This really goes to the heart of one of the problems that we have talked about in this place. In fact, an attempt was made to raise this matter during discussion on a Bill which was before this place the other evening. Unfortunately, the matter did not get a guernsey. I refer, of course, to the question of government interference or government subsidisation in various private or quasi private enterprises. I think the whole question of the setting of freight rates by government needs to be looked at.

In examining the arguments in favour of government regulation of freight rates and/or restrictions on entry to the industry, the May report, which has been referred to earlier, concluded that this type of economic regulation favours only some of those operators who are already in the industry and that is often to the detriment of the users and prospective entrants. I think it is important that those opposite who purport to represent the interests of small businessmen should take that into consideration. It also leads to excessive freight rates. It inhibits the efficiency and effectiveness of operations. It reduces the flexibility of the industry to adjust to changing market conditions. It is difficult and costly to administer. I am sure the honourable member for O'Connor would agree with that assertion and would certainly agree that we should try to minimise all administration costs, particularly if they increase the size of bureaucracy. Also, it does not have a significant bearing on the question of improved road safety.

On the other hand, the May inquiry did find that the current and largely free market arrangements are flexible, efficient and offer good service to the customer. Surely, if we are looking at the most efficient way in which the road freight industry can operate, by looking to those people who are in it and those people who will come into it through the improved entrance requirements that these Bills put forward, this must be lauded also as being a most desirable way in which to proceed. Accordingly, the May inquiry strongly rejected the economic regulation of the industry. It considered it more appropriate to introduce measures to improve the competence and professionalism amongst owner-operators; hence the reason for operator licensing. That is, I believe, a most important point that has tended to be overlooked in the discussions so far about this legislation.

The May report concluded that economic regulation is not a panacea for the industry's ills. Again, this Government is not suggesting that it is. Freight rate setting and capacity licensing schemes would be difficult and costly to enforce, while offering little substantial assistance to owner-operators. In fact, the report recommended measures which focus on quality rather than capacity regulation. I am sure we would all agree that that is most desirable. The upgrading of levels of professionalism within the industry will lead to greater stability as well as improved efficiency and services.

Finally, as I said at the outset, the Federal Government's approach on this issue is consistent with the Opposition's calls for reduced regulation and less government intervention. The economic dries on the other side are calling for less government intervention. Here is a classic case in which it has been proposed. We have seen that the consultation process has been lengthy. I was also a member of the Transport Workers Union of Australia, so I feel that I can speak with some knowledge of this industry. For over 30 years the Opposition refused to speak to the industry. It ignored the industry. It shut its eyes to the breakdown of the relationship between the truckie and his family, the bankruptcy and the pressure that was put on the owner-drivers by the employers of those times. The industry wants this legislation now. The industry has been neglected for many years. It has discussed the legislation with the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) and I am certain that the industry will do all it can to implement the legislation when it is passed through this House.

The Interstate Road Transport Bill provides for an interstate vehicle registration scheme and a trust fund, while the Interstate Road Transport Charge Bill provides for charges to be levied to recover the cost of road damage. The Bills provide for the registration of motor vehicles engaged in interstate, State and Territory or Territory and Territory trade and commerce; collection of charges from registered vehicles to recover the costs of road damage; payment of vehicle registration charges into a trust fund; and the distribution of the trust funds to the States and Territories for expenditure on roads used by registered vehicles.

The Interstate Road Transport Bill replaces with Federal registration State provisions for registering vehicles solely engaged in arrangements existing interstate trade and commerce. Vehicles engaged in interstate trade, or both intrastate and interstate trade, will continue to be registered under existing State laws. As a consequence, all classes of vehicle will pay either Federal or State registration charges. The Interstate Road Transport Bill and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Bill together provide the owner of an interstate vehicle with two options for paying the registration charge. These options are that a charge may be paid on the basis of the actual distance travelled by the vehicle as measured by approved distance monitoring equipment installed in the vehicle or, alternatively, provision is made for a registration charge to be paid on the basis of an assessment of the number of kilometres which the vehicle could be expected to travel during the registration period. This approach offers simplicity in administration and would apply to those vehicles not fitted with approved monitoring equipment. Under both options provision is made for a uniform charge per tonne kilometre to be set to recover a portion of road damage cost.

Our roads were left in a disgraceful state because of our predecessor's inaction. For many years our roads, which are the lifeline of our nation, have been left to decay and have not been repaired. The mixture of the traffic on our roads-that is, the number of push bikes, motor bikes, cars, trailers, caravans, trucks, mobile homes, et cetera-makes driving a considerable feat. This feat is made more difficult if our roads are badly constructed and maintenance has been miserable. I believe that this has occurred in the past. Our Government has corrected this problem. I must agree with my colleague the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) about the dangers of caravans. One of Australia's great pleasures is to be able to drive on a holiday with one's caravan or mobile home. However, many of these drivers have no real experience in the handling of a caravan. Some are definite menaces on our roads. They cause untold frustrations not only to our truck drivers but also to other users of the roads. They cause annoyance amongst many other drivers. Maybe the States should look at issuing a special licence for owners of caravans.

I return to the charges. At the outset the uniform charge will be set in reference to the report of the National Road Freight Industry Inquiry. The charges, which are to be collected by State and Territory registration authorities, are to be paid to an interstate road transport fund. Many problems have existed which serve to highlight the need for a tightening up of transport legislation. Safety is the most obvious issue. The transport industry daily shares the road with members of the general public who are going about their own business. We need to look continually to ensure the ongoing safety of the public, as well as to address the area of road safety being an occupational health and safety issue.

At this point I must draw to the attention of the House the great work that has been done by the Mornington Peninsula road safety committee which operates out of Frankston and looks after the road conditions and some of the problems that occur on the Mornington Peninsula. It has a tremendous record and is staffed by volunteers. It has put submissions to the Government, some of which have been taken up by the Minister. It is an important committee for the people on the Mornington Peninsula.

There is another danger to be considered. The pressure of long distance heavy trucking is an extreme danger to the public and also to owner-drivers. For too long the emphasis and focus of road safety laws have been on the drivers. Emphasis has not been focused on the responsibilities of the management and operators of these companies. I have a friend who is an interstate truck driver who met and spoke with the Minister of Transport in my office in Frankston. My friend has told me of the many problems that he has experienced when driving from Melbourne to Western Australia, which was a regular run. He has driven straight over to Perth, been backloaded and then, because of the pressures that were put on him by the company, has had to drive straight back again. This is the sort of life many truckies live. It is a harsh life. It is harsh on the families, too. By the time drivers get home they are exhausted. My friend got to Frankston, he was three miles from his home after driving from Melbourne to Perth, and back from Perth to Melbourne, and went to sleep at the wheel. Pressure was on him to get back to meet his payments and pressure was put on him by the company he was working for at the time. He had problems in his family life because of the fact he was never home; excess pressure was put on him because the banks demanded their money. The companies also put pressure on him to drive further and further in less and less time, and he was paid less and less money. Many times I have seen him totally exhausted and having to go off to work somewhere else. When I was establishing my own business and things were tough, I dug sewers with him. He worked hard so that he, after working many hours driving the truck, could make enough money to live on and to make certain his family was well cared for. He has been pushed to do this because of what he was paid and because of large companies putting pressure on him. Now, with the new law, he will be able to live a fairly normal life.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us how this legislation achieves that. You have the time to do so.

—It achieves it by giving them a fair return for the work they have done. It gives them fair conditions which they have never had in the past-fair conditions that will come out of this legislation. So far in this debate I have not heard Opposition members speak once about the owner-drivers, who have had to put up with these conditions for many years. They are only interested in the monetary and technical points and how they can use some sort of technical means to knock this legislation. I believe that this small point illustrates the philosophical differences between the two parties. We believe in caring and acting for people, but all Opposition members are interested in is caring and acting in relation to profit.

SPEECH.PARA: There was a great need for the Federal Government to give leadership and direction in this area. The National Road Freight Industry Inquiry initiated by the Federal Government in September 1983, in co-operation with State and Territory governments, strongly recommended against controlling either capacity or freight rates. It is clear that this will compromise efficiency with no long term gain to the community or the industry. This Government has taken the lead. The Government has initiated action in this area. That inquiry recommended that drivers be better trained; that competition with railways be put on an equitable basis; that small owner-drivers be given access to existing consumer protection-something they have never had in the past; that additional state imposts on vehicles registered in another State be removed; and that the Federal Government legislate so that the States could collect registration charges from interstate vehicles, many of these recommendations have been taken up by our Government. Our Government has taken the lead in this area and has addressed these problems. The Minister for Transport has done this, and once again the Hawke Labor Government has initiated action that has been long overdue. For 30 years, I reiterate, past governments did nothing. We have now taken steps to rectify problems in the transport industry, and I congratulate the Minister on addressing this area. I commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One becomes accustomed in this place to listening to Government members acting either as mindless propagandists or as apologists for the Government, but I feel that the comments made by the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) exceeded even the usual standard adopted by Government members. We all have great understanding and, I trust, sympathy for hard working owner-operators as well as for drivers in the transport industry. Many of us know operators personally. Some of us have taken the trouble to drive in their cabins to better understand their industry. The comments of the honourable member delve into the realms of the ridiculous by suggesting that this legislation, which merely provides a legislative umbrella for the States, will in any way put more money into a truckie's pocket. That is an absurdity. For the honourable member to claim that previous governments for some 30 years ignored the needs of truck operators flies in the face of logic, not to say honesty. To suggest that is to slur the truck operators' organisations and their ability to communicate with successive Ministers. I suggest that the honourable member for Dunkley contact a number of trucking organisations and offer an apology for the aspersions cast on their competence. If the honourable member for Dunkley were sincere, he would have referred to the 15 per cent increase in fuel costs this year. He would have referred to the pending capital gains tax. He would have referred to the State Labor governments' enormous increases in costs and charges, if he were concerned about the plight of truck operators. They are the measures which have affected the truckies' pockets, not the legislation now before the House. I invite the honourable member for Dunkley to refer to the clauses in this legislation that will put one penny into the pocket of an operator and allow a truck operator a normal stable life, something the honourable member suggested would result from these two bills.

SPEECH.PARA: The real purpose of the Interstate Road Transport Bill and its associated Bill is to implement some of the recommendations of the Thomas May report into the national road freight industry. The report of that committee of three was tabled in the Parliament in October last year, and included some 98 recommendations for the Federal and State governments to adopt-they being mostly the responsibility of State governments. The implications for the Federal Government in this legislation are twofold. First, the registration of vehicles and the licensing of operators engaged in interstate trade and commerce; and secondly, the establishment of the Australian Road Freight Transport Advisory Committee, better known as ARFTAC, within the Transport Industries Advisory Council. At present there are some 15,000 trucks with interstate registration plates which are issued by the State vehicle registration authorities. This legislation before the Parliament will allow the truck and bus operator the choice at his State office to obtain either State or Federal registration. The Federal registration fees will then be paid into a Federal trust fund and all the moneys in the fund will be allocated to the States for road maintenance. Indeed, the truck operator can choose between two methods of registration, namely, an annual fee of $1,400 for the maximum weight truck, or the installation of a monitoring device on a charge per kilometre basis. One inhibiting factor to installing that device will be the cost of approximately $1,000. It is estimated that this trust fund will receive some $14m in its first year, but it is suspected that that amount will decrease in succeeding years as more truck operators opt for the State registration fee. This legislation requires fees from a truck operator; it does not, as the honourable member for Dunkley suggested, return funds in any shape or form to the operator. I hasten to add that for a number of legal reasons which relate to section 92 of the Constitution it is incumbent upon the Government to ensure that none of the Trust Fund receipts are used for administration. We need the entire amount returned for either the maintenance or the construction of roads.

The States have agreed to legislate for a number of factors, principally the introduction of graduated truck driver licences which will require drivers operating large interstate vehicles to have had appropriate experience. Furthermore, the States will introduce a number of the May reforms relating to finance and insurance to provide owner-operators with access to existing consumer protection arrangements. Other matters include the removal of the speed limit differential between trucks and other vehicles outside built-up areas.

I am extremely uneasy about this legislation before the Parliament for two reasons. The first is that I do not believe proper consultation has been undertaken by the Minister for Transport with either the States or the trucking industry. Secondly, I feel uneasy about the number of regulations that are referred to in the Bills. There is a lack of detail and the legislation relies very heavily upon regulations. I ask the Minister-I would be grateful for an answer-whether these two Bills have been subject to the scrutiny of the Business Regulation Review Unit within the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. As the Minister would be aware, that body should have the responsibility of examining all regulations with a view to reducing unnecessary complexity or the burden on business. I note no reference to scrutiny of those regulations by the Business Regulation Review Unit in the Minister's second reading speech. If the Minister has not referred these two Bills to the body I believe that he has erred in his responsibility. It may well be that the Minister was concerned that that review unit would have found there was an unnecessarily heavy dependence on regulations in this legislation.

We all know that in many ways the trucking industry is extremely unstable. It has a number of problems relating to safety, high cost, price cutting and, of course, the need to speed in order to meet deadlines and make a return on the heavy repayments that so many owner-operators have to make on their trucks. Interestingly, in the last month the Victorian police have announced a blitz on the Hume Highway against what they call rogue truck drivers. Anyone who has had experience in driving on the Hume Highway in particular knows that a number of truck operators-I hasten to add a small proportion-quite openly flaunt speed regulations as well as accepted safety practices. At times I have had to take evasive action against trucks careering from lane to lane as the tailstream in an effort to reduce fuel use. I have had to brake suddenly. Also, I have heard a number of horror stories about trucks from constituents. Therefore, it is necessary for all State governments to ensure that policing of road speed limits, as well as general behaviour on the roads, is in the interests of all other road users and that the small number of rogue drivers are not permitted to blacken the reputation of the whole industry.

It is not possible to speak about interstate transport without referring to the state of our roads. The Minister would be aware that his Victorian State counterpart, the Hon. Tom Roper, has alleged that the Commonwealth has diverted some $10m to the Hume Highway from Princes Highway east.

When he got this hard of hearing problem of not knowing to whom he was talking, when he thought he was talking to Peter Reith and not Peter Reid-

—The honourable member for Franklin should not talk about it being a bit rough. What sort of morality does the Leader of the Opposition bring to politics?
—Order! I suggest to the Prime Minister that he get back to the answer.

—This is what happened in terms of the exposition by the now Leader of the Opposition as to what he thought about his predecessor. According to the article in the National Times, the now Leader of the Opposition, when asked for his response to that view, replied:

and this is the important point-
He has some fundamental weaknesses. We have been directionless for 18 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Social Security aware of claims that social security expenditure was cut back in this year's Budget? Is it a fact that a fall in the number of unemployed under the Labor Government has resulted in a significant drop in expenditure on unemployment benefits? Can the Minister tell the House whether projections in the Budget of a further fall in the number of unemployed this financial year are being fulfilled?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. It is true that some people within the welfare sector have mistakenly seen in terms of this year's Budget a cutback in social security expenditure. What they should have seen are the results of more successful economic policy and policies of social responsibility.

ANSWER.PARA: In the Budget there was additional expenditure and new programs of more than $245m. It is true that there was not an increase in total expenditure. The reason was that the Government is having continuing success in tackling the problem of unemployment.

I do not believe that this Government or any government can achieve a reduction in poverty in this country-and there is signficant poverty-if governments do not tackle correctly the underlying problems. The underlying problem and the reason for the significant increase in social security expenditure over the last decade has clearly been the massive growth in unemployment benefits. It is estimated that the number of people on unemployment benefit will fall by 40,000 this year.

At the end of August the number of people on unemployment benefit had fallen to about 540,000-the first time since the Howard recession that numbers have fallen below 550,000. That is about 30,000 or 5.2 per cent lower than the corresponding period last year.

The picture, while it is generally improving, is not improving in Queensland where we see an increase of 2.8 per cent or about 2,500. Queensland is rapidly overtaking Victoria, despite its much smaller population. It is the State with the highest concentration of unemployment.

Clearly these figures have produced some savings in terms of social security expenditure. Together with the assets test, that has made it possible for the Government to direct some additional assistance to people in greatest need. In the Budget there was assistance to women in poverty. There was some assistance to their children-and we have, as I have said before, a massive problem of poverty amongst something like three-quarters of a million children within this country-and some further assistance to the long term unemployed.

I repeat that we are not into fairyland or looney economics, as it has been referred to, but we are on about responsible economic and social policy. Those two arms of policy are working together to achieve some real improvement in the situation of low income people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I advise the House that we have in the upstairs gallery this afternoon a distinguished delegation from the Diet of Japan. On behalf of the House I extend to members of the delegation a very warm welcome.

—I refer the Prime Minister to the second paragraph of his Press release of 11 September last. In his discussions with Mr Reid referred to in that Press statement, was Dr Armstrong's future discussed? If so, why did he omit any reference to that part of those discussions in his Press release of 11 September? Further, why did he repeat that omission in his answer yesterday when he said only that he was aware of the terms of the settlement? Will he tell the House what he is trying to hide?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am trying to hide nothing. I remind the House of the terms of the Press release of 11 September, which was a totally accurate statement of what had transpired. In the answer I gave to the House yesterday I made it clear that I had had discussions with the Chairman of the Authority and obviously in that I was talking about the criticisms that had been directed to the Authority. Obviously included in those discussions were discussions about Dr Armstrong.
—Ah!

—The Leader of the Opposition should not ah that. For him to say `ah' is a magnificent observation when he knows the facts. As the honourable member for Bradfield has tried to come around this issue in this way, let me make a further observation in regard to the comments that he is reported to have made on this matter following my answer to the Parliament yesterday. He is apparently seeking to draw a distinction between that part of Dr Armstrong's settlement, which he concedes that the Australian Bicentennial Authority already had financial authority to make, and supplementary payments which he contends I could formally have directed not to be made.

ANSWER.PARA: The legal basis for this, he seems to be suggesting, is section 6 of the Australian Bicentennial Authority Act which refers to directions with respect to policies being given to the Board by the Minister. Of course, he is wrong on that. In fact, the legal situation is that the relevant references in this matter are article 41 of the Articles of Association and sections 11 and 12 of the Act. I quote from Article 41 because it is relevant to this question as it has been asked here again today. Article 41 states, quite specifically:

The Chairman shall, for the purpose of his performance functions, have such powers as may be exercised by him under or by virtue of these articles, including the approval of the appointment of the Chief Executive Officer and of other senior appointments to the staff of the Authority and of the terms and conditions of employment, including the termination of employment of the staff of the Authority.
Section 11 (2) of the Act states:
Moneys of the Authority shall not be expended by the Authority otherwise than in accordance with estimates of expenditure approved by the Minister.
Section 12 of the Act states, in part:
Moneys of the Authority shall be applied only-
(a) in payment of any remuneration and allowances payable to any person under the Memorandum of Association or the Articles of Association of the Authority.

As regards these sections of the Act, I am advised that the settlement payment to Dr Armstrong was paid under the heading `Salaries and Payments in the nature of Salary' for which $2.85m had been approved by the Minister assisting me for the Bicentenary, the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, in estimates for the 1985-86 Supply period on 26 June this year. If as a consequence of Mr Reid's determination of a settlement payment to Dr Armstrong the Authority comes to the view that some variation to its approval estimates will be required before the end of the Supply period, the Authority will need to seek my approval in accordance with section 11 of the Act. It will be open to me to approve or disapprove any such request for variation in the approved estimates.

All this was conveyed to Mr Reid in my reply to him on 30 August, to which I referred yesterday and a copy of which I have shown to the Leader of the Opposition. As the Leader of the Opposition knows, I have had no letter of demurral at all from the Chairman of the Authority. In other words, as I made clear in my Press statement, I have provided a totally accurate statement of the position. I repeat that when this matter first arose I attempted not to stifle the opportunity for the Opposition to ask questions, I have since then attempted to handle the matter in a way which will guarantee as far as possible that this important issue of the Bicentenary will not be allowed to degenerate into a question of political point scoring-by me from the Opposition or by the Opposition from us.

I repeat that on all points I am prepared to take the Leader of the Opposition totally into my confidence on this matter. I have done so already. I do not seek to bind him or to say that that prevents the Opposition from asking questions. Despite the fact that these questions have been asked, I continue to say to the Leader of the Opposition that I will provide him with all the information that he seeks on this matter, I will put him totally in my confidence in relation to all that has happened and all that continues to transpire. I hope that he will take up the offer that I made to him. Despite the legislation with which we are saddled which gives me as Prime Minister no authority to determine who shall be the Authority's next chief executive, I hope that he will be prepared to consult with me on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment aware that at the recently concluded homes exhibition in Hamburg in Germany a well-publicised stall was manned by a group purporting to save the kangaroo in Australia? Is the Minister aware that these ill-informed groups are grotesquely distorting the realities of our kangaroo management strategy but have the ability to do enormous damage? Can the Minister say whether his Department is in a position to supply material that could be used to counter this very bad publicity and make people in foreign countries aware of the necessary humane management policy that is being undertaken in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Kalgoorlie for his question. I am aware of some outlandish and quite outrageous statements that have emanated from some elements of the environment movement. I stress the word `some', because the overwhelmingly majority of conservation bodies in Australia take a responsible and sensible attitude. I am not going to name names, but one particular group--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Go on.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, not this time; later on. One particular body receives an annual income of around $400,000 a year from direct mail contributions that it solicits throughout Australia. It is claimed that Australians skin kangaroos alive to save themselves the price of a bullet. Opposition members-Ha, ha!

—I refer the Minister for Communications to the long-standing registered post system which Australia Post is planning to change by stealth next Monday. Is he aware that a standard article which can currently be sent with up to $500 cover by registered post for $3.98 will next week cost $11.33-an increase of nearly 200 per cent? Is he likewise aware that under this new system items of up to $2,000 in value will be sent through the post `with no special security arrangements'? Finally, can the Minister confirm that he has received telegrams from small business people all around Australia protesting at the clandestine way in which these costly and time-consuming changes are being introduced? Will he now in fairness to those people request Australia Post to delay the introduction of these changes until it has consulted representatives of small business?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested when the honourable member stated that Australia Post had made the decision by itself. There seemed to be some implication in that that it had to consult with somebody in relation to it and I think he ought to understand at this stage that that sort of decision is not a Government decision. It is not a standard postage matter and it is within the prerogative of Australia Post management to make that decision. Let us make that clear for a start.

ANSWER.PARA: The last part of the question asked whether I had recieved telegrams and communications of complaint. Yes, I have. Australia Post conducted research at the end of 1984 which showed that the current system of registered mail was unsatisfactory for various reasons-for example, lack of flexibility in the system and a low ceiling of compensation. Secondly-and this will interest the economic dries-it was operating at a loss. Thirdly, the price paid did not reflect the possible value of lost articles. The price paid for registered mail did not sufficiently reflect the value of articles that may be lost. A new service was then examined by Australia Post. It was based more on insurance principles than on the old system of registered post. As I indicated earlier, it was not a Government decision. Hoever, I support the view taken by Australia Post that the existing system clearly needed to be examined, and examined closely.

As a result of the criticism of the proposed new system, Australia Post has decided to delay its introduction for about a month in order that it can consider the criticisms of the bodies referred to by the honourable member for Goldstein. It is also worth pointing out that these services are not, of course, monopoly services. They are not within the monopoly of Australia Post within the Act. Therefore, if, after the matter has been given further consideration, the judgment of Australia Post is that this is the way to go and it turns out that it does not change its view, although it may do so, and if Australia Post has not judged the market in a correct fashion, customers can take their business elsewhere because it is not a matter within the monopoly. This will obviously commend itself to those opposite. While on the question of costs, I think it worth pointing out to the honourable member for Goldstein, who is now the shadow Minister for Communications, and worth while advising him of the position-

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on! Get on with it.

—I was asked a question and I propose to answer it. I think it worth spelling out the situation in relation to postage charges in this country, particularly for the honourable member who asked the question and those who are interested. The honourable member for Mitchell obviously is not, and that does not surprise me. It is worth spelling out the position of Australia Post in a comparison of the costs of posting a standard mail item in this country with those other countries. In figures converted to Australian currency, probably the highest is West Germany at 42.1c. The second is Japan at 37.9c. Then come Canada at 37.1c, Italy at 37.1c, France at 36.3c and the United Kingdom at 34.5c. One has to go to the eighth or ninth position on the list before one comes to Australia at 33c. As I indicated, the proposal is under examination because of the criticism that has been made, but I repeat the point that I made when I started: It was a decision to be taken by Australia Post because it is within its management prerogative.

—Is the Minister for Health aware of concern about the transmission of the acquired immune deficiency syndrome virus in schools? Can the Minister state whether any significant risk of aids transmission occurs in cases where a child carrying AIDS antibodies is attending school?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we all fully understand the concern and anxiety expressed by parents in relation to these issues. At the outset it is very important for all of us to recognise that somebody who is AIDS antibody positive or sero-positive to AIDS does not necessarily have the disease and will not necessarily develop the disease. It simply means that someone has had contact with the virus and the body has developed antibodies against it. I am aware that the New South Wales, Victorian and Australian Capital Territory schools authorities have recently published very comprehensive guidelines for handling these difficult cases in school situations. I think that those guidelines are both responsible and compassionate. These guidelines have been developed by the various governments in collaboration with the National Aids Task Force. Central to all those guidelines is the fact that, on the best medical advice we have, AIDS is not passed on through casual contact or by airborne means. If it were passed on by those means we would have a very different pattern of the disease in this society. Indeed, one of the few features of small comfort in relation to this disease is that it seems to be fairly difficult to pass on.

ANSWER.PARA: I know that the anxieties of those parents to whom the honourable member referred will be relieved only by the provision of prompt, accurate and comprehensive information. The Commonwealth will continue to underwrite programs in the preventive and education fields in conjunction with the States. I would like to note here that a national AIDS conference underwritten by the Commonwealth will be held in Melbourne from 15 to 16 November. I am also grateful to note that every State will be represented at that conference at a high level. This will provide an invaluable opportunity for health workers, administrators, doctors, researchers and community groups together to review the progress that has been made to date and advise us on further policy developments.

If I may finally make one brief advertisement, tomorrow Dr James Curran, who is perhaps the leading epidemiologist in the world on AIDS, will be in Canberra. He will be speaking at the National Press Club but, as I realise that many honourable members on both sides of the House would like to meet him informally, arrangements for that have been made and all members have been circulated.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Has the Government recently made a decision on the level of subsidy payable in respect of rental for Defence Force housing? If so, what changes, if any, have been made in the level of rental subsidy for Defence Force housing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Herbert is most assiduous in the protection of the substantial number of his constituents who are members of the Australian Armed Services, and so is a raft of people behind me. The final report of the task force addressing housing assistance for members of the Australian Public Service and members of the Defence Force has recently been presented to the Government. However, with the exception of aspects of the defence service homes scheme, which were dealt with in the May statement, the Government has yet to commence consideration of the task force's final proposals. In carrying out this program effectiveness review, the task force called for proposals and submissions, published an extensive interim report as a basis for discussion and revision of its proposals and consulted widely with departments and employee groups, including the Armed Forces Federation of Australia. It will be their views and also the views of the task force that will be taken into account when we make our final decisions on the proposals that are put to us.

ANSWER.PARA: At this stage I can say only that the objectives of housing assistance as set out in the interim report of the task force have been endorsed by the Government. For the information of honourable members, they include: That personnel be compensated for housing-related disabilities arising from frequent relocation where this is a required condition of service; that adequate accommodation be provided where personnel are required to reside in locations where suitable alternative accommodation is not available; that financial disabilities due to inter-regional differences in housing costs be minimised for those required to relocate frequently; and that detriment to morale caused by housing matters be minimised. In response not only to this question from the honourable gentleman but also to the many that have been put to me on this matter, this Government stands second to none in its concern for service conditions.

In the area of wages, we overthrew a situation in which the Services were experiencing a wage freeze. They have been subject, since then, to all the community moves that have occurred with the cost of living adjustments of wages. In addition, an independently arbitrated wage increase of 5.9 per cent has been awarded to them. In the area of housing, which is an enormously sensitive area-it was rendered sensitive largely by the fact that it was shamefully neglected for a three-year period when all the housing developments were put on hold-we now confront a very substantial problem, which is one of those problems to which the task force is addressing itself. That was done under the previous Government.

As an earnest of our good faith in this area we have incorporated in the current defence budget an amount of $61m for Defence Force housing, both in terms of the construction of new houses-some 680 new houses-and in terms of refurbishment of old houses. Nobody is going to kid himself that that will be sufficient for the task. We have a considerable backlog to overcome. That will be achieved only over a period. The point is that in critical areas of service conditions, which were not being addressed, which were neglected and which have now posed a very serious problem for us, we are addressing those matters seriously and with reasonable expedition.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective worldpeace initiative needs to be established which will work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all, fulfilling employment, a sustainable society conserving natural resources and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover. By achieving these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world to follow.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable house will:
1. Create an Australian Ministry for Peace specifically devoted to peace-building and the non-violent resolution of conflict;
2. Convene a national summit for survival to discuss the issues of world disarmament, security and national and international co-operation;
3. Fully support the United Nations World Disarmament Campaign by allocating the equivalent of at least 10% of the defence budget to fund peace activities;
4. Actively assist the International Year of Peace in 1986 by initiating programs for peace education, self help development and environmental repair;
5. Develop National Employment Programs to give priority to the planting and growing of forests, food-producing trees and other crops;

6. Implement National Recycling Programs to reuse water and to compost all presently wasted sewage-sludge and organic garbage into hygienic humus, a natural fertiliser, for use in rehabilitating impoverished soils;
7. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
