2. THAT we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, unless such proposed change is first voted on by the people of Australia and passed by a majority of voters in a majority of States.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Small Businesses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
they adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, including farms, destroying incentives and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

any capital gains that might result when owners of small enterprises finally sell these assets are not ``windfall gains'', but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business or farm by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business or farm to create growth and jobs;
the owners of small businesses and farms often depend on a capital gain-which is simply deferred salaries-when they eventually sell their assets to sustain them in retirement;

Your Petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes. And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ewen Cameron and Mr McArthur.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Assistance Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of concerned people of Australia respectfully show their desire that your Honourable House (The Government) act immediately to raise the Tertiary Education Assistance allowance to the level of the Unemployment Benefit.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray:

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Local Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
1. That the functions of local government involve assessing local demand for services and either providing, or facilitating the provision of, those services;
2. That a transfer of responsibility for the provision of services from one level of government to another must be accompanied by a corresponding transfer of funds;
3. That local government in Victoria is becoming increasingly involved in the planning and provision of human services in particular;

4. That the level of services currently provided by or through local government cannot be maintained, and certainly cannot be increased, if the funds made available to local government through the personal income tax-sharing arrangement are not maintained at the present level;
5. That we are totally opposed to any reduction in the percentage of personal income tax allocated to local government.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the funding of local government without the consent of representatives of local government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of State Arts Councils
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the current policies of the Community Arts Board of the Australia Council are disadvantaging rural residents with regard to access to the Arts.

Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Federal Government will allocate sufficient funds to the Australia Council specifically to ensure ongoing funding to State Arts Councils to enable those organisations to maintain access to performing and other arts activities in country areas.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Private Health Insurance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sayeth:
That we the undersigned are totally opposed to any taxation change which involves a tax on Health Fund contributions, health charges or benefits;

That we are already required to pay a 1 per cent levy to partly finance the Medicare scheme and that we would regard any further taxation of our health insurance arrangements as unfair and unreasonable;
That therefore we urge the Government to ensure that there is no taxation on illness and no special taxation on those who seek to insure themselves against the cost of private health care.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. We are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses-represents the nation's historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. We know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. We recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. We are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ayers Rock and Uluru National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the Government's stated intention to hand over to the Mulitjula Community Ownership of Ayers Rock and Uluru National Park, which have until now belonged to all the people of Australia.
We believe that Ayers Rock and the park are part of the natural heritage of Australia and should be retained by the crown on behalf of all living and future generations of Australians.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the house oppose any action that would give ownership of these national treasures to any single group in the community.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Price
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
1. We are completely disatisfied with the pricing policy of petrol in this country.
2. We are aware that it has an adverse effect on the living standards of the average wage earner of this country.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that the price of petrol be reduced by 3c a litre in line with a commitment given by the now Prime Minister of Australia during the 1983 election campaign.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Price
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humble Petition of the South Australian Country Women's Association Incorporated and the Undersigned shall showeth:
The necessity to restore the concessional price of fuel in rural areas-without which there will be increased freight and production costs.
Your Petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will restore concessional price of fuel in rural areas for the benefit of all Australians.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of ABC listeners and viewers showeth that the autonomy and non-commercial independant broadcasting services of the ABC is in jeopardy because the ABC is currently having to bear additional costs involved in the AUSSAT satellite operation.
Your petitioners therefor humbly pray that:

1. The Government restores $20 million to the ABC's budget for 1985-86 to ensure that the services the ABC provides the Australian public are maintained and improved, particularly in terms of educational and rural programs, and that ABC staff are not needlessly retrenched.

2. The Government will not introduce corporate sponsorship or any form of advertising into the ABC since this would destroy the independance and autonomy of the ABC. The non-commercial independant broadcasting service provided by the ABC is fundamental to Australian democracy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows:

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Military Bases in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of citizens of Australia respectfully show:

As a part of the world wide campaign by women in the final year of the United Nations' Decade for Women for `Equality, Development and Peace' (1976-1985) and in view of the grave possibility of nuclear catastrophe, the Union of Australian Women calls for the Australian Government to:
intensify its efforts for nuclear disarmament.
remove U.S. bases from Australian soil.
keep the Pacific and Indian Oceans nuclear free.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Wild Horses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The Petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to have the brumby declared a protected species.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House follow the example of President Nixon in the U.S.A. by declaring our wild horses protected from industry and discriminate slaughter.
And your petitioners, and in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Changes to Veterans' Entitlements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Veterans' Entitlement Bill dated May 1985 is taking a fair ``earned service'' from the men and women of Australia, who kept this country free so that Governments of today could have the freedom to be able to govern fairly.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled ensure that the previous legislation in respect of war veterans' and their dependants entitlements be restored.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That progressive reform of the Australian Taxation System is long overdue and that the burden has to be lifted from the poor and low to middle income earners.
Also, sufficient tax revenue needs to be gained to support and extend public services and to reform the social security system.
Specifically we support:
1. The introduction of appropriate capital gains and wealth taxes.
2. The elimination of all forms of tax avoidance and evasion.
3. Reduced PAYE rates for low to middle income earners, and the elimination of ``Poverty Traps''.
Your petitioners humbly pray for:
1. Elimination of income tax concessions that assist the wealthy.
2. Increased company tax.
3. Improved pensions and other social security benefits, particularly increased allowances for dependent children.
4. Expansion of the public sector to create permanent jobs.
5. No action to be taken to introduce a new universal consumption tax as it would harm those who already pay an unfair burden of taxation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Northern Land Council: Access to Gove
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament: The petition of residents of Nhulunbuy, Arnhem Land, Northern Territory, draw to the attention of the House our objection at being discriminated against by an abuse of the Commonwealth N.T. Aboriginal Land Rights Act and Complementary N.T. Legislation wherein the Northern Land Council on behalf of traditional owners has the right to restrict access in and out of Aboriginal Land (Nhulunbuy).

Residents of Nhulunbuy are currently being discriminated against by the Northern Land Council by an abuse of powers vested in them under the above Legislation by restricting the issue of permits and placing unreasonable conditions on such permits which allow access in and out of Nhulunbuy. Residents of Nhulunbuy have always abided by the terms and conditions of the permit system and to the best knowledge available no resident of Nhulunbuy has been fined for violating these conditions.

Your petitioners so pray that the House obtain an assurance from the Northern Land Council that residents be granted unrestricted access by permit, in and out of Gove upon the offical opening and until the official closing of the Track by the Police each dry season, failing this we ask that the legislation be amended in order that we are not discriminated against in the future.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Wild Horses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned electors in the State of South Australia sheweth that we strongly object to the cruel slaughter of brumbies in Northern Queensland and demand its cessation.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will do all in its power to stop the slaughter of brumbies, or, if this is not possible, to have it carried out in a humane manner.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the house of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain electors of the Division of Cowper respectfully showeth:
That the introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties would not be economically benficial for Australia, as any introduction of such taxes would.
First, adversely affect small and medium sized businesses in Australia, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
Secondly, disadvantage the Australian economy by stifling employment in particular, which is heavily reliant on growth in small and medium sized businesses;

Thirdly, any capital gains that might result when owners of small and medium sized businesses finally sell the business are not ``windfall gains'' but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business to create growth and jobs; and
Finally, the owners of small and medium sized businesses often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries-when they eventually sell their business to sustain them in retirement.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives oppose any attempt to introduce any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties, which would be to the detriment of the economic well-being of the nation, and repeal any existing captial gains taxes, wealth taxes, or death duties, which are to the economic disadvantage of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Home Patients
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia showeth that:

Without any warning and at the worst possible moment, the Federal Government has abandoned the pensioner patients in South Australia's Nursing Homes. These people are suffering undeserving hardship and trauma as a result of the Federal Government's decision to freeze the nursing home benefit levels in South Australia.

The pensioner patients and those on fixed incomes now cannot expect any relief from recent significant fee increases approved by the Department of Community Services and which have coincided with the decision to freeze benefits.

80-85% of nursing home patients are pensioners and the majority are now required to pay in excess of their pension for their nursing care for the very first time. Some are paying over $5 per day on top of their pension. Many are looking for cheaper nursing care that doesn't exist
We request that the Federal Government:

1. alleviate the distress of South Australia's nursing home patients and their families by effective restoration of the principle that pensioner patients should not have to pay more than their pension for nursing home care
2. restore the review of the benefit rates in November 1985
3. resolve its concerns over health care costs with the South Australian Government rather than inflicting unnecessary suffering on nursing home patients.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N. A. Brown) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The escalation of the Mudginberri dispute resulting from the failure of the Government and the ACTU to accept decisions of the Arbitration Commission and the Federal Court.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their place.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statements made yesterday by Mr Simon Crean, the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, have resulted in the Mudginberri dispute being escalated. That dispute is no longer simply an industrial dispute. It has now become a test case of whether the courts and their judgments are to be accepted, enforced and complied with; it has become a test case of whether one privileged group in the community can put itself above the law; and it has become a test case of whether this Govenment will allow one privileged group to put itself above the law. On the evidence that we have had so far, we cannot come to any conclusion other than the ACTU and the Government have failed in their responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: The Mudginberri dispute until yesterday was bad enough. In the first place, individual men had entered into a free bargain with their employer. They got want they wanted. That agreement meant that the men received higher wages. It meant that productivity was increased. It meant that the employer remained viable. It meant that he could provide employment. That agreement was approved by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and it was put into practice after having gone before the Commission.

Against that free agreement, which contained all of those features which no one could deny were desirable, the trade union movement set its face. It set its face against this agreement because it could not bear to see free people doing their own thing and making their own bargains without the domination of the work place by a trade union and without a trade union dictating the wages and terms of employment that would apply. So there was an issue, clear and stark. If anything became obvious during the conduct of that dispute it was that the union cared nothing for the rights of the individual. It cared nothing for the productivity of the abattoir concerned and it cared nothing for the rights of men who wanted to do no more than work.

What was the role of the Government in this dispute? This Government aligned itself with a union which imposed pickets, which stopped men from going to work and which denied to ordinary Australians their rights to do their own thing on the terms and conditions on which they wanted to do them. That was a discreditable and entirely unjustified position for the Government to maintain. But it has maintained it throughout this dispute. It was doubly worse for the Government to maintain that attitude because the union's case was completely baseless and had no merit whatsoever. If there is any doubt about that, let us remember once again those memorable words of one of the two Minister so intimately involved in this matter, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). We know what his contribution was. He said: `Blind Freddy's dog knows that the union is in the wrong on this matter.'

There has been a shameful performance by the ACTU and a shameful performance by this Government which supported it. That was bad enough. That was the situation until yesterday so far as this dispute was concerned. But the matter has now been escalated and it has been escalated by the ACTU, particularly by its President. It has been escalated by the union, the ACTU, by its President and, we would say, also by the Government because of its continued inactivity in this matter. The union and the ACTU have been aided, step by step in this escalation, by the Government's support and by the failure of the Government to live up to its responsibilities. The dispute has escalated because this matter has been to the Federal Court of Australia and not just to the Arbitration Commission, which we are continually being told is the sole repository in which industrial disputes should be resolved.

Yesterday the court rejected appeals by the union against the $44,000 fine and the sequestration order of the union's assets because of its breach of the law. So the matter has been not only to the Arbitration Commission but also to the Federal Court. It should be remembered that the Federal Court was applying the law of this land. Section 45D of the Trade Practices Act is part of the law. The Government and the ACTU may not like it, but the fact is that it is the law and it should be enforced. The Government should stand behind the enforcement of that law.

What was the response of the ACTU? In response to the matter having been before the court and court orders having been made, the ACTU has made a declaration of war on the law. It says it will go on the attack. It will go on the attack against the court, against the enforcement of court decisions and against the claim for damages being made in the court. What we say is short and to the point: No government can tolerate that situation. No government should tolerate that situation. No government should stand by and see court orders treated with contempt. The responsibility of this Government is to stand firmly behind the court, firmly behind the orders made by the court and firmly behind the enforcement of the law. It has completely abrogated its responsibility in this regard.

We have given the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) ample opportunity to say that the Government will use its authority, its standing and its influence with the trade unions to ensure that the orders of the court are complied with. He has refused to do so. The choice was clearly before him but he refused to take it up. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) has also failed in his responsibility and has done nothing but pour scorn over the whole dispute from beginning to end. For him it is a piddling dispute. That is the way he describes it-a piddling dispute. For him, as he said the other day: `There are only 25 workers involved and the matter is not worth bothering about'. This Minister, when faced with a clear case of a union which is in conflict with the workers, the Arbitration Commission, the Federal Court and the enforcement of the law, does nothing. He has said nothing to persuade the union to comply with the law. He does nothing even to encourage support of the Arbitration Commission which approved this agreement in the first place. He, like the Government does nothing despite all of its grand words about having some special relationship with the trade unions and some special influence in the way in which they move and the decisions they make. He does nothing, despite that special relationship, to bring this rogue union into line.

There are further issues that are of concern to us. The first is the rights of the individual. How does the ACTU President see the rights of the individual? We now know, because he made his contribution yesterday. He said that the rights of the individual are a theory. They are not something to be enforced or put into practice, but they are a mere theory. He said it is nothing more than a theory that individuals have rights. He said: `The reality is that we have to deal with collective representative groups'. We believe that the rights of the individual are more than some mere theory. They are rights which people have exercised year in, year out, year after year, and they should be maintained. We on this side of the House support the right of individuals to act as free individuals, to make their own agreements and to do so with confidence that they will be able to have them carried out and that the Government, with all the authority that it has, will support them.

Let us get back to the basic principles in this matter and recognise that what is at issue at the very outset is the right of free individuals living in a free society to do their own thing. What is at issue is the responsibility of the Government to respect and support those rights. But the Government pours scorn on those rights. It has completely abandoned its responsibility to support them and to enforce them. That is a matter of great concern to members on this side of the House.

The second matter of concern is that we can now see, as a result of the dispute that is unfolding before our eyes, what a complete sham the prices and incomes accord is. Only last week the Government published a glossy publication, lauding and praising to the skies the great achievements of the prices and incomes accord. It was produced apparently at a cost of three quarters of a million dollars. It extols the virtues of the prices and incomes accord. I refer to the introductory remarks of the Minister in this memorable document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there a glossy photo?

—Yes, complete with a ministerial photograph. We are told in the Minister's introductory remarks that this accord heralds a bold and innovative approach. The bold and innovative approach, so far as we can see in relation to this dispute, is that one should thumb one's nose at Federal Court orders. One should not worry about whether people have entered into agreements with their employers. One should not even worry if the agreement has been sanctioned by the Arbitration Commission. Honourable members should read this document. They should look at the superman comics scattered throughout it and the colourful illustrations. It is a quite extraordinary document. When we read the print we find the following statement:

SPEECH.PARA: The Accord agreement firmly rejects confrontational industrial relations.

Are we asked to believe that there has been no confrontation in the Mudginberri dispute? The point about this dispute is that there has been confrontation-and new confrontation as from yesterday-and it has come from the union, from the ACTU and, more importantly for our purposes, it is actively supported by the Government. We go on, if we can muster enough courage, to read:
In place of confrontation, it--
the accord-
calls for a more co-operative approach to solving industrial problems.

We know now from the present Mudginberri dispute what all this rubbish in the published document means. We know now that when the union wants to use confrontation, which is condemned in the document, the union will use it. We know that the Government will support the union in confrontation if the union can gain another inch of power. What about co-operation, praised to the skies in this document? We know now what that means. We know that there is to be no co-operation in solving industrial disputes if the rights of the union are at stake and if the dominant power of this privileged and exclusive group is to be threatened to the slightest degree. If that is the situation there will be no co-operation. The attitude of the Government is that the union-its paymaster-must win at all costs, no matter what the merits of the case.

We have the Government day after day crowing in this place about its great industrial disputation record. What a hollow claim it is. Of course, when we look at and think of Mudginberri and we look at the statistics, we will not have industrial disputes if everyone knows that the union will be supported by the Government in bludgeoning into submission anyone who dares to disagree with it. Of course, there will be fewer industrial disputes if the Government gives way every time and does not stand up to protect individual rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is just a theory.

—Individual rights are just a theory, according to the ACTU and the Government. We say that if these fine words about rejecting confrontation and calling for co-operation are to be given any substance at all and if we are to believe that there is an ounce of truth in what the Government says, the Government should step in and stop the confrontation. It claims that it can do that. Let us see the Government do that in this case. The Government should use its authority and should bring more common sense and a better co-operative approach to this matter. In this case there has been co-operation-co-operation between the employees and their employer. That is the co-operation which this society wants to see but which the Government simply cannot stomach. It is time the Government lent its support to that co-operation. As I have said before, this matter has been to the Arbitration Commission. It has been through the Federal Court. It is time the Government woke up to itself and brought this union and the ACTU to their senses. If it does not, it will stand condemned in the eyes of all Australians as having completely abrogated its responsibility. As far as we on this side of the House are concerned, that case has already been made out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a speech from the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown), which is very much a rerun of what was said by his Leader, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), last week and by other people who have participated in debate on this issue. Let me say that much of that rerun includes the rerun of accusations which have been fully repudiated in this House but which have not prevented the honourable member from repeating those absolutely false accusations as though there had not been a thorough refutation. Let met address some of those false accusations that we have heard from the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, he said that the Government has aligned itself with the union that imposed pickets. As I have said on various occasions in this House, the Government has not supported in any way the imposition of pickets by the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union against a decision of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. We have said that that was a wrong thing to have done and that the decision of the Commission should be respected. That does not prevent a union or any other party in any dispute, once an award has been made, from seeking to have a variation made to that award at some subsequent time. But when any party seeks to take direct action against a decision of the Commission, the Government certainly cannot uphold that. That has been our consistent position in this House. It is thoroughly mischievous, at least for the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, to repeat the lie that this Government has aligned itself with the union in the imposition of pickets.

Let me say secondly that another absolutely false accusation was repeated about 20 times in the course of the repetitious speech by the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, and that was that this Government had not defended the law. That is absolutely and totally untrue. He did not produce one skerrick of evidence nor can he produce any evidence to demonstrate that this Government is not upholding the law. I say absolutely that this Government has not supported section 45D of the Trade Practices Act. Nevertheless, we agree that as it is part of the law, the law must be upheld. We have most certainly done nothing which could be construed in any way as seeking to undermine the law.

The Federal Court of Australia, because of action taken very much against our wishes in relation to section 45D, has made a decision in respect of that matter which imposes fines on the union. We are not in any way preventing the collection of those fines. Nothing this Government has done could in any way be said to be stopping the collection of those fines. The union has said that it will not willingly pay. But the reality is, as has been fully explained in this House and as the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party knows full well, that when this accusation was made by the Liberal Party Leader last week I explained then and I explain now that there is a sequestration order which covers some $2m of assets of the union. Regardless of whether the union likes it, the reality is that there is a sufficiency of funds-indeed, far in excess of the amount that is involved in these fines-which are subject to the sequestration order. Therefore, there is no doubt that the fine will be paid from the union's fund.

In that situation the charge that this Government is not upholding the law is an absolutely false, malicious and scurrilous accusation and the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party knows that full well. His constant repetition of that lie, I think, demeans his position in this House very much. He also said that the Government was not upholding decisions of the Commission. That also is absolutely untrue. This Government stands behind the Arbitration Commission. Unlike the Opposition, which would seek to destroy the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, we support the system of conciliation and arbitration. Indeed, we are justified in doing that by a tripartite review of the system by the Hancock Committee of Review into the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems, which unanimously agreed that the system of conciliation and arbitration should be maintained. Therefore, we will do nothing to undermine that system.

We will be making various amendments to the law to improve that system. But nothing we have done in this dispute can be said to be reducing in any way the status of the Commission, undermining the Commission or not upholding decisions of the Commission. As I have said, we have not supported or condoned in any way the action of the union in taking direct action against the Commission's decision. Nevertheless, it is the fact, as I have said, that a party can take an application to the Commission for variation of an award. That is what the union has now done.

I believe that all this would have been done some time ago if, indeed, there had not been the 45D action, which greatly exacerbated the level of this dispute. That forced the dispute into a situation where the temperature was increased enormously. It resulted in a distraction from the issues at stake. It meant that the obvious course for resolution was postponed for a considerable length of time. Now we have reached a situation where the matter is back before the Commission. The Commission has listed it for hearing on 3 and 4 October. At that time it will hear what the union has to say about why there should be some variation of the award. The union will be able to put its case. The Commission will make its decision on that. Whatever decision comes out of that should certainly be upheld. That is the simple situation in regard to the Commission. The Government in no way can be said to be undermining the position of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It stands firmly for the system and for the decisions of the Commission being upheld by the parties in not taking industrial action against them. But where parties have a dispute about the conditions in an award, they of course have the right to go back to the Commission and argue that there should be some change.

It is also said that the Government is guilty somehow because the ACTU made a decision yesterday that it would have some form of industrial campaign in relation to Mudginberri in retaliation for the fines which have been imposed. The Government is in no way involved with that decision of the ACTU. We cannot condone an industrial campaign of that kind if it involves the taking of direct action or placing bans, as I presume it does, although no detail is available at this stage. Nor is there any industrial campaign; it is simply, as I understand it, something that it said will be undertaken in the next couple of weeks. We cannot condone that course at all. I shall certainly be talking to the ACTU about it and seeking to persuade the ACTU and the unions that might be involved in any such campaign not to take part in such a course. I believe that would be counter-productive to an effective resolution of the Mudginberri dispute, which should be found within the confines of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and not by taking retaliatory action of the kind which has been foreshadowed. That is our position on that and the Government cannot be said in any way to be guilty of any action which makes us responsible for any industriual campaign that may take place in this matter.

That leads me to the hypocrisy of the Opposition's position on industrial relations, particularly on section 45D. Opposition members want to say, as the Leader of the Opposition said in this debate last time, that section 45D is an efficient means of resolving industrial disputes. That was his term-an efficient means. It is said that the Mudginberri dispute showed that. Despite the flurry of section 45D action, the picket was there for 120 days before it was lifted. It was lifted, not because of the 45D action which had been going on for months, but only because the matter had got back in the hands of the Commission. It is our clear belief that section 45D has done nothing in the Mudginberri dispute to assist in its resolution. Indeed, it made the whole thing infinitely more difficult to resolve. We have maintained all along that section 45D was counter-productive to good industrial relations. Not only does it make individual disputes more difficult to settle, but it also means that it is likely that there will be retaliatory action and a spreading of the action. This has been the experience over the years that 45D has been on the statute book.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you approve of that?

—Of course I do not agree with it. I am saying that that is the reality of what has happened. During the time that you were in government, time and time again 45D action led to a spreading of the dispute. That is the kind of experience there has been in the past. Read my second reading speech last year as to why section 45D should be abolished and all will be revealed to you. I recommend it to you.
—I have put in more 45D cases than you have. They are often settled.
—Order! I suggest to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that he stop interjecting, or the Chair will need to deal with him.
—He is making direct comments to me.
—I warn the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

—The experience is that section 45D not only makes it more difficult to solve individual disputes, but on many occasions in the past it led and on this occasion perhaps it will lead-although I will do my best to prevent it-to a spreading of the dispute to other areas and to other kinds of action taking place in retaliation. That makes the whole situation infinitely more difficult to resolve. When that course develops the original dispute gets lost in the mayhem that develops in the spreading of the dispute. Opposition members cannot have it both ways: They cannot argue in this place that 45D is an efficient means of resolving industrial disputes and then bitch and complain here about the fact that 45D actions have led to a spreading of industrial disputes. They cannot have it both ways. If 45D is such a great means of resolving industrial disputes, do not complain in here to us once people have taken action on it that now there is more industrial disputation. That is part of our argument, that 45D is not an efficient means of resolving disputes. It does not help resolve the basic dispute and leads to a spreading of industrial disputation, which can be avoided completely by taking the alternative course which we outlined in this Parliament last year when we suggested that 45D should be abolished and a replacement provision put in the Act. In this case it would most certainly have meant that the matter would have been back in the hands of the Commission months before it got there. We would most likely have had an amical resolution of this dispute, which is just not possible once 45D gets involved.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the reality of the situation. The Opposition is being hypocritical in this place in trying to have it completely both ways-wanting to say that 45D is the greatest way of resolving industrial disputes since creation, and at the same time saying: `Isn't this terrible; we have industrial disputes occurring because somebody took 45D action'. I ask Opposition members to make up their minds what they want. If they have a sensible think about the matter they will see that the appropriate course is to accept alternative proposals which we proposed putting in the legislation last year and which would avoid this mad spreading of disputation in a totally unnecessary way.

I would also like to refer to one other matter in the course of my dissertation, and that is that the National Farmers Federation, as I have said previously, has played an unsavoury role in the whole of this dispute. It has done so in the sense of not being a direct party but nevertheless goading and inspiring the employer in this case to take 45D action. I believe that the Federation's motives in this are highly questionable. One of the reasons that has been given for its taking this action is that it supports the destruction of the tally system, and that this is a means of achieving it. I point out in that regard that a firm called F. J. Walker, which operates an abattoir in the Northern Territory, recently reached an agreement with the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union to continue the tally system and it was registered in the Arbitration Commission last week. F.J. Walker is owned by Elders IXL and a director of IXL is Mr Ian McLachlan, who happens to be the President of the National Farmers Federation. If Mr McLachlan thinks it is such a great idea to have the tally system operating in a company of which he is a director, why is it such a bad thing to be operating in another abattoir in the Northern Territory? I believe it goes beyond the tally system to a desire by the NFF to take on trade union power to bring about industrial confrontation, and for the same reasons as the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been one of the most miserable responses to matter of this type I can remember. No wonder we have the trouble we are having at present at Mudginberri, because the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) does not have the courage, the will, to try to overcome an illegal dispute that has been brought on by a union that is not prepared to accept agreements between employers and employees. In spite of the limp claim of support for the courts and the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the fact is that the Government has not enforced or upheld the law. The Minister is following the example of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) by claiming faults on both sides. There is no fault on both sides so far as the workers and the employees are concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a dispute between the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union and those people it has kicked out of the union because they were not prepared to accept the tally system. The union was not prepared to accept an agreement that was reached between the employers and the employees and ratified by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I ask: Why has not the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations or the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) taken action under sections 45D or 45E of the Trade Practices Act on those meat inspectors who refused to cross the illegal picket line? The Ministers sat by and allowed them to flout the law and the ruling of the courts. Who did give permission to those people to camp and to picket in the Kakadu National Park? Were they camped there illegally? I do not think the Government has ever tried to come to grips with that problem. They were camped on Commonwealth administrative territory and they were there for a very extensive period-over 100 days. The Government has condoned illegal pickets; it has condoned illegal camping in the Kakadu National Park; it has refused to make sure that Commonwealth meat inspectors carried out their duty. During the dispute they were on full pay although they were not working. The Government has acted in a very gutless manner on this issue.

The cosy relationship between the Hawke Labor Government and the new commissar of the Australian Council of Trade Unions has already cost this country several million dollars in lost export meat contracts. The irresponsible actions of the Transport Workers Union of Australia, which acted in sympathy with the illegal actions of the AMIEU Mudginberri, are now sabotaging the efforts being made by the Australian sheep meat, lamb and beef industry to try to capture new markets in a very competitive world marketing situation.

The selective TWU ban on air-freighted meat to a number of destinations is discriminatory and contemptuous. We now have an extraordinary set of circumstances which not only points to complicity between the ACTU and the the AMIEU in the Mudginberri dispute but also suggests government involvement. A number of factors lead me to the conclusion that Ministers have been receiving their riding instructions on a number of actions that have taken place right throughout this Mudginberri issue. Clearly, the trade union movement will fight to the last ditch the right of employers and employees to enter into their own contractual arrangements. The unions are fighting an agreement reached between the employers and the employees at Mudginberri which had the blessing of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission simply because the union was not involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shameful conduct.

—It is shameful. The unions are fighting the right of employees to negotiate an agreement under which they could receive up to $1,000 a week as against the $450 to $500 a week maximum they can earn under the tally system which is the system which this union was trying to force upon the 25 workers. The tally system is a rigid and discredited system in many of the abattoirs around Australia. Commissar Crean warned employers that the union movement will retaliate against all similar attacks on fundamental union principles. Are these fundamental union principles trying to force people to accept a lower level of pay under an agreement than they would receive under some award that the AMIEU believes is the right and proper award under which people should work? Commissar Crean tells us:

SPEECH.PARA: There is going to be on-going action in relation to the Mudginberri dispute by virtue of pursuit of Section 45D proceedings.
He warns us:
If anyone uses the law and has the support of the law the movement has no alternative but to go on the attack.

What an outrageous statement from one who has studied law and who undertook a law degree. What arrogance from commissar Crean! In other words, he is exhorting the trade union movement to defy the law and to support illegal action such as those of the AMIEU. Commissar Crean warned the Opposition that agreements between employers and employees, such as that achieved at Mudginberri, should not be viewed as an alternative to centralised wage fixing even though the employees are better off. He rejects the argument that the Mudginberri agreement is a viable alternative to the laborious union dominated centralised wage fixation system. What he is rejecting is the rights of the individual and groups to achieve a better deal for themselves than they could get under the reactionary involvement of discredited unions.

The ACTU is not prepared to accept that other people should have the right to reach agreement without the intervention or involvement of people such as commissar Crean. It is arrogant in the extreme for the commissar to assume that the trade union movement is the only protector of living standards in this country. Who is he to claim that those living standards would be threatened if the unions were not involved in every agreement reached between employers and employees? Look at what has happened to youth unemployment in this country as a result of the adoption of the same principles. Some 25 per cent of our kids under the age of 25 are unemployed because of the inflexibility of and the way in which youth wages were structured by the union movement thus bringing pressure to bear on the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission back in 1974-5 in the days of Minister Cameron.

There is a growing number of unanswered questions over the Hawke Government's complicity in these disputes. The Government's performance on Mudginberri has been absolutely gutless and compliant. A number of curious happenings at Mudginberri have given rise to a belief amongst many people that there has been complicity between the Government, the ACTU and the leaders of the meat employees' union. Prior to the disgraceful illegal picketing by the union at Mudginberri, the Department of Primary Industry moved the Commonwealth meat inspectors from Mudginberri to Jabiru. We were told that the housing conditions at Mudginberri were unsatisfactory and that alternative, more satisfactory, accommodation was available in Jabiru. I have it on informed authority that this is a nonsense because the Jabiru accommodation is, at best, no better than that at Mudginberri. No one else is permitted to stay over night or lodge at Jabiru. Why are the meat inspectors permitted to stay at Jabiru? Who gave permission to the meat inspectors to lodge at Jabiru? When was the decision made to move the Commonwealth inspectors? Did the Minister give an instruction or was he aware of the decision and timing of the move? Was it decided to shift these inspectors to Jabiru so that they would have to cross the picket lines in order to undertake meat inspections to satisfy export requirements?

A number of other facts need to be publicly aired so that people can make their own judgments about the conspiracy theory. Firstly, the Minister for Primary Industry refused to grant approval to accept Northern Territory qualified meat inspectors and veterinary officers as Commonwealth meat inspectors. They are sufficiently experienced and qualified for such a designation. The Minister claimed he had made this decision because he did not want to inflame the situation.

Quite clearly, the Commonwealth meat veterinary officer who was on duty was prepared to perform his duty. I ask the Minister to answer these questions. Did the Commonwealth veterinary officer refuse to perform his duties? Was he requested to work? What duties was he asked to carry out? Honourable members should remember that it was a Commonwealth veterinary inspector who decided to cross the picket line and stay on duty. Were his regular reports to the Department ignored during the pickets at Mudginberri? I ask the Minister if he is fair dinkum to table the regular reports of the Commonwealth veterinary officer. If the Minister does not, he is trying to cover up his own actions. Those reports are the key to whether the works or killings were carried out in accordance with Export Inspection Service requirements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand Mr G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was interesting to talk to two members of the National Party of Australia over the luncheon break. SPEECH.PARA: The National Farmers Federation would be well advised to stop gloating at the victories it has had over the AMIEU lest its bragging raises the stakes too high for the ACTU to ignore. Its behaviour has already guaranteed bad industrial relations in the meat industry for years to come.

I say to Opposition honourable members who are farmers-

It is openly encouraging the dispute by assisting the National Farmers Federation. It is also interesting to note that employers in general have made it clear, certainly to the union, that they have told the National Farmers Federation to keep out of this dispute. SPEECH.PARA: Employers are opposed to the deregistration talk by the National Farmers Federation and to any fines being placed on the union through actions by the Federation. They have told it that once the stock leaves the farm it becomes the property of the processors; therefore, the Farmers Federation ought to keep its bib out of industrial relations. That is something that the Federation does not understand. That goes for the National Party because it certainly does not understand industrial relations. That is quite clear. Let us consider the company R. J. Gilbertson Pty Ltd. It has written to the Federal Secretary of the union totally dissociating itself from the blue in Mudginberri and wanting nothing to do with it. It told the union that what is happening at Mudginberri is a crime in terms of good relations within the industrial arena of the meat industry. That is quite clear. Those opposite can look at the letter. It is there to be seen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you been to Mudginberri?
—Of course I have been to Mudginberri. Has the honourable member been to Mudginberri?
—Yes, I have.
—It is a wonder that the honourable member got away alive. In 1984 the National Farmers Federation, through its industrial spokesperson said:

SPEECH.PARA: However, deregistration of the Queensland AMIEU is only the first step in the NFF's plan.

Quite clearly, the National Farmers Federation is in league with the Opposition in trying to bring about industrial unrest in this country. Under this Government we have had extraordinarily good industrial relations, far better than the Opposition was ever able to achieve.

I take the opportunity, as Simon Crean was mentioned, to put on record my congratulations to him and also to Jack O'Toole for his leadership of the Australian Meat Industry Employees Union in this dispute at Mudginberri. Who is the owner of Mudginberri and from where did he come? His name is Mr Pendarvis. From where is the money coming to bankroll this operation? It is coming from the National Farmers Federation, the Queensland Government and, I understand, from the Westpac Banking Corporation. Is Westpac not the bank that orchestrated the change of leadership of the Liberal Party recently? I understand that someone from Westpac was on the phone on the morning of the ballot and told the Opposition to change leaders. I also understand that Westpac is bankrolling Pendarvis in this dispute. It is outrageous that this has been allowed to occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is bankrolling the union?

—No one is bankrolling the union, other than its members. The members will win out in this dispute. They will be shown to have behaved in an honourable way and they will win the dispute as it goes through the system. On a number of occasions the AMIEU has tried to settle this dispute. That can be shown by the fact that it applied for a variation of the award. That was agreed to by Sir John Moore on 5 September. As the Minister pointed out, the matter has now been sent back to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It will be considered by the Commission in October.

SPEECH.PARA: In contrast, the National Farmers Federation and the owner of the operation, Pendarvis, have refused invitations by the Government and others to sit around the table in the normal industrial relations way to solve the dispute. They have boycotted it and done everything they can to inflame the situation. The Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), knows that. These people have gone out of their way to aggravate the situation. They stand condemned. The National Farmers Federation and the National Party, its puppet in this place, stand condemned for the disruption that they are causing within the industry.

The Minister also referred to Ian McLachlan, the President of the National Farmers Federation. He is a very interesting gentleman. On the one hand, he took part in a debate on television with Jack O'Toole, the Federal Secretary of the union, saying how bad it was that the Mudginberri dispute was proceeding in such a way. On the other hand, he is a director of Elders IXL. That company owns a number of plants throughout Australia, including some in the Northern Territory. Mr McLachlan cannot have his cake and eat it too. He cannot argue on behalf of the National Farmers Federation that the system operating at Mudginberri be the rule for the industry and, at the same time, through Elders, approach the union asking it to give an undertaking to operate under the tally system at Tennant Creek. That operation is Elders-owned. That seems to smack of hypocrisy-asking the union to comply with two different systems. That cannot be done in industrial relations. McLachlan is playing a very dangerous game. Other operators ought to watch out because, at the same time, Elders is negotiating with the union for the killing and supply of buffalo-feral meat-to markets in the south. McLachlan needs to be examined very closely.

The Tennant Creek operation, as the Minister said, is under the F. J. Walker Ltd award. It has been registered with the Arbitration Commission. As I pointed out, Elders is trying to break into other areas. It seems that the National Farmers Federation and the National Party need to do a bit of explaining to the general community. It is quite clear that the Opposition has set about, through its supporters in the National Farmers Federation, creating havoc in the industrial relations arena. It is attempting to do this through this dispute. The National Farmers Federation has proved that its members are nothing but a bunch of brigands and blackmailing thugs who are withholding stock. Those opposite know that it is true that the Federation is withholding stock from any abattoir that does not comply with its wishes. How can McLachlan be paid, on the one hand, to withhold stock from certain plants and, at the same time, support Pendarvis and those at Mudginberri? The Federation members are behaving like brigands.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the trade union movement?

—Those opposite should not worry about the trade union movement. We are ready to go back to the Commission where the dispute ought to be. We are acting in accordance with proper industrial relations rules. The Federation is on a path to destroy industrial relations in this country. Those opposite are part of it because they want to deregulate the industrial relations area. They are on record as saying that. There is no doubt that this is a conspiracy-dare I use the word-between the National Party, the Liberal Party and their lackeys in the National Farmers Federation to try to bring about disruption. Who are the members of the National Farmers Federation? In no way do they represent the decent, hard-working farming community throughout Australia. They are a bunch of elite, wealthy pastoralists who are trying to destroy industrial relations. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition knows that that is true.
—I raise a point of order. I have a lot of small farmers in my electorate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill repeals sub-section 69 (3) of the Judiciary Act 1903. The sub-section is one of the original provisions of the Judiciary Act, and has remained in substantially unaltered terms since 1903. At that time, there were few arrangements for legal aid in Australia and, as such, section 69 (3) was a most useful and necessary provision. It was consistent with similar provisions in the United Kingdom and some Australian States. However, in the words of a Supreme Court judge considering the sub-section earlier this year, it can now only be described as an `historical anachronism'. I would go further and say that it is not only out of step with modern developments in the provision of legal aid but also ripe for exploitation.

Under section 69 (3) a person charged with an offence against the laws of the Commonwealth may apply to a judge of the High Court of Australia or a supreme court of a State for the appointment of counsel for his or her defence. If the judge certifies that the person is without adequate means to provide for his or her own defence and that it is desirable in the interests of justice that counsel be appointed, the Attorney-General is then to make arrangements for that defence. The principle underlining this provision is one which will all would accept. The International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, to which Australia is a party, recognises this. Article 14.3(d) of the Covenant provides:
everyone shall be entitled to the following minimum guarantees-
. . . to have legal assistance assigned to him, in any case where the interests of justice so require, and without payment by him in any such case if he does not have sufficient means to pay for it.
The question which the Bill addresses is the most appropriate mechanism to provide legal aid for those facing criminal charges.

Since sub-section 69 (3) was enacted, and particularly since the 1970s and the work of the previous Labor Administration, this country has seen the development of a very comprehensive and integrated system of legal aid based on the provision of funding through State and Territory legal aid commissions and the Australian Legal Aid Office. In addition, there is a very valuable network of community legal centres in all States. Commonwealth funding for these centres has been increased by approximately 35 per cent to $1.5m within the total Commonwealth legal aid budget. The Commonwealth provides substantial funding from the operation of various elements of legal aid, currently spending about $1.2m per week or $70.26m in 1985-86, an increase of 22 per cent over the figure for 1984-85.

This system provides for legal aid in relation to indictable Commonwealth criminal offences with slight variations among jurisdictions as to means and merits tests. The various legal aid authorities throughout Australia provide legal aid on the basis of the ability of the applicant to meet the cost of proceedings. That is the fundamental test in every case. The system also provides for comprehensive review and appeal procedures where an applicant is dissatisfied with the amount of aid granted or with a refusal of aid. Until this year, certificates had rarely been sought under section 69 (3). It has now become apparent, however, that applicants are using section 69 (3) either to supplement assistance already obtained or to seek assistance which they have otherwise been refused by legal aid bodies in accordance with the accepted tests.

The increase in use of section 69 (3) has followed publicity given to a Federal Court decision earlier this year. In effect, the decision places the Attorney-General in a position where he has no discretion to exercise independent judgment. For example, he has no discretion as to whether the accused is in fact without adequate means to provide his or her defence, or is able to obtain assistance from some other source. If this state of affairs continues, it is anticipated that the costs to the Commonwealth could be substantial. Assistance given pursuant to the certificate issued in the first case this year is likely to amount to $225,000. Since then, two further certificates have been issued to other applicants. The extent of assistance has not yet been ascertained in relation to these but in one case assistance may well be in the order of $1m.

While it was always intended that legal aid would be available to persons meeting guidelines laid down by legal aid bodies, it was not intended that applicants would, in effect, be able to circumvent those bodies established to administer the legal aid funds and go direct to the Commonwealth. Nor was it intended that the courts would be asked to make decisions on questions such as whether or not an accused person has adequate means to provide for his own defence. Such questions are essentially administrative questions and not suited to determination by courts whose procedures on these questions are necessarily expensive and more cumbersome. Following the establishment of their legal aid commissions, the States have already recognised the inconsistency of retaining provisions similar to section 69 (3). Consequently, New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland have repealed such provisions in the Poor Prisoner Defence Acts or similar legislation.

Given that legal aid will continue to be available through the ALAO and State legal aid commissions, the repeal of section 69 (3) should not have any effect on Australia's international obligations and, in particular, on its obligations under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. The legal aid schemes operating in each jurisdiction today, in the Government's view, satisfy the provisions of the International Covenant. Compared with the provisions available in 1903, the current system provides a far greater service and coverage for those in need. The requirement which we and the community face is to spread the legal aid dollar fairly and equitably. A provision such as section 69 (3) can operate to distort the normal legal aid processes and is redundant. I commend the Bill to the House.
