PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill, which is part of a package of revised assistance arrangements for the commercial motor vehicle industry in Australia, proposes the phasing out over a three-year period commencing on 1 January 1986 of the bounty assistance on certain components used in the assembly of general purpose heavy commercial vehicles. The bounty, which was introduced in 1978, had been due to terminate on 30 June 1985. However, in order to avoid any disruption to the industry pending a final decision by the Government on the future assistance arrangements for the industry, it was extended by the Government until 31 December 1985.

New assistance arrangements for this industry were announced by the Government on 6 August 1985 and will have the effect of ensuring that the level of assistance currently provided by the bounty will be maintained through an equivalent level of tariff assistance on most components presently covered by the bounty scheme. Thus, while the form of assistance will change from a bounty on local production to a tariff on imported components, the level of assistance will generally be maintained.

Proposed section 14D of the Bill proposes that during the three-year phasing period the bounty will be reduced from its current level of 20 per cent to nil by 1 January 1989. At the same time it is proposed that the relevant tariff assistance be progressively increased from nil to 25 per cent by 1 January 1989. The appropriate customs tariff alterations will be contained in a Customs Tariff Amendment Bill to be introduced later in the sittings. In developing the new assistance package the Government took into account the comments made by the Industries Assistance Commission-the IAC-in its 1984 report on heavy commercial vehicles parts and accessories. The Commission's preferred option was for the existing bounty and by-law arrangements on components to be phased out over five years with duty rates on completely built-up vehicles to be increased to 25 per cent. The Commission proposed that at the end of the phasing period, components which currently attract by-law would be dutiable at the general rate of 25 per cent.

The Government accepted the finding of the IAC that the level of assistance accorded vehicle assembly was too high and had resulted in an unacceptable level of fragmentation in the industry. However, it was hard to see any benefits in the IAC's preferred package since it involved both a contraction in industry activity and increased prices to consumers. The IAC proposal aimed at a massive reduction in assistance levels to assembly. The reduction envisaged was in fact more substantial than that set for the passenger motor vehicle sector under the Government's current policy. If assistance levels were to be reduced on the scale proposed by the Commission, a very substantial contraction in both local assembly and component production would be inevitable. Similar views were expressed by the majority of the industry.

In developing the new assistance package the Government also took into consideration submissions from industry which noted that the bounty had not been successful in encouraging the use of local components in the assembly of heavy commercial vehicles. Rockwell Standard of Australia Ltd, for instance, once the largest manufacturer of bountiable components, which used to be in my electorate, was unable to sustain its manufacturing activities in spite of the relatively high level of assistance accorded by the bounty redistribution. A number of manufacturers of bountiable components requested that bounty assistance be replaced by a tariff, generally at the rate of 25 per cent. As a consequence of criticism of the existing arrangements, the Government is concerned to simplify the current assistance which involves a mix of tariff and bounty assistance on a small range of components. The new arrangements will place assistance on a tariff only basis, by 1 January 1989, generally at a uniform rate of 25 per cent.

I mentioned earlier that this Bill only covers the bounty part of the Government's new assistance package. It may be helpful if I were to outline briefly the other aspects of the Government's package which are not covered by the Bill. The other main elements of the package are:

(1) There will be a reduction in the general tariff rate for general purpose heavy commercial vehicles and most special purpose vehicles from the present rates of 22.5 per cent and 25 per cent respectively to 20 per cent. Crane lorries, which are currently dutiable at 35 per cent on the crane section and 25 per cent on the lorry, will attract a single rate of 30 per cent;

(2) Duty at the existing rates for non-bountiable components, except those for fire engines less than 2.72 tonnes gross vehicle mass, which will increase from 2 per cent to 25 per cent will be maintained. The reason for the increase on these fire engine components is that most components for fire engines under 2.72 tonnes GVM are indistinguishable from components for other vehicles;

(3) By-law entry is to be restricted to components for use in the assembly of the cab-chassis only of general purpose vehicles and driveable chassis only in the case of buses. This is designed to remove an anomaly whereby assemblers of general purpose vehicles could import body components duty free whereas body builders were denied similar access. To amend the by-law to enable body builders and others to obtain access to duty free componentry would result in a substantial reduction in assistance to producers of components for truck and bus bodies;

(4) A tariff of 25 per cent is to apply to bodies and trailers when imported separately. When imported with or as part of a completely built-up vehicle, these components attract the same duty rate as the vehicle. This is being done to avoid the situation whereby two different rates could apply to a complete vehicle, for example, 20 per cent on the cab-chassis and 25 per cent on the body. Such split rates cause administrative complexities for exporters, importers and the Australian Customs Service and the Government feels that they should be avoided wherever possible; and

(5) A uniform tariff of 25 per cent is to apply to filters other than filters from New Zealand, which will remain dutiable at existing rates. Filters are currently dutiable at rates ranging from 2 per cent to 35 per cent, with about 80 per cent of imports being dutiable at 25 per cent. Many filters which are dutiable at 2 per cent are exactly the same as others dutiable as 25 per cent, and this has created difficulties in the past for Customs administration. This decision removes that anomaly and a uniform rate of 25 per cent will apply. New Zealand rates on filters have to remain at current levels under the provisions of the Australia-New Zealand closer economic relations trade agreement.

The advice of the Automotive Industry Authority is being sought on what additional components, if any, would be competitive with imports at the general rate of 25 per cent. Further announcements will be made on this aspect in due course.

The new arrangements I have just outlined seek a more moderate reduction in assistance to assembly activity than that suggested by the IAC. The Government expects that they will lead to a reduction in prices to consumers and to a much healthier and more competitive local industry. The majority of the provisions in the Bill, notably provisions in Parts 2, 3 and 4, relates to changes to modernise the administrative provisions in the existing Act. The new provisions are similar to provisions incorporated in other bounty legislation since 1984.
Financial Impact Statement

It is estimated that the cost of bounty assistance during the phase-out period will be $1.25m for the period 1 January 1986 to 30 June 1986, $2m in the fiscal year 1986-87, $1.4m in 1987-88 and $0.6m from 1 July 1988 to 31 December 1988. All values are at current prices. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr White) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: INTERSTATE ROAD TRANSPORT BILL 1985[COGNATE BILL:INTERSTATE ROAD TRANSPORT BILL 1985]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Bill 1985.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting at 12.45 p.m., I was addressing the problem of funding for roads and the effect that has on the safe and economic passage of road transporters. I was using as an example the Princes Highway east of Dandenong. The Victorian Minister of Transport, the Hon. Tom Roper, has alleged that the Commonwealth has diverted some $10m from the Princes Highway east to the Hume Highway. As a result, whether or not that allegation proves correct-I invite the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) who is at the table, to respond to it-large sections of construction of a dual carriageway east of Dandenong remain uncompleted.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter has been of tremendous concern for a great many Victorians-not just for the residents of Gippsland, my electorate, and the residents of the electorate of the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) but also for the tens of thousands of visitors and tourists who journey east. It is nothing short of a scandal that so much of that highway remains single lane and, more importantly, dangerously so. Half-completed works on a dual carriageway stretch for kilometre after kilometre. It is galling to be travelling at a slow speed parallel to an unfinished dual carriageway on which no work has been undertaken for some weeks. Any work that is under way on some parts is progressing at a snail's pace. I ask the Minister whether the allegation by the State Minister that funds have been diverted to the perhaps more politically sensitive Hume Highway are true or, if the $10m figure is not accurate, to what extent funds have been diverted. I may say that State-Commonwealth clashes over road funding have far more to do with the need to satisfy different constituencies than with party politics or party rivalries. I accept that, as would every member of the Opposition. If the claims by the State Minister are incorrect, I certainly wish to know so that I may respond to my constituents, who have laid the blame fair and square at the feet of the Commonwealth.

I mentioned before the suspension of the sitting my unease about a number of aspects of this legislation, none more important than the failure of the Minister to consult properly with both the industry and the States. We know that the States must enact legislation to complement the legislation before the Parliament today. Sadly, looking at their timetables, it is unlikely that the States will pass such complementary legislation until the middle of 1986 at the earliest. In one or two States there are indications that the legislation may not even be passed until late next year. I am puzzled-and again I ask the Minister for an answer-why the legislation has been introduced in this fashion. Moreover, I question the logic of the Minister introducing legislation covering only some aspects of the Commonwealth's response to the May committee's recommendations. Why does he not wish to bring in a compact package of legislation rather than what seems to be piecemeal legislation dealing with part of the May committee's recommendations which will necessitate further legislation in the future to deal with other aspects?

Mr Deputy Speaker, you will be aware that before the luncheon suspension I asked the Minister whether the regulations under this legislation had been referred to the regulation review unit within the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. Whilst in the process of asking the Minister to respond to specific questions, I further ask him whether he agrees with the rate regulation for interstate road freight referred to and rejected by the May committee, as the Minister is only too well aware, which recommendation I understand the Government accepted. Does the Minister support the Australian Road Transport Federation and the Transport Workers Union in setting minimumn interstate rates for owner-drivers? You will realise, Mr Deputy Speaker, that this is a matter of crucial importance. If the Minister-and the Government, by extension-does not support the Federation's and union's agreements for rate setting, will he please say so to alleviate the many doubts and concerns that this agreement is causing to operators in the industry?

In conclusion I wish to say that there are many aspects of this legislation which I support enthusiastically. It is in my view a good initial response to the May committee's recommendations, but I do not believe it is a complete response and I do not agree that it ought to be brought in at this time when it is demonstrably obvious that the States and the industry have not been properly consulted and have not considered the fine print, if you like. For that reason I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Murray in which, whilst not withdrawing the support of the Opposition for the Bill, we seek its delay until a later date-the commencement of the 1986 autumn sittings. Failure to do otherwise will mean that this piece of legislation will operate on a trial and error basis and I do not believe that this legislation has the inherent certainty so needed in this field. I invite the Minister to take up the Opposition's amendment and to defer the legislation until the several concerns I and my colleagues have raised, not least the honourable member for Murray, are properly answered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Interstate Road Transport Bill and oppose the amendment moved by the Opposition. In the second reading speech of the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) the importance of the road transport industry was emphasised when he informed us that 75 per cent of all the freight carried in Australia is at some time carried by this industry and that, of the total freight in Australia, 30 per cent is carried by the industry. I think it is true to say that in the past the industry has been left with no national direction to find solutions to the many problems it faces. It seems to me that this is more of a philosophical arrangement because of the navel-gazing exercise that went on under the previous Government. The States righters, the proponents of small government and of getting governments off people's backs, would look at this industry and say that if a truck happened to be in Western Australia it was a Western Australian problem, when that truck went into South Australia it was a South Australian problem and that there was no relationship between the two.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government takes a very much different view and recognises the importance of this industry as a national industry. We are prepared as a national government to tackle the problems, to work with the industry to come up with solutions to the many problems that have confronted it and held it back in the past. Members of the previous Government did nothing more than sit on their hands while demonstrations such as the Razorback blockade in 1979 were portrayed in front of them. This Government, on the other hand, has consulted. In fact the Minister for Transport, who is at the table, early in this Government's tenure commissioned the National Road Freight Industry Inquiry. We have consulted with the States and Territories, with the industry itself, with the unions involved and with the users. There is a clear distinction between the way in which this Government works and the way in which the previous Government did in that this Government consults and tries to tackle the problem on a broad front; that is, it is bringing together people who are involved in the industry to try to reach some consensus on ways in which we can overcome this problem.

When the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) made his initial contribution before the luncheon suspension he said that governments could not put money into the truckies' pockets. That is true, and I do not think anybody on this side would say that that is the intention of the Government. We on this side certainly take the view that governments should stay out of it as much as they can and let the truckies get on with making a profit. One thing this Government can do and has done is to give economic growth to this country so that there is more economic activity and so that the truckies have more opportunity of making a profit. It stands to reason-in fact it is axiomatic-that the level of economic activity in the country is reflected in the profitability that people in this industry enjoy. When the previous Government was kicked out of office there was negative growth and the number of bankruptcies in this industry was skyrocketing. Profit levels in this industry, as in the whole of the economy, have now been restored. We have had 5 per cent growth in the last two years and in the present financial year it will once again reach 5 per cent. In fact we may well admit that it will exceed that.

The National Road Freight Industry Inquiry identified a number of problems. Some of these are not new and have been around for a long time. Boom-busts in the industry at times when the industry is undergoing a very slow period can lead to the playing off of one small operator against another. We can draw an analogy with the industrial relations policy being espoused by dry members of the Opposition. They talk about playing one person off against the other and in that way hope to get the cheapest price. This has happened in the trucking industry. It does no good to the operators or the industry.

All this impacts on the families of the drivers. Interstate truck drivers are away for long periods and having the economic base of their operations threatened in the way I have just outlined has a severe impact on the families. Of course, road safety is something which we as a national government think is a national responsibility, and the inquiry looked at that aspect. There is also a need to educate prospective new entrants. Certainly I do not think anybody who goes into this industry should go into it with his eyes closed or be induced into it by the smooth talking of people who might want to sell him some equipment. I am told that it is very easy to get into the industry but, once one is trapped in it, it is virtually impossible to get out.

Another recommendation which arose out of the inquiry concerned speed limits; that is, the necessity to rationalise speed limits so that trucks are not forced to go at a slower rate than other road users. I remember that a couple of years ago a company in Western Australia advertised its overnight freight rates from Perth to Port Hedland and if one did one's mathematics one soon came to the conclusion that the only way the promise could be fulfilled was if the trucking company actually broke the speed limits. So one can see that that was one of the important findings of the inquiry.

Another recommendation concerned consumer protection. I have spoken briefly about the role played by some over-zealous salesmen who would seek to get people enrolled in the industry by selling them this expensive equipment. I think that the rights of the people buying this expensive equipment should be looked at. This applies not only to this industry but also right across the Australian community. It is not only the truck drivers who are in need of consumer protection but also the Australian public at large. Also arising out of this inquiry will be a fair code of conduct. I do not think that anybody goes into any enterprise and asks for any advantage over his competitors, but I believe people would like to think that the codes of conduct which they employ are being employed by their competitors. If we are to have private enterprise, free enterprise, let us all do it on the same bases. The introduction of the Bills complements the Government's excellent record on the provision of highways in Australia. No government in the history of Australia has spent more on its roads than this Government. This year we will spend $1,245m on our national highways. As I said, that record has not been surpassed.

I wish to take up one of the comments made by the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) about the Hume and Princes highways and the interrelationship between the funding of those two highways. One thing which this Government will not do that the previous Government did is use road funding for the pork barrelling exercises that were rampant during the term of the previous Government. The honourable member for Gippsland might be comforted to know that the only reason, I would think, that the Princes Highway was left undone was because the previous member for Gippsland resigned his seat and the previous Government was defeated. As far as this Government is concerned priorities will be based on need rather than on pork barrelling. That is the reason why the highways which need the funds will receive them.

The only Commonwealth cost to interstate freight transport is the fuel levy. That fact has not been recognised by the Opposition. The Commonwealth Government makes no change on that industry apart from the fuel levy. On looking at the cost to the Government of that industry, I was told that one interstate truck trip causes as much damage and wear and tear to our national highways as 10,000 cars.

The Government has played its part in introducing this legislation today. It has conducted the inquiry over 12 months. As I have said, it has consulted everybody who is in any way associated with industry. One of the criticisms coming from the other side-in fact, it is the intent of the Opposition's amendment-is that the Government is being too hasty and that it should put off this legislation. All I can say to the Opposition is that the report has been out for 12 months. That is long enough to receive fair comment and to have the matter considered in depth; I do not think the Opposition's amendment helps. This problem has been around ever since the first truck went over a State border, and that was many years ago.

The Government has played its part in ensuring that the interstate transport industry in this country is at last getting the recognition that it deserves. It is now up to the States to implement the complementary legislation necessary to allow the provisions of the National Road Freight Industry Inquiry to be realised. I conclude by congratulating the Government on this initiative and congratulating the Minister on the excellent way in which he has handled the inquiry and the negotiations, as I said, with all the people who are associated with the industry. I support the legislation before the House today and oppose the amendment on behalf of the people of Canning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am deeply concerned as to the need for and the haste with which this legislation has been introduced. The honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) was at pains to tell us that the report of the National Road Freight Industry Inquiry has been around about 12 months. That has nothing to do with the legislation. Everybody has seen the report. This is the first week in the history of Australia that anyone has seen the legislation. Legislation is the sharp end. It is from legislation that penalties and all the pressures that can be added to the life of a truck driver occur. I thought it was rather remarkable that the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) told us this morning that the legislation was all about helping truck drivers. There is nothing in it, that I can see, that will help truck drivers.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, I accept that the multiplicity of State road transport law is a problem. I accept that the financial return to the small business truckie is severely depressed. I also accept the criticisms of the safety and general operating conditions of the road transport industry. These things are realities and facts. I do not accept that the involvement of the Federal Government is desirable or necessary. That is clearly evidenced by the fact that all of this is for nothing if State governments do not pass the appropriate complementary legislation. If they intend to pass complementary legislation-the good offices of this Government has managed to get them to that point-why the necessity for this legislation? Why could it not be that, one by one, they put together the necessary uniform legislation and police it as the Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) told us it would be policed? He said: `We are not going to police the legislation. The Commonwealth Government is going to have the States as agents, et cetera'. So why is it necessary for us to rush this piece of legislation through the Parliament? Let me tell honourable members. There is good reason for that. This legislation has a very real purpose; that is, it reintroduces and gives constitutional validity to imposing road maintenance taxes on interstate trucking. That is what the legislation is for. It is most unfortunate that at this stage of the game the trucking industry has not woken up to it.

A few comments have been made today in regard to the various abilities and qualifications of people addressing this subject. One might call the attention of the House to the fact that I am licensed to drive an articulated vehicle, including a road train, up to 100 feet long and I have done so. I have owned quite a number of such vehicles. I have had to be confronted with the economics of operating them. I was a founding director of a very successful medium sized trucking company which dealt solely with owner-drivers. I was able-I urged it from the beginning-to pay those men 70c in the freight dollar, which was something quite unique. I know a bit about the business and I know how truckers live and work.

Far too much has been said today that any person without qualification or substantial financial backing can wander into a finance company and buy a new truck. I have not met such a person yet. Such people might exist-I have heard the talk about it-but I have been in the position of guaranteeing a number of drivers so that they could buy a truck. They were good men with some financial backing, but they could not get the finance on their own. I do not know where they get it from. Some sales people might try to talk them into buying a truck but it is the finance companies which take the final decision. I think that is worth knowing. The legislation does not address that problem any more than it addresses the problem raised by the honourable member for Dunkley of getting the bloke home on time to see his wife. There is nothing about that in the legislation. This legislation is about raising revenue.

If the Minister wants to be critical in any way about what I have to say in respect of the trucking industry, I want him to know that my qualifications and my knowledge based on experience are better than a promotional ride for television between Sydney and Newcastle which he undertook on one occasion.

I think it is foolish to say that the legislation will not lead to Commonwealth involvement. In fact, over time it will result in the creation of a large Federal bureaucracy. The Minister might give us a tip as to what coloured flashing lights vehicles driven by Commonwealth officers will have. I would like to speculate that in line with the current mode of the Government's thinking the lights might be coloured green and gold. It will be quite interesting to see what does happen. The reality is that the legislation makes plenty of provision for that sort of thing. My recollection is that clause 44 of the Bill is concerned with the definitions of various people who can pull up a truck and demand all sorts of things. The clause defines a Commonwealth officer as a person who:
(a) is in the service or employment of the Commonwealth or an authority of the Commonwealth; or
(b) holds or performs the duties of any office or position under a law of the Commonwealth;

If such a person is going to be running around the countryside in a vehicle with green and gold lights, for how long can the community be guaranteed that only one person will be involved? The legislation makes provision for that, and consequently will get it. The trucking industry has to be warned.

We are asked to give carte blanche to regulations. Clause 13 of the Bill is preceded by the heading `Regulations may make further provision with respect to registered motor vehicles'. The clause then lists all the things in respect of which the Commonwealth can make regulations. It is very strange that everybody throughout Australia, including the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), is against regulation at the moment. They are taking this view for a very good reason-they have had enough of regulation. However, the Government is seeking to impose even more regulations on all of the industries that are over-regulated. The Institute of Public Affairs told us recently that for every dollar the Federal Government spends on business regulation the private sector must spend at least $3 just to comply. The cost to the private sector of Federal and State business regulation in 1978-79 has been estimated at $3,720m. The private sector at that time was estimated to have had to provide 16,000 people to comply with Federal Government regulations and a further 38,000 people to comply with State Government regulations. Here we are being offered more regulation in the time honoured system of rush the legislation through the place and come out with the regulations later.

We are well and truly aware that the sharp end of this legislation-the complementary State legislation-will not be ready for months and probably even a year. This Government has been embarrassed with its attempts to regulate the insurance brokers industry to which there is even some cross-reference in this legislation. What has happened in this area? Although the Government rushed token legislation through this place in respect of the insurance brokers industry, regulations in that area have still not been finalised. So what is the rush in this case? The way in which the Government is proceeding is dangerous and is not fair. I personally believe that new and, if one likes, ground breaking legislation of this nature should not be presented to the Parliament unless the regulations are attached. That is the way it should be. One does not get fined thousands of dollars by this legislation. A fine is imposed in accordance with the regulations. This Bill makes provision for regulations under which a driver can be disqualified and lose his livelihood. That is what is in this legislation for the trucking industry.

Let us look at what the trucking industry has got already. We have been told that the Government wants to get more money from the industry. This Bill is all about getting more money off truck drivers who are at present contributing 30 per cent of their revenues in taxes of one form or another. I presented to the House on a previous occasion some examples of that. The sales tax that is amortised on a decent prime mover is about $7,300 per annum. On a trailer it is $1,176. Fuel tax can be estimated at $38,500 per annum. The figure is probably more in view of recent increases. Sales tax on tyres over a year amounts to $4,600. All of these taxes are really Federal Government revenue. The honourable member for Canning said that these things are not being done to truck operators. These people should not have to pay any more Commonwealth revenue to be used to build or service the roads that they use. They should not have to pay the $1,400 plus that this Bill sets out to extract from them because they are making a substantial contribution already. Even sales tax on tarps, dogs and chains cost them $175 a year. Stamp duty on insurance costs them about $400 a year. In some cases licence fees, which already cost them about $1,400 a year, is to be transferred over to the Federal area. Bank charges-this is bad tax-cost a further $237 a year. Of course, they have to pay sales tax on other things.

On a turnover of just $158,000 operators have to pay all of those taxes. In fact, a truck owner-driver working an average of 12 hours a day, 330 days a year pays $12.33 an hour in tax and that amount does not include income tax. What does the Government have in mind for him in the tax area? I do not think there is any doubt that we are going to get a capital gains tax. No one will deny that. Anybody who knows anything about the trucking industry knows that when one trades in a leased vehicle one tries to buy it out. One usually has some equity in the truck which then becomes a capital gain when one trades it in on a new vehicle. The Government is going to tax that capital gain. There will be no inflationary component because everything takes place too quickly. That is just another little thing that will be introduced tomorrow afternoon. Is it not amazing that negative gearing will also come in tomorrow afternoon?

TALK.START.PARA: —That should put the industry into reverse, shouldn't it?

—We are talking about trucks and gear boxes. I just wonder whether all the clocks in the house of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) go backwards on account of negative gearing. It is very probable that they do. I bet that all the investment clocks that he has are negatively geared. Honourable members can take it from me that those negatively geared clocks that all go backwards are not included in any of the tax proposals. It is only people like poor little truckies who will have to carry the burden of government.

SPEECH.PARA: Truckies also have to carry the burden of devaluation of the currency. Nearly all of the line haul operators are using imported trucks which are the only ones available. The Australian Financial Review of 13 May indicated that a Kenworth truck worth $147,000 in March will be worth $200,000 in January 1986. In addition, truck operators are trapped by interest rates. What sort of interest rate will they have to pay on a new hire purchase or lease agreement if they have to turn their truck over because it does not meet the rules and requirements of the new legislation because it is getting a little bit old and shaky? The result will be diabolical.

The real problem faced by the industry is the burden of government. Truck operators do not need to be helped by this legislation which State governments could introduce. I believe that the Minister had other means at his disposal to influence the States. He has just re-negotiated the road grants agreements. Do not tell me that he could not have used that as a bit of weight if he thought it was necessary to overcome the silly situation that exists. However, the Minister has a total commitment to a total bureaucracy in this area. He has demonstrated that already with the Department of Aviation. For example, he totally insulted Dick Smith who tried to tell him that he had some problems in respect of that industry. There was no need to do that to the man who came to tell him how better to run his bureaucracy. The Minister is totally linked to bureaucracy which he is going to make bigger. As I said, the Department of Aviation is an example of that.

I do not know how anyone can justify the stupid statistic that one 38-tonne truck is worse than 10,000 cars in terms of road wear. I know a lot about trucking. A well-equipped truck on recently made roads is not going to do any sort of damage of that nature. People are kidding themselves if they think it will. It is like the lions and the blasted sharks statistic in Western Australia. It may be true that lions have killed more people in Western Australia than have sharks, but that is a meaningless statistic and so too is the one about trucks and motor cars. It is about time we stopped using such comparisons.

Trucking is a very economical way of serving the Australian community and meeting its freight needs. The industry does not need all of this additional involvement. I think that truck operators have to be warned, and warned again, that this is a very insidious piece of legislation that will be used to collect more money from them. the people in the industry are being herded into a flock which will be at the mercy of the big trucking companies, the railways and, of course, the Transport Workers Union which has no time for small truckies, does not want them around and is constantly working to erode their chances of making a living. We see this happening almost daily in the fuel industry. It is a shame that this is happening.

I would like to touch upon some of the other problems that this rather mild piece of legislation will create. Minister, in his second reading speech, talks about disqualification. Of course, we find that disqualification can occur if a person interferes with a measuring device, the device that a person will be required to put on his truck in order to tell the tax collector how many miles he has done. That provision is contained in the legislation. One ground for disqualification will be that a person has interfered with that device. I guess that one some occasions someone else may interfere with the device and a truck owner will have his livelihood taken away from him because he is found guilty of this terrible crime. That is why I say that this Bill is about revenue. It will provide more revenue for the Government. It imposes an additional burden on the trucking industry.

The legislation contains nothing for member's of the trucking industry. They have been told by the honourable member for Dunkley that they will be able to get home to see their wives more often. Someone else has told them that they will get better rates of pay. Let us look at the fraudulent suggestion that the railways will lift their charges as a result of these measures. Of course, that will be believed when it is seen. We do not know what the State governments will do, but the second reading speech states that there will be improvements in railway cost recovery to match any improvements in cost recovery in road freight. What does that mean? I understand that to mean that, for ever extra dollar that is taken from the road industry, there will be some obligation-if it can be made to stick-on the part of the railways to raise their freight rates proportionately. That is all that that means. How does that advantage the trucking industry? The additional cost has already been imposed.

There is no suggestion that I can find in the legislation or in the Minister's second reading speech that the railways will stop making subsidised losses of $50m, $100m or $150m a year and compete on a proper cost basis. That is what the truckies believe is being done for them today. That is not what the second reading speech states. It states that the railways will match the amount of money that goes into this fund. They will do some nice old fiddles in that regard; do not worry about that. Anyone who has tried to look at the books of a State railway will know-as I well know, in trying to represent farmers and to compare the prices charged for grain freights with those charged for mineral freights, and things like that-that the railways work the books to suit themselves. That is the biggest fraud of all. I think the truckies are hanging their hopes on a belief that the Government will stop State governments imposing predatory prices and will deal, of course, with the freight forwarders, the other great enemy of the small owner-driver truckie.

Let us look at what has happened to the truckie in recent times. I will cite freight rate figures for the period 1975 to 1985 between Adelaide and Perth. In 1975 in actual dollars the figure was $64 a tonne, which in real dollars today would be $165.30 a tonne. The rate is $115 a tonne. That shows how much the truckies have been screwed to date. The Government in this legislation will impose additional costs on them. It will appoint another heap of inspectors but it will do nothing else. There is nothing in the legislation for them. It is a useless piece of legislation. If the Government wants to address the questions of safety and uniform requirements, I applaud that, but they are matters for State Governments, anyway. The Government's responsibility was to use its influence to straighten matters out.

The figure for freight rates between Melbourne and Perth is now $147 a tonne. But using the 1975-85 comparison, in 1985 dollars it ought to be $170 a tonne. We find that inflation has gone up by 158 per cent in that decade. Freight rates have increased by 79.7 per cent. That is the message for truckies. Throughout that time the Government has increased their tax burden. It will now impose a capital gains tax. In time, if their interest payments exceed their revenue, which could happen in some circumstances, it will probably want to attack them for using negative gearing. Honourable members should remember what I said: The next time someone talks about negative gearing in this place he should talk about the clocks of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I think they all go backwards because they are negatively geared. I bet the Treasurer does not deny that fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite utterances to the contrary by honourable members opposite, the Interstate Road Transport Bill 1985 and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Bill 1985 that are before the House at present represent a further example of the Hawke Government's commitment to consultation to achieve solutions in areas of difference and conflict. I refer the House to the complimentary comments of the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) on the importance of the co-operation he received from the States, Territories, industry, unions and users in the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: As was mentioned earlier today by my colleague the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), these Bills complement the Government's Australian land transport program legislation, which was a benchmark in Australian transport history.

A cognate debate on the Interstate Road Transport Bill and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Bill is necessary because one provides for the interstate vehicle registration scheme and trust fund, while the other permits the necessary charges to be levied to recover the costs of road maintenance and upkeep. Distribution of trust funds to the States and the Territories for expenditure on relevant roads is also provided for in these Bills.

The interstate vehicle registration scheme will remove the anomaly of vehicles solely engaged in interstate trade avoiding the payment of reasonable registration charges which recover the costs of road damage, as this legislation replaces existing State provisions for registering such vehicles. Previously, under State provisions, a rather nominal fee was charged to interstate vehicles. Obviously, vehicles which are engaged in intrastate trade, or a combination of intrastate and interstate trade, would still be subject to registration under existing State laws.

As has been mentioned by my colleague the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth), owners of interstate vehicles may choose one of two methods for paying the registration charge. They may pay either on the basis of actual distance travelled, as measured by approved distance monitoring equipment installed in the vehicle-which, I hasten to add, is tamper free-or on assessment of the number of kilometres which the vehicle could be expected to travel during the registration period. Both of these options provide for a uniform charge per tonne-kilometre to be set, the initial level of which is to be set in line with the recommendations of the National Road Freight Industry Inquiry-that is, $1,400 for a 38 tonne unit.

The interstate road transport operators licensing scheme proposed in these Bills will provide for operators' licences to be issued to businesses engaged in heavy long distance interstate vehicle operations. Under the Interstate Road Transport Bill, there is provision for a court to withdraw such operator licences when licensing authorities detect persistent breaches of road safety laws or Federal road safety standards. Clauses 10 and 11 of the primary Bill provide that, where a vehicle does not meet safety requirements or have appropriate insurance, it should not be driven on the roads and the appropriate authority can cancel or suspend registration. Clause 34 permits the Minister to establish Federal road safety standards which may be used as part of the criteria against which the conduct of those engaged in interstate transport can be judged in order to determine whether public safety is at risk. Like my colleague, the honourable member for Dunkley, I am particularly concerned about road safety. Accordingly, I am gratified that the Minister for Transport has seen fit to approach this legislation with road users and road safety in mind.

In America the lifestyle and plight of the truckie has become the stuff of folklore, if not legend. Although the exploitation of drivers by owners and operators in that country may not be mirrored in the Australian road transport system, it is certainly the case that long haul drivers, such as those transporting goods to Western Australia, must cope with incredible pressures in terms of turnaround times and general conditions of work. I am not sure whether honourable members present are aware that even a tube of toothpaste is generally road transported to Western Australia. So we are pretty dependent on long haulage by road in this country.

While relatively few truck drivers may actually resort to popping pep pills or other stimulants to keep them awake on long journeys, many continue to put their health at risk in other ways-by driving for too long at high speeds and by failing to eat proper meals or to take regular breathers while on the road. In doing so they obviously place at risk the safety of other road users. I can recall having driven across a white line after nearly falling asleep at the wheel while driving from Melbourne to Perth. I am sure that it is much more difficult when one is in charge of a heavy vehicle.

Road transport in this country has been subject to deep-seated problems which particularly affect owner-drivers and their families. It is an extremely competitive and unstable industry in which bankruptcies abound. Through the use of appropriate monitoring devices the Federal scheme will contribute to greater professionalism and safer operating arrangements within the industry. Proper maintenance of vehicles is crucial to the safety of truck drivers and other road users. I am pleased that these Bills address questions such as that and also the ability of heavy road transport users to drive their trucks in a competent manner.

I congratulate the Minister on his endeavours to achieve agreement on this legislation. It is, indeed, unfortunate that some members of the Opposition choose to claim that consultation has not taken place with State and Territory governments and people in the industry. These are important legislative provisions governing an area of our industry which covers at some stage 75 per cent of all freight being moved throughout Australia. Overall, the industry performs almost 30 per cent of the total domestic transport task. I am very concerned about the need for the provisions contained in these Bills and I commend the legislation to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: It must be said also that the measures inherent in the Bills are definitely measures for the good. The problems facing this country, with its great distances and comparative sparsity of population, put us in a unique position. I suggest that the House recognise that it is time that this legislation be enacted so that the States will be able to operate on the basis of a federal piece of legislation which they knew was to be introduced and which will also give all aspects of the industry the incentive to go ahead and put their house in order so that the industry can have adequate status for it to progress. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the fact also that honourable members who have taken part in this debate have outlined many of the facts concerning the Interstate Road Transport Bill and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Bill as well as the problems and the advantages. I for one appreciate that there have been conferences between the Commonwealth and the States on the future of the trucking and the coach industry throughout Australia, and that there is general agreement within the industry that measures should be adopted that may assist in overcoming some of the problems and place the industry on a much sounder basis than is the case at present. One must appreciate that it has been only in the last ten to 15 years that road transport has developed throughout the continent. Prior to that because of convenience transport was chiefly by rail. It was necessary for the large and smaller transport operators to play their part as the demand arose.

SPEECH.PARA: Although in principle I support the legislation because the industry itself has requested it, I too would like to sound some warnings. I am always concerned when the Commonwealth intrudes on what one could assume is the responsibility of the States. Throughout the debate on this Bill and in the second reading speech of the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris), it has been said that the matters we are principally concerned about are safety, the training of drivers and the standard of trucks. I believe that the intervention of the Commonwealth in this field is only another measure of Commonwealth control and a move to attract greater revenue from the trucking industry throughout the Commonwealth. I do not believe that the legislation is necessary. I do not believe that it is necessary for the Commonwealth to intrude at all onto these measures I mentioned earlier, which basically are the responsibility of the States.

In the years to come I can see that down the line there will be greater control brought about by legislation and regulations. Today the Minister has been asked what will follow so far as the regulations are concerned. Problems will arise. We have only to think about our bus and coach industries in our local districts to see the restrictions that have been placed on them. Admittedly, they have been principally State restrictions. One sees the same thing in the taxi industry. Councils or States have control over entry into that field. I am worried that in the long term-maybe even the short term-such industries will be controlled by the Commonwealth, in consultation with the States. This will ultimately mean that the people who will be involved in the trucking industry throughout this country will be the bigger companies. I am concerned about where smaller truckies finish up.

It is of no use our talking about tax. I know that the truckie using the roads should pay a certain tax towards their upkeep. Earlier in this debate the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) pointed out that today the truckie is paying tremendous taxes. He is paying tremendous taxes on his fuel, on the vehicle he buys, on the parts that he buys for the vehicle and on his insurance. Most of this revenue is going into government coffers, either Commonwealth or State. We need to realise this. I advise the House to be on guard against the innovations that could arise in years to come following the introduction of this measure.

This legislation gives Big Brother, the Commonwealth, for the first time control over a tax on the truckies of this country who are travelling interstate. While it may be necessary for some conformity between the Commonwealth and the States perhaps for registration fees or certain conditions of transport-sure it is necessary to have these-do not tell me that the States have to come to the Commonwealth and say: `You have to bring in the legislation and impose a fee'.

I would like to question where the $14m will be spent. I want to see it spent not only on national highways but also on the arterial, rural and local roads of this country. This is very important. We know that roads have to be upgraded. A fair amount of funding is now going into roads. I am wondering whether truckies will be overburdened by their financial responsibility to meet the challenge. Where have we gone wrong? Possibly the Minister and I would agree on this matter. I give him credit for many things which he does. We have to realise that where this country has gone wrong is in our rail and road transport system generally.

A train is the only thing that travels on a railway line. What travels on a road? All types of vehicles, pedestrians, bicycles and all nature of things move on a road, but there is no conflict on a railway line. A train goes either one way or the other. We are not using our railway system throughout this country as much as we should for freight. I will tell honourable members what will happen if we have a balance between road costs and rail costs. The consumer right down the line will be the person who will cop the result of the legislation. If we are to get cost recovery from road transport and if we are to parallel that with cost recovery from railways, it is a natural thing that freight costs will have to rise. That is why I question this entire legislation. I see many inefficiencies in our State railway system, particularly the New South Wales system which is running at about a $400m a year loss. Will we recover sufficient costs from rail freight to meet that? All road freight in this country should be sent by rail and I have said why. Only a train travels on a railway line. Surely we can have a more efficient service than we have at present.

I accept the fact that there are instances, particularly with country industry and decentralisation, where certain industries are established only because they are able to load their product at A and take it directly to B without having to handle it two, three and four times. Road transport is essential. It is essential in every country, even the British Isles which has motorways and efficient railway systems. However, they still require road transport. So the road and rail systems should be able to run much more in harmony and much more satisfactorily than what they are at present.

Let me go back to what I said at the beginning of my remarks. We are facing a period when the road transport of this country is still developing. It will develop further. But for goodness sake, the Commonwealth should keep its dirty fingers out of it because we do not need it. Let the States handle this matter. This afternoon we have heard such nonsense from a lot of Government members who have spoken about the personal effect this legislation will have on drivers. We live in a competitive world. If I am prepared to borrow money to start an enterprise of my own I have to compete with the other fellow-big and small. Is it not fair that we do that? How much can we protect every enterprise in the community? Sure, we have a responsibility to protect the safety standard of a vehicle and the qualifications of the person who will drive it. I do not know whether it is a Commonwealth responsibility; I believe it is a State one.

This legislation is accepted on both sides of the House because the industry has sought it and has consulted with the Minister about it. However, is the industry becoming a little too frantic too early? Should it not look at other measures that it should adopt, sit back and wait and see what the results of the legislation will be? The Minister brought in the legislation and the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), moved a very sensible amendment. Let us steady down a little and look at the legislation. Let us wait and see what the States will do. Let us see whether the States do agree with it. I am not so sure that all the States of Australia do agree with the legislation. I doubt that they do.

My word is one of warning. We should be very careful because we are building something gigantic and over the years ahead its cost will be very considerable indeed so far as all types of transport are concerned.

I do not want to see us take any measure which, down the line, will place the road and coach transport industries of this nation into the hands of a few big operators throughout Australia. We should look after the industry. The Minister's intention with this legislation might be very good. I may be a little older than the Minister. I may not have had any more experience than he has but I respect him. Let me say this: There are dangers for road transport in the legislation that is before the Parliament at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address only two aspects of the Interstate Road Transport Bill and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Bill: Firstly, the quality of the legislation and, secondly, the steady erosion of individual liberties which one of its clauses exemplifies. We have heard from the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) that this is a comprehensive package and he has extolled the virtues of his own work. Of course, he has denigrated the work of the previous Government-not his Government, but ours. Yet, if we look at just one clause-clause 34-of the Bill we will see immediately how well founded is the Opposition's case that this Bill should be redrafted. What does it deal with? It deals with Federal road safety standards. What does it say? Laconically, it says:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of this Part, the Minister may, by order in writing, declare standards, to be known as federal road safety standards with respect to road safety matters.

Given the aims of this Bill, one would think that a matter of prime importance would be the standards that the truck drivers will be asked to meet. Yet we do not know what they are. Presumably the Minister does not know what they are. It would certainly seem that the industry does not know what they are. I wonder whether his Department has any idea what they should be. If it has any idea, it is not telling us. What will happen? At some later stage some regulations will be put in place. They will set up safety standards-standards which may be quite arbitrary and beyond anything which is reasonable-on which we will have no opportunity whatsoever to express a view. So much for the quality of the legislation. Let me turn to clause 45. It is described in the explanatory memorandum, which states:

Sub-clause (1) empowers a Regulatory Authority to require a person to furnish information or produce documents relating to the performance of the Authority's functions or to contraventions of this Bill and its regulations:-
regulations we have not seen-
or relevant safety provisions. Failure to comply with such a request without reasonable excuse is an offence under the Bill.
It continues:

Sub-clause (3) provides that self-incrimination does not constitute an excuse for refusing to furnish information or produce documents. However self-incriminating information or documents are not admissable as evidence except in specified types of prosecutions such as those involving criminal conspiracy.

Is it not kind of the legislation before the House to allow that amount of exculpation. Many years ago we developed the concept of the right to remain silent. It has been in the law for hundreds of years. I acknowledge immediately that it has been infringed by past governments. There are occasions and circumstances which require that answers should be compelled; for example, special investigations under the Companies Act, certain inquiries into criminal matters of the kind conducted by royal commissions and by the National Crime Authority committee. But the case for them has to be compelling.

What do we find in this legislation? Anyone requested pursuant to this power is compelled to produce information. True it is that, except for certain special purposes, that information cannot be used directly against him in evidence in criminal proceedings. But anybody who has any understanding of how criminal inquiries work knows that once the facts are known it is not a hard job to prove an offence by different means. The important thing is to know what are the facts. This legislation provides a power of compulsion.

What else does it say? I would like the Minister to provide an answer on this because perhaps there is an answer. Sub-clause (4) of clause 45 contains a provision to the effect that a person is not excused from giving information because it may incriminate. Earlier in the legislation we see that a person is bound unless, in effect, there is lawful excuse, to produce a document or information when required to do so by a regulatory authority and to do that in writing, and sign it.

Will the Minister advise the House whether legal and professional communications are excluded under this clause? There certainly were similar provisions in other Acts-I have not checked whether they are still there; perhaps the Minister has checked. I speak particularly of the Companies Code-which provides that the provisions are not intended to overcome legal professional privilege. A provision may be found-if not in this legislation, elsewhere-which would protect legal professional privilege. I should be glad if the Minister would tell us where it is to be found. If it is not to be found, under no circumstances could this House allow legal professional privilege to be invaded in such a casual manner.

It is sometimes said by this Government that it is the great defender of rights. Yet we know and the Australian people are learning that it divides rights into two categories. There are those who are entitled to rights, for example Mr Crean and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and those not entitled to rights, for example the workers at Mudginberri, who are quite deluded when they think that they have rights. Abattoir workers and owner-drivers fall into the category of persons who, according to this Government and the Australian Labour Party, do not have rights. Once more we witness a small instance, some may think, but a very clear instance of a further erosion of basic rights, the right being the right to remain silent. If someone is stopped by a policeman in New South Wales or the Australian Capital Territory for killing somebody, the law says that he has the right to remain silent. Courts cannot compel someone to give evidence against himself yet, by the means in this Bill, that right is abrogated in a fundamental way.
