That was the undertaking at the Australian Transport Advisory Council at its last meeting. In our position we have to recognise in the spirit of this issue that each of the States has traditional ways of handling this industry and each of the States has its particular problems. As long as the thrust and the spirit is there, I believe we can reach the stage where industry, the States and the governments will be satisfied that substantial progress has been made to enable the proclamation of the legislation.

The honourable member for Murray said that rail freight increases must occur first. I make the point to the House that when we look at the transport system in this country we are not looking at road or rail-and that is the great tragedy of the past and a tragedy of some of the present. It is a matter of road and rail. Each form of transport carrying out that task for which it is technically and socially efficient is the economic answer to the problem at hand in that particular form of transport. In that way we will get the best possible result in export performance and economic performance for this country. We undertook to give a reference to the Inter-State Commission concerning the rate of cost recovering in road and rail. It has that reference and that investigation is under way. We are establishing for the first time in this nation the actual rate of cost recovery in road and rail. There were guesstimates in the past and there have been advised estimates, but that is now the task of the Inter-State Commission. It is not a matter of regulation, as some would suggest.

The honourable member for Murray also wants completion of progress before proclamation. I think I have covered that adequately in the remarks I have already made. The Opposition previously indicated its support for the recommendations and the Government is acting on them. A number of honourable members on the other side made reference to some sort of bloated Commonwealth bureaucracy. No matter what the legislation contained, they said that they knew this was going to happen, that there would be this army of public servants. I am sorry to disappoint them, but there will be one officer. I do not have any spare staff in my Department to devote to that purpose. What we are doing in effect with this legislation is providing legislation to fill a gap between State and Federal responsibilities in respect of road transport. Having provided the Federal legislation, we will then utilise the State administrative systems. The Commonwealth will legislate and the States will collect the charges and do the inspections utilising their existing administrative structures. They will collect the revenue, which will be paid back to the Commonwealth, as the second reading speech shows, and put in a trust fund which the Commonwealth will hold until it is dispensed in full to the States again. That gets around the problem that nobody has been able to solve in the past. To speculate that there is some kind of enormous bureaucracy is just fantasy. It is not on. In decades ahead, if the Opposition is elected to government maybe it would want to do that, but certainly that is not the intention of this Government. It will not happen under this Government.

The honourable member for Murray also raised the question of payment by instalments. The Interstate Road Transport Bill provides for that under clause 9 and the frequency of instalments will be left to the States to determine, whether it be six-monthly or whatever they want to arrange, but that is being provided for. He also said that government authority vehicles should be subject to the same fees. That is a matter that I am discussing with my colleagues. He also raised the matter of police enforcement of the new speed limits. I think we all agree that the real test of speed limits is whether they are actually being observed by the community. We know what they are. In respect of trucks, that ground has been covered, but suffice to say if the limits are to be raised-having a common limit for all vehicles outside built-up areas-there has to be visible enforcement of the speed limits. That is a recommendation of the inquiry and that is certainly what we will be putting to the States. That is part of the package overall.

Also raised was how much the operators licence fees will be. That is a matter that has not yet been resolved by the States. The honourable Member for Murray asked for notice about new regulations to be given to industry. That is not always practical but I will repeat again that in the spirit of this legislation and in the approach to this problem that will be discussed with industry. There will be consultation on the regulations. This legislation is only going to work on that basis, and I underline that point. It has got this far because there has been good will and good faith on the part of all parties concerned and the Government will continue on that basis. The honourable member for Murray also asked whether there would be a combined fee for a prime mover and trailer. The answer is yes, but the cost for the prime mover and trailer will be combined into one figure. In the case of independent operators, who in some cases own only a prime mover and the freight forwarder provides the trailer, there will be a split fee. Those fees will be determined on the basis of axle loadings. In discussions with industry we have found that that is the fairest way to deal with that problem and I provide that information for the honourable member.

I am currently examining the proposed membership of the Australian Transport Advisory Committee, ATAC, and I hope in the next few weeks to be able to announce the composition of that Committee. This matter has gone forward on the basis of frankness and good faith between all parties and I am quite confident that will continue. The honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) complained about the speed of this legislation and I have responded to that. He referred to Minister Roper's letter from Victoria. I assume that he has a copy of that letter. My response to Minister Roper was a response to all State Ministers, so it was not some coup for the honourable member for Bass to have that information, it was not some secret piece of information. My response, as I said, was provided to all State Ministers and referred to a letter that the Victorian Minister had earlier written to me on the matter. He did not have any advance start on anybody else.

The contribution of the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham) I think is the classic of them all. Here we have a landmark piece of road transport legislation dealing with a problem that this federation has not been able to resolve in the past, and the honourable member for the Northern Territory has seen it as appropriate to confine most of his comments to the Alice Springs-Darwin railway. I am sure that the truckies of the Territory have No. 1 interest in the Alice Springs-Darwin railway. The honourable member referred to the `parlous state' of the north-south highway route. As I have said to him before in this chamber-I will say it again in his absence-when, as chief Minister, he was negotiating with our Government about the Alice Springs-Darwin railway and it was put to him that the alternative was the upgrading of the national highway between Alice Springs and Darwin, his response, on a number of occasions, was that the road was adequate in its then existing condition. I am talking about May-June 1983, more than two years ago. For him to address this chamber from the Opposition benches this afternoon and have the temerity to refer to the `parlous state' of the highway system between Alice Springs and Darwin personifies cheek and impudence, and it does explain a flexibility in expressions from the honourable member.

He said that the shipping services to the Territory were cancelled. I have to say that the business enterprises of this Government are operating on the basis of providing those services that earn their keep. He said at the time that private industry would rush in to provide these other shipping services. Two years later they have not yet materialised. We are not in the business of running services which are not used and which are a call upon taxpayers when they cannot pay their way. I say to the honourable member for the Northern Territory that those days are over. That fairy godmother flew away about 2 1/2 years ago. There is strict control of Government expenditure. It is responsible government expenditure; it does not take the form of handouts for individual members as the former Chief Minister wanted. In his confused argument he went on about there being a case for the Alice Springs-Darwin railway. All I have to say to him is that the Hill Independent Economic Inquiry into Transport Services to the Northern Territory, an inquiry of competence and validity, showed quite clearly that to proceed with the construction of that line would be a serious misallocation of resources. But since then another report has been put forward, to which the honourable member has referred, by some Canadian group. I say to him and to all those who espouse the view put forward in that report that the Alice Springs-Darwin railway is an intra-Territory route. It does not involve Federal government; it is simply a matter for Territory decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the 1983 campaign the Prime Minister promised to build it.

—We have no time for spendthrifts like my friend opposite. Those days are over. But if the railway is such a good proposition, as the honourable member has put, the Territory Government will rush in to build it. I am sure that, given the competence, the resources and the expertise in business of those who sit opposite now-they say that they know how to run a business-they will be rushing to put their money into it. It will be such a good thing! They will want to be in to float it. Why do honourable members opposite need government assistance? They should get their hands out of the taxpayer's pocket. Those days are over; they are gone. But honourable members opposite will be rushing to put their own resources into the project. I suggest to the honourable member that he take that proposition back to his colleagues.

SPEECH.PARA: But there is one beautiful twist to the story. Back on 14 July 1983 a special Press conference was held in Darwin, attended by the now leader of the Opposition in South Australia and the present honourable member for the Northern Territory, and with the approval of the Premier of Queensland. At that Press conference a wonderful scheme was announced to build that railway, financed by the Queensland Government, from Mount Isa to Darwin via Alice Springs and down to Adelaide. The Queensland Government was going to fund it. It was all go. I noticed a couple of weeks ago in a report in the Daily Telegraph that the Premier of Queensland was scathing in some criticism he made of the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, who has now suggested that the private sector could build that railway. The Premier of Queensland feels that he has been betrayed. He wanted to be in on that deal; he wanted to build that railway. So why bring a request for assistance here? The Premier of Queensland announced on 14 July 1983, that he wanted to build the railway. The former Chief Minister has said that this is a wonderful goer and that business would want to be in it, and the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) says that it is a great proposition and that it ought to be built, that he can find the money, that they have the money and the expertise. They should get their hands out of the taxpayer's pocket. The railway is not a problem for this Government; it is a problem for the Territory and, if need be, the private sector.

The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) referred to the neglect of the trucking industry. That is a neglect of the past, of the previous Government. As I said, this Government has moved on that issue and I thank the industry and the organisations and governments concerned for their co-operation. The honourable member complained about road expenditure. We are also correcting that failing of the present Opposition. Suffice to say that in some seven years it slashed road funding in this country by some half a billion dollars. The highway to which the honourable member referred is part of a total allocation for Victoria. It is being considered along with other proposed expenditure items. At the time the response to which he referred was made, we had not received any proposals from the Minister of Transport in Victoria. Those proposals were received subsequently and will be considered in line with other requests.

The honourable member for Gippsland raised the matter of rate regulation rejected by the May National Road Freight Industry Inquiry. The mere fact that we accepted the May inquiry's recommendations that we reject rate regulation is sufficient evidence of our support of them. We have rejected that proposal. We have not entertained the idea of regulating either rates or capacity. Rather, we are concentrating on strengthening the industry and making it safer.

Then we had the contribution of the honourable member for O'Connor-this self-proclaimed expert on the road industry (Mr Tuckey)-that was the most disappointing contribution of all. He displayed his usual negative attitude. If ever there was evidence of somebody who was out of touch with industry it was that contribution. The honourable member is completely out of touch. It may have been his particular approach to industry, but it was out of touch with the mainstream thinking of the industry. He went on to say that a new charge would be placed on operators. Sure, it is a new charge, but it is a charge that the industry and the State governments want. We have agreed to legislate for it. We get no benefit out of it. There is no net reward to this Government; we are just providing the legislative means for it. But it will put all operators in the industry on a fairer basis. That is what it is all about. The honourable member in his other argument referred to all the taxes that the industry has to pay. All I can say to him about that is that those taxes are common to all industries. If anybody is to blame for the price of fuel in this country it is those who sit opposite, who introduced the import parity pricing policy, who trebled the price of petrol and quadrupled the Federal fuel rated revenue take in their seven years of office. Again they come along and bleat to us. It is their problem and we are trying to make the best of it that we can. With this legislation the industry will be in a much better position.

The real objective is to get the economy growing. There was 5 per cent growth in 1983-84, almost 5 per cent last year, and there has been a 4 1/2 per cent growth in the current year. That is what business wants. It does not want excuses; it wants strong economy that is growing, lifting demand and lifting cargoes. That is the answer to the problem, not handouts. For heaven's sake, honourable members opposite should get their hands out of the taxpayer's pocket. There is an end to the spendthrifts opposite. We are getting back to building the economy.

I think I have covered all the questions that have been asked by members of the Opposition. I thank the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar) for his reasoned contribution. I stress to him that it is not a matter of road or rail but of road and rail each performing a particular task. The honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) spoke of the intrusion of the Commonwealth tax and big brother. I say to him that he has misinterpreted and misunderstood what the legislation is about. Here are sufficient controls in the legislation. The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) has argued for uniformity, yet he does not want the provisions which would ensure that uniformity.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is not what I said. What I said was that we should have the safety standard provisions in front of us.

—Well, I do not want to take more of the time of the House going through them. I will give the honourable member a note, to save the time of the House, on road safety standards. (Extension of time granted) I thank the House. The standards will be discussed with industry. They could be modelled along the lines of the dangerous goods case. As I said, none of this will work without proper consultation with the industry. In respect of clause 45, he addressed the issue of information being difficult to obtain yet easy to destroy. It does not affect the honest operator and is clearly aimed at those who might otherwise cheat on the system or on their mates in the industry. I am advised that the High Court held that there is implied privilege for legal professional advice in a similar provision in the Income Tax Assessment Act. I thank the House for the contributions. I commend the Bill to the House and reject the amendment.

I sincerely want to obtain more information on this subject, as I think others do too-some in the industry and some in the other States. The first question I pose concerns the three separate definitions for a monitoring device. The first is a monitoring device; the second is a charge monitoring device, and the third is a standard monitoring device. In each of the definitions the device has the ability to be any of the others. When one tries to find out what is actually different about a charge monitoring device, all one can find in clause 36 is that it is a device in which the word `charge' is used. I would like to know what the difference is between a charge monitoring device and any other form of monitoring device. What function does it fulfil? What purpose is it for? What type of charge does it actually cover, quantify or allocate? My next question concerns clause 8 of the Interstate Road Transport Bill. A number of people have asked questions in this respect. The clause states:

SPEECH.PARA: Motor vehicles and trailers to be registered
A person shall not-
drive on a road;
cause or permit to be driven on a road; or
cause or permit to be left standing on a road;
a motor vehicle or trailer-

That is the initial list, at least, of questions that I have to put to the Minister. TALK.START.PARA: —One area which I wish to raise with the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) concerns the cost recovery processes envisaged by the Minister in regard to rail transport. the person has, after the commencement of this section, on one or more occasions, contravened, attempted to contravene, or been involved in a contravention of, one or more relevant safety provisions; and

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us look at the matter. The honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) asked: What are monitoring devices? There are three types of monitoring device. SPEECH.PARA: In regard to clause 10 (1) (c), as to who will decide whether the vehicle is unsafe, at this stage I expect that that will be done by the States because they are registered under State laws, and State regulations will apply. There will be an opportunity for industry to be involved. Certainly, they can still be disallowed by the Parliament. They are subject to parliamentary disallowance. So there is every safeguard. DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF SUBMARINE ESCAPE TRAINING FACILITY, HMAS STIRLING, WESTERN AUSTRALIA

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament:
Construction of a submarine escape training facility, HMAS Stirling, Garden Island, Western Australia

This proposal was referred to the Public Works Committee on 20 March 1985 and is for the construction of a simulated submarine environment with design aspects representative of those in present and future submarines. The training facility will comprise:
a submarine escape training tank incorporating a submarine escape training module;
a shallow training module;
support services for the training tank and modules;
an eight level reinforced concrete building to house the tank, associated teaching areas and support services;
site works, building and engineering services.

The limit of cost of the works is $10.3m at February 1985 prices. With adjustment for cost escalation, due entirely to increases in building industry prices, the current estimate is $11.3m at August 1985 prices. The Committee has reported favourably on the proposal and has recommended construction of the works.

The primary requirement of the proposal is to construct a facility in which submariners may be trained in methods of underwater escape from a stricken submarine by, firstly, classroom instruction and, secondly, instruction and drill in simulated conditions. A secondary requirement is that the facility will support training in special diving techniques. A joint Department of Defence-Department of Housing and Construction fact finding mission inspected a number of similar facilities in the United States, the United Kingdom, Germany and Norway. The appraisal of these overseas facilities has enabled the two departments to incorporate the combined experience of those facilities into this proposal.

Subject to the approval of this House, it is intended to commence calling tenders in October 1985 and to award the first contract in early December 1985. Actual construction would commence in January 1986. An expenditure of $1m is anticipated this financial year and the completion target date is August 1987. It is expected that these works will generate average employment on site of 40 positions, peaking to 80 with off-site employment of approximately 100 engaged in prefabrication, the escape tank and the modules. I thank the Public Works Committee for its effort in examining this proposal and for the support it has given. I commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) for making the information available to me. The Opposition does not object to this work being approved. However, we would like to say this to the Minister: Because of these facilities being at a distance from a major centre of population, and with the usual dirth of employment opportunities in this kind of area, it seems to us to be a prime target for maximisation of use of private enterprise rather than departmental employees. In that respect we note the Minister's statement on employment numbers. In this case the Department of Housing and Construction should really act in the role of managing agent. As such it should make sure that most of the work is given to private enterprise, that the use of local tradesmen and subcontractors is optimised, that employment opportunities in the area are widely publicised, that the most competitive quotes are obtained from tradespeople in the area and that the role of the Department is minimised. We wish the Department well with the project.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very briefly to the motion which, as Deputy Chairman of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I am more than happy to support. I must confess that when we approached this inquiry we were very conscious of its relative remoteness. We were very conscious of the environmental issues about which many people in that part of the world could quite excusably have had some apprehension. We as a Committee are enormously pleased to find that the submarine escape training facility, which honourable members will appreciate is a tower building, will be strategically placed so that it will be non-intrusive on the environment.

SPEECH.PARA: One found in that inquiry that in peacetime the greatest hazard to which the Royal Australian Navy is exposed rests in quite an achievement. If my memory serves me correctly they are the tamars which are peculiar to Garden Island. I feel quite free to say on behalf of my colleagues that the Committee was impressed enormously. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the House for very long in dealing with the Census and Statistics Amendment Bill, which involves a relatively minor amendment to the Census and Statistics Act 1905. The major amendment seeks to extend the ambit of the census statistics to enable external Territories to be included in the 1986 census and future censuses of population and housing conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The earlier censuses were conducted under local ordinances. This means that the inhabitants of the Terri- tories will be treated in exactly the same way as other Australians but, because of cost benefit considerations, the Territories to be included in the census will be prescribed by regulation. It is estimated that the additional cost of extending the census to the Territories will be $58,000. The Opposition supports the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: There is another amendment relating to section 14 of the Act which covers the provisions allowing a person to avoid stating religious denomination or sect. There is a technical change to the wording of that section which does not remove the right of the person to omit such declarations. The Opposition supports that. We note also that the amendments in this Bill do not extend Part III of the Census and Statistics Act to external territories and the Part III provisions of the Act relate to statistical gatherings outside the census. These might not be relevant to the particular Territories, which have their own requirements, and they will be dealt with in the ordinary manner. I will now conclude my remarks to allow my colleagues to speak to this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Census and Statistics Amendment Bill will do two things. First, it will bring the external Territories clearly within the ambit of the Act so that the populations of the external Territories will be included in the Census and Statistics Act. Secondly, the amendments will clarify section 14 of the Act so that the original intention is no longer in question-that is, that a person is not liable to any penalty for not answering a question relating to what religious denomination or sect he may belong to.

SPEECH.PARA: The first amendment inserts a new section 2 into the Act so that the Government's policy of equal treatment of all citizens is carried out. Instead of each census in the external Territories being carried out through local ordinances, the inhabitants of the external Territories will be treated in the same way as other Australians. It is extremely important that the Government of the day has at its fingertips an up-to-date data bank of basic information about the Australian population if it is to bring about relevant and appropriate legislation and changes for the betterment of the Australian way of life. Ignorance and guesswork about our citizens lead to poor government; enlightenment and information, coupled with an appropriate comprehension of what is best for Australia, lead to good government.

But, platitudes aside, what does our census, taken every five years, tell us about our population and what analysis should government apply to the information gathered? Every time prior to a census being taken there is a public debate on what questions should or should not be included in the census. Most of the heated debate is around privacy and the right to inquire into personal affairs, particularly the pecuniary standing and wealth of individuals and households. I strongly suspect that the concern for privacy is not always genuine, but often a cloak, a screen, to hide the shame of being poor and the guilt of being wealthy when there is so much poverty around.

The concern for privacy is too often a sham. The census and the statistician, and indeed the government, are not concerned with details of an individual-only in aggregate information which will build a comprehensive picture of the Australian population which, in turn, will provide a basis for macro-economic and social policies. Section 13 (3) of the Act protects that privacy and will continue to do so. It quite clearly prohibits the release of information which could lead to identification of any individual. I believe it is important to gain information on the spread of incomes in the population and the distribution of wealth in Australia. Would a census establish in 1986 the trend of the statistical sampling carried out by the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty which showed that in 1973 8.2 per cent of the Australian population-that is, 780,000 people lived below the poverty line?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I do not desire to intrude into the honourable member's speech, but I would remind him that this Bill is a pretty narrow one.

—In 1984 the census showed that 18 per cent or 2.8 million people, including some 800,000 children, lived below the poverty line. Both Labor and Liberal governments enjoyed office in that time-the Liberal Government for 7 1/2 years of those 11 years. Undoubtedly the growth in unemployment and inflation contributed greatly to the growth in poverty. Would a census confirm some 1968 studies which showed that the top 10 per cent of income earners earned 10 times the income of the bottom 10 per cent of income earners? How has our wealth been distributed since 1982, when the wealthiest 2,500 Australians earned, or had assets which totalled as much as those earned or possessed by the poorest 2 1/2 million people?

SPEECH.PARA: I strongly suspect that the massive redistribution of wealth and disparity of income that have occurred over the last 20 years are continuing unabated. The debate on tax reform and the Goverment's measures over the next few days should keep in mind the increasing imbalance and maldistribution of income and wealth in this country.

Honourable members may be surprised to learn that the only census in this country to measure the distribution of wealth and income was held in 1915-70 years ago. That census was unique in that it covered all individuals in the population but not those in the external territories over 18 years. Thus, it had the broadest coverage of all studies of income and wealth distribution in Australia. It also provided comprehensive, detailed information on the forms that assets took but not of the income from each of those assets. Without going into details, the most significant findings were that the distribution of wealth and income were highly unequal and that inequalities of income and wealth were closely related.

The prime purpose of the 1915 war census into wealth and income was to establish the private wealth of the community so as to measure what resources were available for the World War I war effort. The distribution of income and wealth was a secondary consideration. If we really do mean to make war against poverty we will need to know our total wealth and how that wealth is distributed. Any war against poverty will require the best weapons to investigate and monitor its extent and incidence-absolute poverty and relative poverty, the latter, of course, requiring information on the distribution of wealth and income. Private individual information must become public aggregate information through the Census and Statistics Act. It will mean that if questions on income and wealth are included on the census form, it must be obligatory that they be answered; otherwise the necessary information may not be forthcoming.

The census should not be seen as the sole source of information on wealth and income. Other weapons in the armory against poverty include comprehensive inquiries as has been suggested by my colleague the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi), and sample data techniques. Each method has its deficiencies but together, over time, they would paint an accurate and complete dynamic picture of the distribution of wealth and income of the Australian population.

The census has the advantage that the whole population would be covered and could be used as a base check against sampling. The census has the disadvantage that it may not be able to provide the details and checks on valuations that can be determined through surveys. In both inquiries there is always the danger of respondents unwittingly, or deliberately, misstating asset values and incomes or misinterpreting questions. However, for all that, I believe that census data and inquiries can complement each other with some of the broader details such as the incidence of shareholding being asked in the census and more detailed questions, such as the value of such shareholding, being obtained from an inquiry. The Commonwealth Statistician at the time, Mr Knibbs, in the conclusion to his report on the war census published in 1918, stated:

. . . in view of the fact that the wealth and income census gives important results in respect of the community which are not obtainable by any other method of estimation, it appears desirable that such a census should be taken every ten years in conjunction with the ordinary population census-

That is under the Act, we are dealing with, which was in place before the war census was conducted. Mr Knibb's final conclusion was that the most satisfactory wealth estimates will be obtained by a means of a combination of the wealth census and inventory methods. In conclusion, my message tonight is to recommend to the Government that questions on wealth and income be part of the general five-year census and that it be first held next year so that the war against poverty can be stepped up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond briefly to the comments of the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb), who referred to people having created controversy prior to a census on the grounds of some ill-conceived notion of false concern for privacy. I remind the honourable member that some years ago even the Law Reform Commission told the Australian Statistician to smarten up his act. I have spoken frequently on the Australian Bureau of Statistics. What aroused me originally was seeing several stacks of census forms around the edge of a lounge room where a private party of 30 to 40 people was being held in the late 1960s or the early 1970s. The person involved was a superviser. In that situation there was as much concern about privacy as there would be in a prison.

SPEECH.PARA: I also remember when the Bureau eventually agreed to provide envelopes. This followed little notes being left by census collectors stating: `Leave it in the letterbox or under the doormat'. People were expected to tick their income levels and there was considerable outrage and disappointment about what went on. Thus, the Bureau introduced the envelopes. To get one of those envelopes was like trying to pull a tooth out of an old chook. The envelopes were hardly available. I remember the big controversy in the mid-1970s when the Statistician had two or three of his top men visit me in my Canberra office. They told me that the envelopes would be available. When the census started they were locked away in some Brisbane warehouse and people could not get them. That is an historical account for the honourable member for Streeton, and every bit of it is true. So he should not think that the concern about privacy by people such as me has been misplaced.

I am not going to spend my time talking about the past because I want to raise a matter for the Government, honourable members on this side of the House and perhaps the Statistician's office to consider. During the recent recess-as a result of my interest in the Bureau being reawakened, so to speak, by its ramming some old man through the courts in Brisbane because he had failed to comply with the legislation-I started to look in a positive way at the structure of the Statistician's office and at how much it was costing Australia. I conducted my own overseas research.

I had an interesting conversation with the United States statistician, the statistician of Great Britain and also the statistician of Canada. It suddenly unfolded that the Australian Statistician's office staff of 3,500 people has a ratio of one statistician for every 4,400 Australians. In the United States of America there is one statistician for every 18,500 of the population and in the United Kingdom there is one for about every 15,500 people. This information was available from the statisticians of those countries. I concede that it is a very difficult area in which to make absolute comparisons because one is comparing like with partly like in some instances. Many countries have different arrangements. I am endeavouring to make the point that when there is a disparity of having one statistician for every 4,400 people in Australia, compared with one for 18,500 in the United States, or one for 15,500 in the United Kingdom, we are entitled to examine this matter further. I went further and discovered that the Australian Statistician recoups less than half a per cent of the Bureau's annual expenditure as a result of the sale of his information, whereas in the United States of America 30 per cent in recouped.

I know that many honourable members on the other side will squirm about privatisation and portray it as a dirty word. But I hope that they see beyond that. There is a message that one can question the quality and the timing of the material that we are producing in Australia. Perhaps the Americans, who are more market-orientated, are producing information that people will buy. In Australia the Bureau can often hardly give it away. Most of the publications cost somewhere between $1 and $5 at the most. There are about 500 of its publications-I am relying on memory-and about 375 attract a price that is a mere pittance.

In the few minutes available I will make some positive suggestions about what the Government should be looking at to restructure the ABS. In doing so, bearing in mind that if in the United States there is one statistician for every 18,500 people and one for 15,500 in the United Kingdom, it would not be fair to say that the ABS, servicing a country with a smaller population, should have its staff at a similar level. But let us have, for example, one statistician for every 10,000 people. That is reasonable. The honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) nods his head in agreement with the suggestion that if the other countries have such levels, one in 10,000 is not an unfair level for us. I repeat the suggestion that we should improve the quality of information and put it on a user-pays basis for both governments and private users. I refer again to the fact that we get less than half of one per cent of revenues from sales of information whereas the United States gains about 30 per cent.

Secondly, the Bureau should charge those organisations and departments which ask for surveys to be conducted on their behalf rather than doing it free of charge, as at present. Many government departments ask for surveys to be conducted although not all requests are satisfied at the moment. If a charge were made the more frivolous or unnecessary requests would cease to see the light of day. For example, of the 99 requests for surveys made to the ABS in 1984-85, 11 were made by the Office of the Status of Women. Almost 12 per cent of requests were made by this new little organisation that has been recently established. Were this office and others forced to pay for these surveys from a limited budget, they might examine the desirability or the necessity of collecting the information in the first place. As well, if cost recovery pricing were adopted, it would provide a mechanism for private enterprise to pay for and receive the results of specialised surveys, conducted at their behest, using the Bureau's expertise and legislative powers. This purchasing facility is not available at present to private enterprise.

Thirdly, some or all of the Bureau's computer operations should be contracted to private enterprise. About 625 members of its staff are locked into this aspect. Fourthly, if the computer operations are found to be too integrally involved with other ABS functions, entire areas of statistical collection, processing and dissemination would be contracted out to private enterprise. Although the ABS believes that private enterprise organisations-such as the Morgan (Roy) Research Centre Pty Ltd-are not sufficiently professional to collect, process and disseminate statistical information of national importance, not only does the private sector disagree, as expected, but also it can point to highly complicated surveys which have been successfully completed for such organisations as the Bureau of Labour Market Research.

The observation has been made by some in the business sector that most of the Bureau's statistics are useless to them because they are so out of date by the time they become available. This is another strong argument for selling entire areas of statistics collection to private enterprise, which would be obliged to provide timely information for its users, otherwise it would find itself without customers. Fifthly, the Bureau should encourage and charge commercially for the outplacement of professional Bureau staff who advise others on survey methodology. Sixthly, it should establish an external oversight body which has the power to examine: All existing forms and surveys to ensure that they are relevant, easy to fill out, and not too burdensome; all proposed surveys and forms for the same criteria; and the Bureau's entire budget each year using zero-base budgeting, rather than the requests for yearly increases. This oversight task would be comparable to that of the Office of Management and Budget in the United States which performs these tasks for the Bureau of the Census.

The seventh point is that an independent inquiry should be established into the ABS in particular, and government statistical collection, processing and dissemination in general. The inquiry should comprise public service and private enterprise users and providers of statistical information, with importance being placed on the input from small business. The head of the inquiry should be drawn from the private sector and its terms of reference should be to increase efficiency and to promote cost-cutting and revenue-increasing measures. The eighth point is that the census should be ten-yearly or decennial-this would be a bomb to the minds of honourable members such as the honourable member for Streeton-with interim sample surveys to compensate for the loss of information. From information available on manning and budgetary levels in overseas statistical agencies, there is evidence of a correlation between high expenditure and frequency of census, over and above the actual costs of the census.

As I said before, in the United States, which has a ten-yearly census, there is one statistician for every 18,000 people, and Great Britain has one for every 15,500. But I repeat that Australia has one for every 4,411 people. There are possibly more statisticians than there are members of the Royal Australian Air Force. Other countries such as Germany, South Africa, Great Britain, Norway and the United States have a ten-yearly census. Japan has three every twenty years, as does France. Our five-yearly census has been born more out of historical precedent than from a defined need. The powers that we gave to the Statistician earlier this year by altering the Census and Statistics Act to give him access to the Australian Taxation Office would allow him to supplement the information. If the honourable member for Streeton really wants a proper picture of wealth, this facility would provide it and give a greater update of the system than he suggested. His suggestion was simply for an enlargement of the existing system.

I would then establish, encourage, strongly market and charge for on a full cost-recovery basis, an electronic statistical dissemination system for major users. If it were really updated, groups wanting information, such as newspapers, could plug in and the cost for that information could be related to the cost of collection. Now, the Bureau makes itself Mr Nice Guy to everybody. It boasts that if school kids want to take part in debates, both sides of the debate will be supplied with information. If people ring in, although it might take a little time, information is supplied. But if people were made to pay I am sure that a lot of this wasted time and wasted public money would stop because people would ask only for what they truly needed. Even the newspaper industry could use it this way. The Bureau seeks to be just `Mr Nice Guy' who is liked by helping often very mediocre people look good by supplying them with information.

I notice that the newly upgraded shadow Minister, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), is shaking his head in agreement. I also suggest that the compliance rates on surveys could be reduced to accommodate the conscientious objectors. If the Bureau does not obtain a 100 per cent kill, it railroads people through the courts. It wants everybody to answer its requests for information, yet Canada and other places settle on a 95 per cent or 96 per cent response. I believe that if a person feels strongly about not providing information that the Bureau could leave him or her be. I have seen the Bureau pursue people like fox terriers pursue rats. It is like the Mountie always getting his man-the Statisticians office must get compliance 100 per cent of the time. That is a ridiculous and unnecessary goal.

As a by-product of this situation, I suggest that a lot of the information that the Statistician collects in this country is inaccurate because when people feel resentment about the system they simply fill in anything or everything just for the sake of it. In my research during the recess I spoke to a lot of businessmen who privately confessed that when it came to providing information they just settled with close to what they thought because they find Bureau requirements virtually a pain in the neck. Some carelessly comply just to keep themselves out of trouble and the courts.

I suggest that the Bureau could smarten up its act in terms of accuracy if the Government, in conjunction with the Bureau, was prepared to acknowledge the hours that people are often required to spend on Bureau returns. If Myers, David Jones or a brewery are asked information on a monthly basis, those companies have a capacity to offset the time spent on filling in forms against income. Those companies employ people on wages to do that and it all works out in the profit and loss. Therefore, the Statistician or the Australian taxpayer is contributing towards the cost of that information gathering. There is no recognition of the efforts of the little businessman. I believe that if the Bureau wants a form filled in, and if that takes say four hours, it should allow that small businessman to deduct $80 off his income, or if he has to fill in a form three times a year, he deducts $240 off his income, so that there is some financial compensation. At the moment people are forced to comply by pointing a virtual gun at the head. I am quite sure that this frequently leads to inaccurate information.

Effective policy making and administration requires accurate, comprehensive information about the number and characteristics of the popualtion. Intrusiveness is minimised as far as possible and one of the amendments we are discussing today makes it quite clear that respondents do not have to state their religion if they do not want to. That leads to the second issue I want to briefly mention-whether or not completed census forms should be destroyed. In Australia at present census forms are pulped once the information has been collated so as to reassure those who are seriously concerned about privacy. No names or addresses are permanently recorded once the statistical information has been extracted. Australia is unusual in doing this. In Canada, the United States of America and Britain all census forms are preserved. In New Zealand, every second census is retained indefinitely. Census forms in Australia have been destroyed immediately the data has been collated only since 1971. Before that they were retained for a period to allow new cross-tabulations once the initial analysis had been completed. Some colonial censuses were preserved and these are now an important research source for historians and genealologists in particular. Census material can be of use for epidemiological research as well. There are many people in Australia who support retention of the forms for these reasons. Similar constraints could be imposed on the use of Australian forms if they were retained. I hope that the general acceptance of the 1986 census throughout the community will reassure the planners and encourage re-consideration of the retention of the 1991 census forms. TALK.START.PARA: —The latest Australian Bureau of Statistics labour force statistics for August 1985 show a slight rise in unemployment to 8.3 per cent of the work force. I would be relieved if I thought this reflected reality. The problem with national statistics is that they do not give a true picture of unemployment rates in some key areas of the economy. Rural Australia has been disadvantaged, not only through a general shift in revenue-on one estimate about $648m has been re-allocated away from rural Australia since the Labor Government came to office-but mainly because of insensitive and non-consultative decision-making by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue of employment is particularly serious in the two main regional centres in the electorate of Forrest-Albany and Bunbury. We can forget about the 8.3 per cent; it would be more like 18 per cent in Albany, according to the local Chamber of Commerce and others, and in Bunbury the unemployment rate is currently about 16 per cent. The residents of Albany wonder why the only endangered species that the Labor Government is not concerned about is the town's industries. Last year the Government introduced quotas to reduce Australia's tuna catch. The limits set made the fishing ventures unprofitable. This was a nail in the coffin for Albany's fishing fleet of 100 ships and a canning factory employing on a seasonal basis about 350 workers. The final nail was driven home this year when the Government introduced lower negotiable quotes, and most fishermen have been forced to sell. As a result, the fishing fleet from Albany has lost its viable infrastructure. Even if Hunts Foods Pty Ltd Canning Factory which, I might say, is now in receivership, continues to stay open, it will not be canning locally caught tuna. The tragedy is that the Government has given away a profitable industry to an export competitor.

The closure of Borthwicks was another case. Here the Labor Government went to the extraordinary lengths of granting the unemployment benefit to striking workers. Without the financial pressure to return to work, and under the thoroughly mischievous leadership of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, the workers remained on strike long enough to ensure the closure of the meat works. Employment statistics will never record the number of people who leave town, or lose their second job, or do not register. The loss is noted by the retail sector, and a decline in living standards throughout the community. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had promised the certainty of this development in the 1984 election campaign at Collie. In the last week of the election he visited the electorate of Forrest a number of times, which I might say was all fairly helpful, and assured the people of Forrest that the smelter would go ahead. With these sorts of definite assurances, business and local government were prepared to meet the new demand. The small business sector in Bunbury is particularly efficient as a result of the city's relative proximity to Perth. It has to share the market forces. Profit margins are slight and the small business sectors in Bunbury and Albany have been the first to feel the impact of the Labor Government's policies. TALK.START.PARA: —Honour- able members may be familiar with an article which appeared on page 13 of today's Australian Financial Review entitled `Bendigo: a vision that went terribly wrong'. In a very long article the author, Lim Say Boon, makes a number of points about Bendigo which I believe need to be addressed. Amongst others, he says that the main economic activity is manufacturing, that the official unemployment level is 10.3 per cent and rising and that estimated total unemployment, including hidden unemployment, is 15 per cent. The writer makes a number of scurrilous allegations concerning the level of unemployment and industrial development in Bendigo. I believe it is pertinent to put some facts before honourable members and that newspaper.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the broadest measure of economic performance, we can look at the quarterly job vacancy figures which are released publicly by the Bendigo Commonwealth Employment Service office. Those figures show that the Bendigo office's notification level is higher than that of any other provincial centre in Australia and compares more than favourably with those of most metropolitan larger offices. For example, in the most recent quarter, June 1985, there were some 1,754 notified vacancies. I point out for the benefit of honourable members that that compares with the June quarter 1983 figure of 1,172. In other words, there has been an improvement in advertised job vacancies in Bendigo in the last two years of 49.6 per cent and there is, therefore, no doubt that those figures are impressive and show that Bendigo's economic performance is particularly reassuring and indicative of a strong growth trend.

Another way in which we can look at Bendigo's economic performance is to compare its current level of unemployment with the level when this Government took office in March 1983. In March 1983 the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations calculated that the unemployment level in Bendigo was a massive 14.8 per cent. I am pleased to say that the most recent CES job figures for Bendigo show that the current unemployment level for June 1985 is 8.9 per cent. That means that there has been a massive reduction from 14.8 per cent to 8.9 per cent in the space of just two years.

We can also look at the strong economic recovery in Bendigo as evidenced in the housing industry. The people of Bendigo are putting their confidence and their faith into new housing activity. The June quarter Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show that 226 new homes were approved for construction in Bendigo at a total value of more than $10m. Again that compares with a figure two years ago, in March 1983, of $3.3m. In other words, there has been an increase in housing activity in the Bendigo economy of more than 300 per cent in just over two years. That is hardly evidence of an economy with a malaise. It is certainly evidence of an effective local member, a strong local economy and, of course, effective national economic policies.

The final matter I wish to comment on is industrial development because, according to the Australian Financial Review journalist, Bendigo `finds itself in an industrial time warp lacking in adequate mechanisms to promote structural change'. The fact is that nothing could be further from the truth. New capital investment in the Bendigo region is running at record and unprecedented levels across the whole range of economic activity. Enterprises such as Elders-IXL, through Mayfair and Barastoc, Allied Mills Ltd and Stafford Ellinson, to name just a few well-known firms, would not invest in a area that they considered `trapped in an industrial time warp'. Local firms like Gillies Bros Pty Ltd would not successfully float stock issue on the Melbourne Stock Exchange unless they were confident of future profitability. Finally, in respect of industrial development, it should be said, that of the five firms mentioned in the scurrilous Australian Financial Review article, each is operating at higher production levels than two years ago and four have improved their employment levels over the last two years by 25 per cent.

In summary, job vacancies in Bendigo are up by 49.6 per cent. The rate of unemployment is down from 14.8 per cent to 8.9 per cent. The number of unemployment beneficiaries is down by 19 per cent. The value of housing approval in Bendigo in the last two years is up by 300 per cent. Those figures are not made up. They are not evidence of a town suffering economic malaise. In fact, they are hardly typical of a city with a 15 per cent hidden unemployment rate. They are typical of a city with strong economic growth which will remain strong into the future.

Special arrangements will also be made to continue payment of the handicapped child's allowance for children who, for a period of up to 28 days in any one year, temporarily leave home to receive respite care. The total additional allocation of funds for disability services in 1985-86 will be about $121m. This amount includes a forward commitment of $9m which will be available for new projects eligible for funding under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act.

While maintaining its support for institutional care in nursing homes and hostels, the Government is concerned to provide a realistic level of support for those aged and disabled people who prefer to remain living in their own homes. The focal point of the package announced in the 1984-85 Budget is the proposed cost-shared home and community care or HACC program. This program will enable an expansion of home and community care services available under existing programs such as home help and home nursing, as well as the provision of a wide range of new services such as home-based personal care, community-based respite care and transport and laundry services. SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the Parliament this evening about an all too often forgotten, if not deliberately ignored, part of Victoria. I refer to the beautiful and productive East Gippsland area incorporating the shires of Omeo, Tambo and Orbost. This productive and vital area of Gippsland and Australia is having the life choked out of it by both State and Federal governments.
—Swifts Creek is superb.

—The Minister for Primary Industry interjects that Swifts Creek is part of that area. He has been to Swifts Creek and he knows that it is populated by strong, independent farmers and people involved in farming-related service industries. Though the Minister can proudly claim to have been to that picturesque and productive area, his Government has done little by way of freight, fuel or services to assist those people. The Minister knows that they pay the same taxes as everybody else. However, they receive but a fraction of the services provided by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: It is all very well to use East Gippsland for tourism-for its beaches, for the skiing at Mt Hotham, for fishing, boating and hiking-but the people of this area are deliberately discouraged when it comes to industry and commerce. The two mainstays of this area of Australia are timber and grazing. Sadly for both of these industries, the policies of successive governments have resulted in a lowering of productivity and the return on investment. New industries are not permitted to be taken up. I cite as an example a marble mine which is just fractionally inside a national park at Berambra. A number of reductions in services have affected grazing. The fuel reduction burning program has been restricted. Forests Commission offices have been downgraded and their numbers reduced. There is a shortage of lands inspectors. The level of road funding is hopelessly inadequate for the more remote areas. Transport services for the public are practically non-existent. In addition, unemployment services for the young unemployed as well as the adult unemployed remain at a minimal level.

I cite as an example the proposal for community employment program funding by the Swifts Creek High School to set up a building program to establish a sports centre. The great advantage of this sports centre is that it will not be used just by the Swifts Creek High School, which the Minister for Primary Industry would have seen, but will also be of use to the community. This is an ideal opportunity for the Government to get behind a local community which will provide its own services with a minimal amount of government assistance. Yet it seems that the Government is less than enthusiastic about assisting the Swifts Creek High School to bring about this desperately needed community facility. The building project is of the order of a quarter of a million dollars, which is large by CEP standards. My argument is that in view of all the circumstances and taking into account the special need of this isolated area, the Government ought to be prepared to allow the initiative of the local residents to be rewarded. Surely all rules relating to CEP funding are flexible. Each application deserves to be looked at in its own right. For that reason I can see no earthly justification for depriving the Swifts Creek High School of this desperately needed facility.

Radio and television reception continues to be a problem for all residents in the East Gippsland region. Despite a great many representations to the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy), there is no light at the end of the tunnel. Perhaps the Aussat satellite will, to a large extent, allow the communications enjoyed by people in metropolitan Australia to be received by the residents of East Gippsland. However, such services will be provided at substantial cost to the residents themselves.

Everybody who lives in relatively remote or isolated areas expects to carry extra burdens and make sacrifices. However, they should not have to make the kinds of sacrifices that the Government expects them to make.
